Social capital and life satisfaction among Chinese and Korean elderly immigrants

Author: Kim, Bum J1; Linton, Kristen F; Lum, Wesley1 School of Social Work, University of Hawaii at Manoa, USA

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 87-100.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284269?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary Research has indicated that many Asian Americans experience life dissatisfaction. Studies have also found that social capital is a protective factor for life satisfaction. This study analyzed the impact of social capital and other demographic characteristics on the life satisfaction of 172 Chinese elderly immigrants and 205 Korean elderly immigrants. Chinese and Korean elderly immigrants participated in a structured survey, which measured social capital, life satisfaction, and demographic variables. Multiple regression analyses were conducted to test the impact of social capital on life satisfaction among Chinese and Korean elderly immigrants. Findings Social capital was a strong predictor of life satisfaction among Korean elderly immigrants (p < .05), while only one aspect of social capital, community partnership, was associated with life satisfaction of Chinese elderly immigrants (p < .05). Applications Social workers and social service agencies may improve life satisfaction among Korean and Chinese elderly immigrants by increasing their social capital. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+capital+and+life+satisfaction+among+Chinese+and+Korean+elderly+immigrants&amp;rft.au=Kim%2C+Bum+J%3BLinton%2C+Kristen+F%3BLum%2C+Wesley&amp;rft.aulast=Kim&amp;rft.aufirst=Bum&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313504699

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+capital+and+life+satisfaction+among+Chinese+and+Korean+elderly+immigrants&amp;rft.au=Kim%2C+Bum+J%3BLinton%2C+Kristen+F%3BLum%2C+Wesley&amp;rft.aulast=Kim&amp;rft.aufirst=Bum&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313504699

Citation Impact Scores of Top African American Scholars in Social Work Schools: The Story Behind the Data

Author: Huggins-Hoyt, Kimberly Y1; Holosko, Michael J; Briggs, Harold E; Barner, John R1 School of Social Work, University of Georgia, Athens, GA, USA

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 164-170.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284342?accountid=14667

Abstract: U.S. tenure-track positions have steadily declined over the past 30 years and emphasis on research productivity has escalated. To achieve higher research and scholarship goals, the literature revealed that African American scholars have additional issues to overcome beyond the usual hurdles and challenges confronting other faculty. This study explored current research productivity by examining citation impact scores (h-indices) collected from Publish or Perish of African American scholars in top 25 ranked schools of social work cited in the 2012 U.S. News and World Report. The resultant sample consisted of N = 14 scholars with h-index scores of 9 and higher. Results revealed nonsignificant statistical differences between specified subgroupings, and 80% of these scholars overexceeded their respective school mean h-index scores. Future research calls for a more comprehensive knowledge of faculty research and scholarship activities overall, including unique subgroups of Social Work scholars such as African Americans. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Citation+Impact+Scores+of+Top+African+American+Scholars+in+Social+Work+Schools%3A+The+Story+Behind+the+Data&amp;rft.au=Huggins-Hoyt%2C+Kimberly+Y%3BHolosko%2C+Michael+J%3BBriggs%2C+Harold+E%3BBarner%2C+John+R&amp;rft.aulast=Huggins-Hoyt&amp;rft.aufirst=Kimberly&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=164&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514530004

Avoidable Ignorance and the Role of Cochrane and Campbell Reviews

Author: Gambrill, Eileen11 University of California at Berkeley, Berkeley, CA, USA gambrill@berkeley.edu

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 147-163.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284567?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Campbell and Cochrane Collaborations were created to reveal the evidentiary status of claims focusing especially on the effectiveness of specific interventions. Such reviews are constrained by the population of studies available and biases that may influence this availability such as preferred framing of problems. This highlights the importance of attending to how problems are framed and the validity of measures used in such reviews, as well as the importance of reviews focusing on questions concerning problem framing and the accuracy of measures. Neglecting such questions, both within reviews of effectiveness and in separate reviews concerning related claims, results in lost opportunities to decrease avoidable ignorance. Domains of avoidable ignorance are suggested using examples of Cochrane/Campbell reviews. Without attention to problem framing, systematic reviews may contribute to maintaining avoidable ignorance. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Avoidable+Ignorance+and+the+Role+of+Cochrane+and+Campbell+Reviews&amp;rft.au=Gambrill%2C+Eileen&amp;rft.aulast=Gambrill&amp;rft.aufirst=Eileen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514533731

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Avoidable+Ignorance+and+the+Role+of+Cochrane+and+Campbell+Reviews&amp;rft.au=Gambrill%2C+Eileen&amp;rft.aulast=Gambrill&amp;rft.aufirst=Eileen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514533731

Unemployment Benefit Exhaustion: Incentive Effects on Job-Finding Rates

Author: Filges, Trine1; Geerdsen, Lars Pico; Knudsen, Anne-Sofie Due; Jorgensen, Anne-Marie Klint1 SFI Campbell, Copenhagen, Denmark

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 21-43.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284730?accountid=14667

Abstract: Purpose: This systematic review studied the impact of exhaustion of unemployment benefits on the exit rate out of unemployment and into employment prior to benefit exhaustion or shortly thereafter. Method: We followed Campbell Collaboration guidelines to prepare this review, and ultimately located 12 studies for final analysis and interpretation. Twelve studies could be included in the data synthesis. Results: We found clear evidence that the prospect of exhaustion of benefits results in a significantly increased incentive for finding work. Discussion: The theoretical suggestion that the prospect of exhaustion of benefits results in an increased incentive for finding work has been confirmed empirically by measures from seven different European countries, the United States, and Canada. The results are robust in the sense that sensitivity analyses evidenced no appreciable changes in the results. We found no strong indication of the presence of publication bias. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Unemployment+Benefit+Exhaustion%3A+Incentive+Effects+on+Job-Finding+Rates&amp;rft.au=Filges%2C+Trine%3BGeerdsen%2C+Lars+Pico%3BKnudsen%2C+Anne-Sofie+Due%3BJorgensen%2C+Anne-Marie+Klint&amp;rft.aulast=Filges&amp;rft.aufirst=Trine&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514529830

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Unemployment+Benefit+Exhaustion%3A+Incentive+Effects+on+Job-Finding+Rates&amp;rft.au=Filges%2C+Trine%3BGeerdsen%2C+Lars+Pico%3BKnudsen%2C+Anne-Sofie+Due%3BJorgensen%2C+Anne-Marie+Klint&amp;rft.aulast=Filges&amp;rft.aufirst=Trine&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=21&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514529830

Transition Services for Youth With Autism: A Systematic Review

Author: Westbrook, John D1; Fong, Carlton J; Nye, Chad; Williams, Ann; Wendt, Oliver; Cortopassi, Tara1 Disability Research to Practice, SEDL, Austin, TX, USA john.westbrook@sedl.org

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 10-20.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284745?accountid=14667

Abstract: Purpose As the number of individuals diagnosed with autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) rises, attention is increasingly focused on employment outcomes for individuals with ASD who are exiting public school settings. This review aimed to identify what works in transition programs to help students with ASD obtain competitive employment after graduation. Method Authors combed through the literature to find all research that could definitively identify interventions that predictably led to employment for transitioning youth. Results: While no definitive conclusions can be drawn based upon the current review, the authors identified qualitative research that addressed elements of potential successful employment placements for individuals with ASD. Discussion Future research efforts are needed to develop studies that utilize rigorous experimental designs to determine the relative effectiveness of the various interventions being utilized in transition programming for students with ASD. This review is published in its entirety in the Campbell Collaboration Library of Systematic Reviews. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Transition+Services+for+Youth+With+Autism%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;rft.au=Westbrook%2C+John+D%3BFong%2C+Carlton+J%3BNye%2C+Chad%3BWilliams%2C+Ann%3BWendt%2C+Oliver%3BCortopassi%2C+Tara&amp;rft.aulast=Westbrook&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=10&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514524836

Workfare versus reconceptualizing work: Rethinking social security reform for lone mothers in Hong Kong

Author: Leung, Lai-ching; Chan, Kam-wah

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 111-122.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284915?accountid=14667

Abstract: Workfare has become a dominant social welfare approach in dealing with unemployment in various cities around the world. Recent social security reforms for lone mothers on benefits in Hong Kong are examples of the application of workfare in practice. This article argues that workfare strategy based on an outdated industrial-productivist conception of work contributes to the marginalization and undervaluation of work performed by disadvantaged groups. A reconceptualization of work will help to open up new alternatives in social work practice. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Workfare+versus+reconceptualizing+work%3A+Rethinking+social+security+reform+for+lone+mothers+in+Hong+Kong&amp;rft.au=Leung%2C+Lai-ching%3BChan%2C+Kam-wah&amp;rft.aulast=Leung&amp;rft.aufirst=Lai-ching&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=111&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812461044

What Works in Developing Nations to Get Children Into School or Keep Them There?: A Systematic Review of Rigorous Impact Studies

Author: Petrosino, Anthony1; Morgan, Claire; Fronius, Trevor; Tanner-Smith, Emily E; Boruch, Robert F1 WestEd, Woburn, MA, USA

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 44-60.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284959?accountid=14667

Abstract: Due to evidence linking education and development, funding has been invested in interventions relevant to getting youth into school and keeping them there. This article reports on a systematic review of impact studies of these school enrollment interventions. Reports were identified through electronic searches of bibliographic databases and other methods. To be eligible, studies (1) assessed impact on primary or secondary school enrollment outcomes; (2) used a rigorous design; (3) were conducted in a low- or middle-income nation; (4) included at least one quantifiable measure of enrollment or related outcomes; (5) were available before December 2009; and (6) included data on participants post-1990. A coding instrument extracted data on study characteristics from each report. Standardized mean difference effect sizes were computed for the first effect reported. The sample includes 73 evaluations. The average effect size was positive across all outcomes. However, the results varied. Studies that focused on building new schools and other infrastructure interventions reported the largest average effects. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=What+Works+in+Developing+Nations+to+Get+Children+Into+School+or+Keep+Them+There%3F%3A+A+Systematic+Review+of+Rigorous+Impact+Studies&amp;rft.au=Petrosino%2C+Anthony%3BMorgan%2C+Claire%3BFronius%2C+Trevor%3BTanner-Smith%2C+Emily+E%3BBoruch%2C+Robert+F&amp;rft.aulast=Petrosino&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthony&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=44&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514524837

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=What+Works+in+Developing+Nations+to+Get+Children+Into+School+or+Keep+Them+There%3F%3A+A+Systematic+Review+of+Rigorous+Impact+Studies&amp;rft.au=Petrosino%2C+Anthony%3BMorgan%2C+Claire%3BFronius%2C+Trevor%3BTanner-Smith%2C+Emily+E%3BBoruch%2C+Robert+F&amp;rft.aulast=Petrosino&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthony&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=44&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514524837

Stepparenting issues and relationship quality: The role of clear communication

Author: Pace, Garrett T1; Shafer, Kevin; Jensen, Todd M; Larson, Jeffry H1 Bendheim-Thoman Center for Research on Child Wellbeing, Princeton University, USA

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 24-44.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285069?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary Using data from a sample of RELATE (the RELATionship Evaluation Survey) respondents in stepfamilies (N=560), this study examined the association between relationship quality (satisfaction and stability) and stepparenting issues. Although stepparenting issues can negatively impact romantic partners in stepfamilies, we suggest that high-quality communication may be a protective factor for individuals and couples stressed by their relationship with a nonbiological child. Findings Our results show that stepparenting issues are negatively associated with satisfaction and stability, but is partially mediated by clear-sending communication. Further, this mediation is stronger for women when considering satisfaction and for men when considering stability. Applications Our results show that stepparenting issues can be a strong sense of discord among romantic couples. Yet, they also indicate that clear-sending communication in relationships can substantially reduce the negative association of these issues with relationship quality. This finding suggests that therapeutic models that focus on emotionally focused couples therapy, structural family therapy, or address issues within the family system may be best for addressing common problems in stepfamilies. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Stepparenting+issues+and+relationship+quality%3A+The+role+of+clear+communication&amp;rft.au=Pace%2C+Garrett+T%3BShafer%2C+Kevin%3BJensen%2C+Todd+M%3BLarson%2C+Jeffry+H&amp;rft.aulast=Pace&amp;rft.aufirst=Garrett&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=24&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313504508

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Stepparenting+issues+and+relationship+quality%3A+The+role+of+clear+communication&amp;rft.au=Pace%2C+Garrett+T%3BShafer%2C+Kevin%3BJensen%2C+Todd+M%3BLarson%2C+Jeffry+H&amp;rft.aulast=Pace&amp;rft.aufirst=Garrett&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=24&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313504508

Utilizing Mutual Aid in Reducing Adolescent Substance Use and Developing Group Engagement

Author: Mogro-Wilson, Cristina1; Letendre, Joan; Toi, Hiroki; Bryan, Janelle1 University of Connecticut, West Hartford, CT, USA cristina.wilson@uconn.edu

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 129-138.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285105?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: This study assessed the effectiveness of mutual aid groups for high school students. Methods: A quasi-experimental design was applied to 242 adolescents, where every other adolescent was assigned to the intervention or the control condition. The study evaluated the influence of implementing mutual aid groups in decreasing perceived risk of substance use, favorable attitudes toward substance use, and reducing substance use while increasing group engagement. Participants were assessed at baseline, during Sessions 2 and 7, and treatment exit. General linear mixed-effects models were used to detect significant differences between treatment and control conditions. Results: Findings indicated mutual aid groups significantly reduced favorable attitudes toward drug use and decreased alcohol and marijuana usage compared to the control group. In addition, the adolescents in treatment significantly increased their group engagement. Conclusions: Results support mutual aid group work models for reducing alcohol use and increasing group engagement for high school youth. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Utilizing+Mutual+Aid+in+Reducing+Adolescent+Substance+Use+and+Developing+Group+Engagement&amp;rft.au=Mogro-Wilson%2C+Cristina%3BLetendre%2C+Joan%3BToi%2C+Hiroki%3BBryan%2C+Janelle&amp;rft.aulast=Mogro-Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Cristina&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513518080

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Utilizing+Mutual+Aid+in+Reducing+Adolescent+Substance+Use+and+Developing+Group+Engagement&amp;rft.au=Mogro-Wilson%2C+Cristina%3BLetendre%2C+Joan%3BToi%2C+Hiroki%3BBryan%2C+Janelle&amp;rft.aulast=Mogro-Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Cristina&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513518080

Subjective well-being, social work, and the environment: The impact of the socio-political context of practice on social worker happiness

Author: Shier, Micheal L1; Graham, John R1 School of Social Policy and Practice, University of Pennsylvania, USA mshier@sp2.upenn.edu

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 3-23.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285136?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary The environmental context of direct social work practice has been found to impact social worker subjective well-being. Most research focus on the geographic and cultural characteristics of that practice environment. To expand this knowledge domain a qualitative inquiry has been undertaken to understand what aspects of the socio-political environment impacted social worker well-being. Findings This qualitative study, with a sample of social workers (n =19), found three themes related to the socio-political environment that can contribute to practitioner well-being. Respondents identified that their subjective well-being is impacted by: (1) perceptions of practitioners by community members, (2) conflict with social work program mandates, and (3) changes with the social welfare system. Applications Possible methods of addressing these issues to improve workplace functioning for social workers are discussed along with areas of future research. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Subjective+well-being%2C+social+work%2C+and+the+environment%3A+The+impact+of+the+socio-political+context+of+practice+on+social+worker+happiness&amp;rft.au=Shier%2C+Micheal+L%3BGraham%2C+John+R&amp;rft.aulast=Shier&amp;rft.aufirst=Micheal&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=3&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313503449

____________________________________________________________

Children without parental care in Poland: Foster care, institutionalization and adoption

Author: Knuiman, Sandra; Rijk, Catharina HAM; Hoksbergen, Rene AC; van Baar, Anneloes L

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 142-152.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285178?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes the historical background and current situation of the child welfare system for children without parental care in Poland. Nowadays in Poland, most children without parental care still have both parents, but are placed in out-of-home care as a protective measure. Multiple scenarios are possible for these children. Financial resources, however, are often not sufficient to provide the most desirable care. Despite reforms aimed at deinstitutionalization and a growing number of foster care placements in Poland, almost 20,000 children remain in institutional care. For some children without parental care domestic or international adoption is decided. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Children+without+parental+care+in+Poland%3A+Foster+care%2C+institutionalization+and+adoption&amp;rft.au=Knuiman%2C+Sandra%3BRijk%2C+Catharina+HAM%3BHoksbergen%2C+Rene+AC%3Bvan+Baar%2C+Anneloes+L&amp;rft.aulast=Knuiman&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=142&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812473138

A new role for social work in remote Australia: Addressing psycho-social needs of farming families identified through financial counselling

Author: Doxey, Grant1; McNamara, Patricia1 Mallee Track Health and Community Service, Australia

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 32-42.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285181?accountid=14667

Abstract: Farming families in rural and remote parts of the world are often marginalized from social care. This article describes a phenomenological exploration of problems presenting to financial counsellors in remote south-eastern Australia. Individual and family issues, referral processes and professional competencies have been identified, along with suggested changes to service delivery. Complex psycho-social difficulties are revealed. Financial counsellors, working in isolation, are unable to adequately address these. However, no social work service has been accessible to many consumers living in remote farming communities. Social work, within interdisciplinary partnerships, is being piloted as a result of this study. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+new+role+for+social+work+in+remote+Australia%3A+Addressing+psycho-social+needs+of+farming+families+identified+through+financial+counselling&amp;rft.au=Doxey%2C+Grant%3BMcNamara%2C+Patricia&amp;rft.aulast=Doxey&amp;rft.aufirst=Grant&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=32&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812461046

Transfer of teaching styles: Teaching social work in Iraqi Kurdistan as a Swede

Author: Liedgren, Pernilla11 Dalarna University, Sweden

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 175-185.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285184?accountid=14667

Abstract: From time to time universities in the Global North teach social work in the Global South. This article describes and discusses pedagogical aspects of such projects, focusing on teaching styles and strategies developed. Nine interviews with Swedish teachers with experience of teaching in Iraqi Kurdistan were conducted. The teachers had different methods of mastering the teaching situations and three major styles were identified, referred to in this article as guide, therapeutic and Socratic. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Multicultural social work and national trauma: Lessons from South Africa

Author: Abdullah, Somaya11 University of Fort Hare, South Africa

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 43-54.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285196?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the role of multicultural social work at community level in the context of national trauma. Drawing on the records of South Africa's post-apartheid Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC), it examines the South African experience with a view to deriving preliminary guidelines on multicultural practice that can assist social workers in these and similar circumstances. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Multicultural+social+work+and+national+trauma%3A+Lessons+from+South+Africa&amp;rft.au=Abdullah%2C+Somaya&amp;rft.aulast=Abdullah&amp;rft.aufirst=Somaya&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=43&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812461019

Post-disaster school relocation: A case study of Chinese students' adjustment after the Wenchuan earthquake

Author: Ng, Guat Tin; Sim, Timothy

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 7-22.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285215?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on the results of a survey of 540 Chinese school children's adjustment in temporary school relocation after the Wenchuan earthquake. The overall results depicted a positive picture of functioning. The findings were contrary to expectations, as earlier observational reports suggested that pupils had adjustment difficulties. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Post-disaster+school+relocation%3A+A+case+study+of+Chinese+students%27+adjustment+after+the+Wenchuan+earthquake&amp;rft.au=Ng%2C+Guat+Tin%3BSim%2C+Timothy&amp;rft.aulast=Ng&amp;rft.aufirst=Guat&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=7&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812456051

____________________________________________________________

Students' perceptions of International Social Work: A comparative study in the USA, UK, and Georgia

Author: Lalayants, Marina; Doel, Mark; Kachkachishvili, Iago

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 97-110.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285222?accountid=14667

Abstract: The field of social work worldwide has been increasingly influenced by globalization, migration, and other conditions that require professionals to be responsive and knowledgeable in addressing them. This collaborative project examined students' perceptions of International Social Work at three universities in the United States, United Kingdom, and Georgia. Students' responses indicated an overall strong interest and widespread agreement that there is a link between local and global social issues. The findings suggest that social work education needs to be globalized and tailored to students' needs, which will help them identify social work strongly as part of a profession and affect change across the globe. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Students%27+perceptions+of+International+Social+Work%3A+A+comparative+study+in+the+USA%2C+UK%2C+and+Georgia&amp;rft.au=Lalayants%2C+Marina%3BDoel%2C+Mark%3BKachkachishvili%2C+Iago&amp;rft.aulast=Lalayants&amp;rft.aufirst=Marina&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=97&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812473140

Understanding service needs and service utilization among older Kurdish refugees and immigrants in the USA

Author: Choi, Sam1; Davis, Cindy; Cummings, Sherry; Van Regenmorter, Christina; Barnett, Molly1 University of Tennessee, USA

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 63-74.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285231?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study explored service needs and service utilization among older Kurdish refugees and immigrants in the US. A sample of 70 older Kurds is included and descriptive statistics were utilized. The findings of this study reported that older Kurdish refugees and immigrants are experiencing multiple service needs yet they do not seek help to meet their service needs. This study also highlighted existing barriers to services among older Kurdish refugees and immigrants, which accentuate the need for the development and implementation of culturally competent services for this unique population. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+service+needs+and+service+utilization+among+older+Kurdish+refugees+and+immigrants+in+the+USA&amp;rft.au=Choi%2C+Sam%3BDavis%2C+Cindy%3BCummings%2C+Sherry%3BVan+Regenmorter%2C+Christina%3BBarnett%2C+Molly&amp;rft.aulast=Choi&amp;rft.aufirst=Sam&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=63&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812471694

____________________________________________________________

Challenges for marginalized minority parents in different welfare systems: Child welfare workers' perspectives

Author: Kriz, Katrin; Skivenes, Marit

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 75-87.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285244?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the challenges that marginalized minority parents face raising their children in England, Norway and the United States. While there are similar patterns of challenges across the three countries, such as cultural differences, including lack of language proficiency and knowledge of the society and systems, cross-country differences seem primarily to correspond to different systems of welfare aims and services. We discuss the implications of these findings on underprivileged minority children. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Challenges+for+marginalized+minority+parents+in+different+welfare+systems%3A+Child+welfare+workers%27+perspectives&amp;rft.au=Kriz%2C+Katrin%3BSkivenes%2C+Marit&amp;rft.aulast=Kriz&amp;rft.aufirst=Katrin&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=75&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812456052

____________________________________________________________

Irrigation-based social work relieves poverty in India's drylands

Author: Agoramoorthy, Govindasamy; Hsu, Minna J

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 23-31.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285256?accountid=14667

Abstract: India's drylands, located in the states of Gujarat and Rajasthan, receive low rainfall (annual average of 95-1000 mm). Farmers have to rely on the monsoon rains to cultivate crops. Realizing the irrigation water need of the farmers who inhabit the drylands, a non-profit agency called NM Sadguru Water and Development Foundation (hereafter, the Sadguru Foundation), initiated social work based on irrigation water to assist farmers in growing more crops. In this article, we present data on the irrigation-based social work implemented by the Sadguru Foundation across the drylands of western India and how it benefits local farming communities. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Irrigation-based+social+work+relieves+poverty+in+India%27s+drylands&amp;rft.au=Agoramoorthy%2C+Govindasamy%3BHsu%2C+Minna+J&amp;rft.aulast=Agoramoorthy&amp;rft.aufirst=Govindasamy&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812463106

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Irrigation-based+social+work+relieves+poverty+in+India%27s+drylands&amp;rft.au=Agoramoorthy%2C+Govindasamy%3BHsu%2C+Minna+J&amp;rft.aulast=Agoramoorthy&amp;rft.aufirst=Govindasamy&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812463106

____________________________________________________________

Psychosocial Interventions for Women with HIV/AIDS: A Critical Review

Author: Hernandez, Julieta P1; Macgowan, Mark J1 Florida International University, Miami, FL, USA

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 103-116.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285365?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective Recent research on psychosocial interventions addressing the well-being of women with HIV/AIDS has brought new options for practitioners. This study critically reviews the treatment features, methodological quality, and efficacy of these interventions. Methods A comprehensive search between 2000 and 2011 identified 19 studies employing 10 different interventions. Results In all, 11 studies were methodologically strong and 12 reported interventions superior to other treatments. Among those with positive results, Cohen's effect sizes ranged from small (d = 0.33) to large (d = 1.50) across well-being outcomes. The Cognitive Behavioral Stress Management/Expressive Supportive and Structural Ecosystems Therapies ranked as probably efficacious. The Teaching, Raising and Communicating with Kids and the Maternal HIV Self-Care Symptom Management programs were ranked as promising treatments. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychosocial+Interventions+for+Women+with+HIV%2FAIDS%3A+A+Critical+Review&amp;rft.au=Hernandez%2C+Julieta+P%3BMacgowan%2C+Mark+J&amp;rft.aulast=Hernandez&amp;rft.aufirst=Julieta&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=103&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514527799

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychosocial+Interventions+for+Women+with+HIV%2FAIDS%3A+A+Critical+Review&amp;rft.au=Hernandez%2C+Julieta+P%3BMacgowan%2C+Mark+J&amp;rft.aulast=Hernandez&amp;rft.aufirst=Julieta&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=103&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731514527799

____________________________________________________________

Gender Invariance of Family, School, and Peer Influence on Volunteerism Scale

Author: Law, Ben1; Shek, Daniel; Ma, Cecilia1 University of Hong Kong, Pokfulam, Hong Kong blaw@hku.hk

Publication info: Research on Social Work Practice  Vol. 25, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 139-146.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285372?accountid=14667

Abstract: Objective: This article examines the measurement invariance of Family, School, and Peer Influence on Volunteerism Scale (FSPV) across genders using the mean and covariance structure analysis approach. Method: A total of 2,845 Chinese high school adolescents aged 11 to 15 years completed the FSPV scale. Results: Results of the confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) are consistent with those of previous studies and support the four-factor model of the FSPV scale in each gender. Multiple-group CFA demonstrates the gender invariance of factor pattern, factor loadings, factor covariances, and intercepts of the measured variables across samples. The empirical findings indicate that male adolescents perceive more influences on volunteerism from families, schools, and peers than female counterparts. Both groups perceive extrinsic influence to be similar. Conclusion: The FSPV scale is gender invariant and can be used in assessing the perceived influence of social systems on volunteer service participation among Chinese adolescents for both genders. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Gender+Invariance+of+Family%2C+School%2C+and+Peer+Influence+on+Volunteerism+Scale&amp;rft.au=Law%2C+Ben%3BShek%2C+Daniel%3BMa%2C+Cecilia&amp;rft.aulast=Law&amp;rft.aufirst=Ben&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=25&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=139&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Research+on+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10497315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1049731513517556

Researching collaborative processes in domestic violence perpetrator programs: Benchmarking for situation improvement

Author: Diemer, Kristin1; Humphreys, Cathy; Laming, Chris; Smith, Joanie1 School of Social Work, University of Melbourne, Australia Kdiemer@unimelb.edu.au

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 65-86.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285507?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary This article reports on research undertaken in Victoria, Australia with workers from men's behavior change programs (perpetrator programs) to explore the extent of the collaborative processes established with police, child protection, and other human service organizations. It poses the question: how do regional collaborative arrangements and the pathways to referral reflect the responsiveness of men's behavior change programs to domestic violence service integration? It builds on a strand of research highlighting the significance of the wider domestic violence intervention system in holding men who use violence accountable. Findings A research tool was designed around a Practice Matrix to outline different dimensions against which expectations of collaboration could be benchmarked in men's behavior change programs. It was found that at this early stage within the domestic violence reform process in Victoria that the integration of programs within the wider domestic violence sector was relatively undeveloped. The feedback loops between agencies, which enable reporting on attendance, breaches of intervention orders, changes to the risk assessment, and progress at formal review points were relatively undeveloped. However, the formal engagement within domestic violence regional committees and with police was more developed. Application Social workers, particularly in the vulnerable children's area provide referrals to men's behavior change programs. Active involvement in feedback, risk assessment review, monitoring for change support the accountability and collaborative effort required to strengthen the effectiveness of men's behavior change and enhance the safety of women and their children. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Researching+collaborative+processes+in+domestic+violence+perpetrator+programs%3A+Benchmarking+for+situation+improvement&amp;rft.au=Diemer%2C+Kristin%3BHumphreys%2C+Cathy%3BLaming%2C+Chris%3BSmith%2C+Joanie&amp;rft.aulast=Diemer&amp;rft.aufirst=Kristin&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=65&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313504682

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Researching+collaborative+processes+in+domestic+violence+perpetrator+programs%3A+Benchmarking+for+situation+improvement&amp;rft.au=Diemer%2C+Kristin%3BHumphreys%2C+Cathy%3BLaming%2C+Chris%3BSmith%2C+Joanie&amp;rft.aulast=Diemer&amp;rft.aufirst=Kristin&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=65&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313504682

Attitudinal and behavioral indicators influencing employment decisions among married and single mothers in Taipei, Taiwan

Author: Hsieh, Mei-O; Leung, Patrick

Publication info: International Social Work  Vol. 58, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 123-141.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285549?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examines employment decisions of 113 single and 322 married mothers and predicts that mothers were more likely to engage in paid work when the following factors were present: the acceptance of childcare from others, the association of positive meaning with employment, the importance of being part of the workforce, and the belief in enriched human capital. Mothers who believed that housework affects the ability to work outside the home and who adhered to beliefs favoring division of labor by gender were less likely to seek paid employment. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Attitudinal+and+behavioral+indicators+influencing+employment+decisions+among+married+and+single+mothers+in+Taipei%2C+Taiwan&amp;rft.au=Hsieh%2C+Mei-O%3BLeung%2C+Patrick&amp;rft.aulast=Hsieh&amp;rft.aufirst=Mei-O&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=123&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0020872812461045

____________________________________________________________

The Luhmannian approach to exclusion/inclusion and its relevance to Social Work

Author: Schirmer, Werner1; Michailakis, Dimitris1 Department of Social and Welfare Studies, University of Linkoping, Sweden; Center for Social Theory, Ghent University, Belgium werner.schirmer@liu.se

Publication info: Journal of Social Work  Vol. 15, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 45-64.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285557?accountid=14667

Abstract: Summary Although the concept of social exclusion is central to the academic discipline of social work, there is not much theoretical clarity about what it actually means. For instance, exclusion is used as a synonym for poverty, marginalization, detachment, unemployment, or solitude. We argue that the systems-theoretical framework developed by the German social theorist Niklas Luhmann (1927--1997) provides the conceptual tools to understand inclusion and exclusion in a theoretically adequate way that is highly relevant to Social Work. Since there is scarcely any literature on Luhmann's work in the field of social work not written in German, this article aims to provide a systematic introduction to the Luhmannian theory of society with respect to the distinction of inclusion/exclusion and its relation to social work to an English-speaking audience. Findings After a presentation of some basic concepts, it will be argued that exclusion is not a problem per se nor is inclusion always and per se unproblematic. The Luhmannian approach suggests that inclusion and exclusion are operations of social systems that treat human beings as relevant addresses for communication. Against that background, systems theory gives a clear and accurate description of what social work can (and cannot) do in terms of inclusion/exclusion. Applications The main purpose of social work is exclusion management. Exclusion management involves working on the social addresses of individuals with the aim of improving their attractiveness for other social systems, a (re)orientation towards being includable. It appears in three forms: exclusion prevention, inclusion mediation, and exclusion administration. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Ltd., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Luhmannian+approach+to+exclusion%2Finclusion+and+its+relevance+to+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Schirmer%2C+Werner%3BMichailakis%2C+Dimitris&amp;rft.aulast=Schirmer&amp;rft.aufirst=Werner&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313504607

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Luhmannian+approach+to+exclusion%2Finclusion+and+its+relevance+to+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Schirmer%2C+Werner%3BMichailakis%2C+Dimitris&amp;rft.aulast=Schirmer&amp;rft.aufirst=Werner&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=14680173&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F1468017313504607

'In a perfect world it would be great if they didn't exist': How Australians experience payday loans

Author: Banks, Marcus1; Marston, Gregory; Russell, Roslyn; Karger, Howard1 School of Economics, Finance and Marketing, RMIT University, Melbourne, VIC, Australia.

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 24, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 37-47.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700670582?accountid=14667

Abstract: In the last few decades, payday lending has mushroomed in many developed countries. The arguments for and against an industry which provides small, short-term loans at very high interest rates have also blossomed. This article presents findings from an Australian study to contribute to the international policy and practice debate about a sector which orients to those on a low income. At the heart of this debate lies a conundrum: Borrowing from payday lenders exacerbates poverty, yet many low-income households rely on these loans. We argue that the key problem is the restricted framework within which the debate currently oscillates. Key Practitioner Message: Framing payday borrowing as a problem of market failure leads to one-sided and ineffective regulatory responses; Until governments instigate real alternatives for cheap and readily available credit, and broader anti-poverty measures, curbing access to payday lenders can have the perverse effect of increasing privation; For practitioners seeking to abolish payday lending, campaigns for higher wages and a liveable social welfare income are central. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=%27In+a+perfect+world+it+would+be+great+if+they+didn%27t+exist%27%3A+How+Australians+experience+payday+loans&amp;rft.au=Banks%2C+Marcus%3BMarston%2C+Gregory%3BRussell%2C+Roslyn%3BKarger%2C+Howard&amp;rft.aulast=Banks&amp;rft.aufirst=Marcus&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12083

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=%27In+a+perfect+world+it+would+be+great+if+they+didn%27t+exist%27%3A+How+Australians+experience+payday+loans&amp;rft.au=Banks%2C+Marcus%3BMarston%2C+Gregory%3BRussell%2C+Roslyn%3BKarger%2C+Howard&amp;rft.aulast=Banks&amp;rft.aufirst=Marcus&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12083

Social work in the making: The state and social work development in China

Author: Gao, Jian Guo1; Yan, Miu Chung1 Department of Social Work, Shandong University, Jinan, China.

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 24, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 93-101.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700670592?accountid=14667

Abstract: The instrumental role of government in the development of social work in China has led to questions about its political function. So far, little has been reported on how the government has 'made' social work in China. To fill this gap, we first provide a brief chronological review of major policies and activities of the Chinese government in its making of social work in China. The state's intervention has indeed been massive and crucial although, politically, it may limit the mandate of social work in China. Yet, we argue that the development of the social work profession in China is generating institutional space for the emerging civil society to take a more active role in welfare service delivery. Situated and mediating between the state and the emerging civil society, the social work profession in China will need to constantly negotiate its mandate to meet the needs of both sides. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Social+work+in+the+making%3A+The+state+and+social+work+development+in+China&amp;rft.au=Gao%2C+Jian+Guo%3BYan%2C+Miu+Chung&amp;rft.aulast=Gao&amp;rft.aufirst=Jian&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12089

____________________________________________________________

Reducing child poverty and assessing targeting performance: Governmental cash transfers in Taiwan

Author: Chen, Ke-Mei1; Leu, Chao-Hsien; Wang, Te-Mu1 Department of Social Welfare, National Chung Cheng University, Taiwan.

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 24, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 48-61.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672377?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this study, we focused on child poverty and examined the targeting performance of governmental cash benefits in Taiwan, and whether they successfully alleviate child poverty when budget constraints are imposed. We employed data from the cross-sectional Survey of Family Income and Expenditure 2010, which was conducted by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics of the Executive Yuan in Taiwan. We investigated efficiency and effectiveness, using the IRIS, Beckerman, and Shapley approaches, to measure targeting performance. The results suggest that few transfer programmes perform well in terms of both target efficiency and effectiveness; this generates trade-offs and paradoxes between efficiency or effectiveness, undercoverage or leakage, vertical or horizontal efficiency, and universal or selective benefits. We conclude by suggesting social policy implications based on the findings. Key Practitioner Message: Using different approach (targeting performance) to analyse child poverty; Using targeting efficiency and effectiveness to analyse whether governmental cash benefits ameliorate child poverty given specific budget constraints. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Reducing+child+poverty+and+assessing+targeting+performance%3A+Governmental+cash+transfers+in+Taiwan&amp;rft.au=Chen%2C+Ke-Mei%3BLeu%2C+Chao-Hsien%3BWang%2C+Te-Mu&amp;rft.aulast=Chen&amp;rft.aufirst=Ke-Mei&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=48&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12102

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Reducing+child+poverty+and+assessing+targeting+performance%3A+Governmental+cash+transfers+in+Taiwan&amp;rft.au=Chen%2C+Ke-Mei%3BLeu%2C+Chao-Hsien%3BWang%2C+Te-Mu&amp;rft.aulast=Chen&amp;rft.aufirst=Ke-Mei&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=48&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12102

Prioritising care services: Do the oldest users lose out?

Author: Gautun, Heidi1; Grodem, Anne Skevik1 NOVA, Oslo and Akershus University College of Applied Science, Oslo, Norway.

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 24, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 73-80.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672583?accountid=14667

Abstract: Population ageing is a major concern in most European countries. Demands for health- and care services will increase, as older people typically have a higher need for such services. What is often overlooked, however, is that older users increasingly compete with younger users for the same limited care resources. We ask: How do employees in the Norwegian care sector make decisions regarding the allocation of services to younger and older users? To answer this question, we interviewed decision-makers in Norwegian municipalities. Despite providing for equal rights to services, laws allow for an interpretation of needs and this can result in the unequal distribution of services. Our study indicates that needs are defined differently for younger and older users, which affects the amount, type and content of the services allocated to younger and older people. When resources are scarce and priorities must be established, the services to the oldest suffer. Key Practitioner Message: The article lays the groundwork for an open debate about the allocation of resources to users in different life phases; The analysis conceptualises and makes explicit important normative decisions made by practitioners. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Prioritising+care+services%3A+Do+the+oldest+users+lose+out%3F&amp;rft.au=Gautun%2C+Heidi%3BGrodem%2C+Anne+Skevik&amp;rft.aulast=Gautun&amp;rft.aufirst=Heidi&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=73&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12116

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Prioritising+care+services%3A+Do+the+oldest+users+lose+out%3F&amp;rft.au=Gautun%2C+Heidi%3BGrodem%2C+Anne+Skevik&amp;rft.aulast=Gautun&amp;rft.aufirst=Heidi&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=73&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12116

Human Service Administrators' Knowledge About Immigration Policy: Associations With Attitudes, Political Ideology, and Organizational Practices

Author: Smith, Brenda D; Womack, Bethany G

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 1,  (0, 2015): 67.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658206?accountid=14667

Abstract: To be effective, providers of human services must be knowledgeable about immigration policy. This study aims to (a) assess the accuracy of human service administrators' knowledge about state immigration policy and (b) identify individual and organizational characteristics associated with immigration policy knowledge. The study focuses on Alabama, which implemented a highly restrictive state immigration law in 2011. A survey of a probability sample of human service administrators found that many administrators thought that state immigration policy was even more restrictive -- of both immigrants and those who help them -- than it actually was. Consistent with theory, administrators with more favorable attitudes toward immigrants and stronger perceptions of community support for immigrant services were more knowledgeable about the law's specific restrictions. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Human+Service+Administrators%27+Knowledge+About+Immigration+Policy%3A+Associations+With+Attitudes%2C+Political+Ideology%2C+and+Organizational+Practices&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Brenda+D%3BWomack%2C+Bethany+G&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Brenda&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Family Drug Courts: Conceptual Frameworks, Empirical Evidence, and Implications for Social Work

Author: Lloyd, Margaret H

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 1,  (0, 2015): 49.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658262?accountid=14667

Abstract: Families in the child welfare system who are affected by substance abuse face distinct challenges to achieving reunification. Family drug courts (FDCs), which are child welfare courts based on a therapeutic framework of legal scholarship, arose 2 decades ago as an alternative approach for adjudicating these cases. A comprehensive review of prior empirical research on FDCs is presented to ascertain whether the model is a best practice for this population. The results of this review suggest that children in families that are involved in FDCs spend less time in foster care and are more likely to achieve reunification. This analysis incorporates findings from qualitative literature and undertakes methodological and values-based critiques in order to develop implications for social work research, practice, and policy. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Family+Drug+Courts%3A+Conceptual+Frameworks%2C+Empirical+Evidence%2C+and+Implications+for+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Lloyd%2C+Margaret+H&amp;rft.aulast=Lloyd&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Mental Health and Educational Outcomes for Youth Transitioning From Foster Care in Michigan

Author: White, Catherine Roller; O'Brien, Kirk; Pecora, Peter J; Buher, Anne

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 1,  (0, 2015): 17.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658274?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examines foster care experiences and adult functioning of 65 alumni (ages 23-24) of Michigan foster care, using data from case records and in-person interviews. Results indicate that Michigan foster care alumni had similar or worse outcomes than their peers in other alumni studies, and significantly worse outcomes than their peers in the general population in the areas of mental health, substance dependence, and education. More research is needed to understand this transitional period for youth leaving foster care and to determine which evidence-supported interventions lead to their success as adults. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Mental+Health+and+Educational+Outcomes+for+Youth+Transitioning+From+Foster+Care+in+Michigan&amp;rft.au=White%2C+Catherine+Roller%3BO%27Brien%2C+Kirk%3BPecora%2C+Peter+J%3BBuher%2C+Anne&amp;rft.aulast=White&amp;rft.aufirst=Catherine&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=17&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Economic Conditions of Child Physical Abuse: A Call for a National Research, Policy, and Practice Agenda

Author: Conrad-Hiebner, Aislinn; Scanlon, Edward

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 1,  (0, 2015): 59.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658306?accountid=14667

Abstract: Child physical abuse and economic hardship are two of the most pervasive social problems addressed by the social work profession. Despite empirical evidence that child physical abuse is associated with economic disparities, the field of child welfare lacks a national, coordinated agenda for economic hardship prevention. We review social scientific studies that demonstrate the links between child abuse and a range of economic stressors, including poverty, unemployment, and material hardships. Implications for research, practice, and policy are presented, which could enhance the financial well-being of low-income families at risk of child physical abuse. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=The+Economic+Conditions+of+Child+Physical+Abuse%3A+A+Call+for+a+National+Research%2C+Policy%2C+and+Practice+Agenda&amp;rft.au=Conrad-Hiebner%2C+Aislinn%3BScanlon%2C+Edward&amp;rft.aulast=Conrad-Hiebner&amp;rft.aufirst=Aislinn&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=59&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Guilty Knowledge

Author: Weick, Ann

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 1,  (0, 2015): 35.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658518?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work began in the heart of human need. From the vantage point of late eighteenth century industrial excess, the plight of the poor seemed particularly harsh against the backdrop of burgeoning new wealth. From this cauldron of despair, illness, and pain, social work drew onto its wide and capacious lap those whose lives were being stunted and crushed by the implacable machinery of industrialism. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Guilty+Knowledge&amp;rft.au=Weick%2C+Ann&amp;rft.aulast=Weick&amp;rft.aufirst=Ann&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=35&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Food Acquisition Strategies, Food Security, and Health Status Among Families With Children Using Food Pantries

Author: Kaiser, Michelle L; Hermsen, Joan

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 2,  (0, 2015): 83.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658521?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers working with families must consider the relationship between food insecurity and health. Low-income households often have limited food options and rely on food acquisition strategies to stretch food dollars. This study included 532 adults with children who completed surveys at one of 40 food pantries in 26 counties. This study highlights the ways families acquired food to meet their needs, what health issues were prevalent, and the relationship between food acquisition strategies and food security. Despite using multiple acquisition strategies, 74% were in food-insecure households and 80% were overweight or obese. This study provides evidence that food security and health should be considered when conducting assessments, testing interventions, and developing policies across practice settings. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Food+Acquisition+Strategies%2C+Food+Security%2C+and+Health+Status+Among+Families+With+Children+Using+Food+Pantries&amp;rft.au=Kaiser%2C+Michelle+L%3BHermsen%2C+Joan&amp;rft.aulast=Kaiser&amp;rft.aufirst=Michelle&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=83&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Establishing a Prevention-Focused Integrative Approach to Social Work Practice

Author: Rishel, Carrie W

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 2,  (0, 2015): 125.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658522?accountid=14667

Abstract: Establishing a prevention-focused integrative approach to practice is of critical importance for social work. The Affordable Care Act promotes a shift from fragmented health care delivery toward integrated models of service delivery that emphasize prevention. This shift prompts the need for practitioners who understand the interrelationship among mental health, substance use, and physical health care, and who are prepared to address these needs through a collaborative prevention-focused approach. This article describes such an approach to practice in which social workers integrate micro, mezzo, and macro practice efforts across service systems and, along with allied health and social service professionals, effectively and efficiently address major problems of living within the environmental context. Suggestions regarding curriculum implementation and policy advocacy are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Establishing+a+Prevention-Focused+Integrative+Approach+to+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Rishel%2C+Carrie+W&amp;rft.aulast=Rishel&amp;rft.aufirst=Carrie&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=125&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
