Hello: On Our Legacy and Possibility

Author: Fogel, Sondra J

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 1,  (0, 2015): 3.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658540?accountid=14667

Abstract: As 2015 begins, there are many issues that vie for our attention and call for collective action to influence policies and treatment processes that impact those who are vulnerable and marginalized in US society as well as globally. Indifference toward other people or communities, expressed through anonymous social media outlets, fiery conversations, or brutal group action, suggest a growing culture of deepening intolerance for open, respectful dialogue about conditions and treatment of those in great need (Kolivoski, Weaver, & Constance-Huggins, 2014; Schmitz, Stakeman, & Sisneros, 2001). Finally, persistent health, mental health, and other biopsychosocial conditions that weaken individual and family strengths and capacities for growth and stability are challenged by declining funding for needed programs and service providers, onerous bureaucratic procedures, and an increased suspicion of those who carry stigmatized labels regarding their contributions to the community (Ellerbe et al., 2011). Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Hello%3A+On+Our+Legacy+and+Possibility&amp;rft.au=Fogel%2C+Sondra+J&amp;rft.aulast=Fogel&amp;rft.aufirst=Sondra&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=3&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Reducing Risk: Families in Wraparound Intervention

Author: Schneider-Munoz, Andrew J; Renteria, Rose Ann M; Gelwicks, Jesse; Fasano, Matthew E

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 2,  (0, 2015): 91.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658542?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study used a relative risk (RR) regression method to explore the extent to which children of caregivers in the Brevard C.A.R.E.S. (Coordination, Advocacy, Resources, Education and Support) wraparound intervention experienced a reduction of maltreatment 6 months post completion. Brevard C.A.R.E.S. is a wraparound intervention designed to reduce and prevent child maltreatment in identified at-risk families of children 0-17 years old. The study of 308 children included 131 whose caregivers completed the intervention and a comparison group of 177 similarly situated children. The study found that children whose caregivers completed the intervention experienced less verified maltreatment than children in the comparison group. These findings have implications to enhance systems of care in the community that seek family interventions to support child maltreatment prevention. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Reducing+Risk%3A+Families+in+Wraparound+Intervention&amp;rft.au=Schneider-Munoz%2C+Andrew+J%3BRenteria%2C+Rose+Ann+M%3BGelwicks%2C+Jesse%3BFasano%2C+Matthew+E&amp;rft.aulast=Schneider-Munoz&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Reducing+Risk%3A+Families+in+Wraparound+Intervention&amp;rft.au=Schneider-Munoz%2C+Andrew+J%3BRenteria%2C+Rose+Ann+M%3BGelwicks%2C+Jesse%3BFasano%2C+Matthew+E&amp;rft.aulast=Schneider-Munoz&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Trauma and Resiliency in Grandparent-Headed Multigenerational Families

Author: Lee, Youjung; Blitz, Lisa V; Srnka, Miranda

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 2,  (0, 2015): 116.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658577?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study explored the experiences of 23 grandparents raising grandchildren to better understand the vulnerability and resiliency of grandparent-headed multigenerational families. Three key themes emerged: (a) family trauma with multigenerational impact, (b) multiple stressors impacting the custodial grandparents, and (c) family resiliency that can promote healing and growth. The discussion highlights complex intersections of trauma and stress, and resiliency and healing. Implications for social work practice include the importance of understanding the nature of trauma and resiliency in clinical interventions to ensure the healthy development of children and older adults. Implications for social work advocacy include the necessity to promote flexible policies that address the needs of grandparent-headed households. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Trauma+and+Resiliency+in+Grandparent-Headed+Multigenerational+Families&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Youjung%3BBlitz%2C+Lisa+V%3BSrnka%2C+Miranda&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Youjung&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=116&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Bridging the Distance: A Clinical Phase Model of Family Therapy With Adolescent Residential Treatment

Author: Baez, Johanna Creswell

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 1,  (0, 2015): 41.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658579?accountid=14667

Abstract: As early as the 1970, residential care sought to include families in the clinical treatment of their children (Kemp, 1971). However, families have not been consistently included in residential treatment (Sunseri, 2004) and models are needed to clinically support the phases of family treatment. This article describes an integrative clinical phase model for supporting family therapy with an adolescent in a residential program. Several different phase models are reviewed for family involvement in residential treatment (Fairhurst, 1996; Jones, 1985; Martone, Kemp, & Pearson, 1989). A phase model is advanced that includes updates in family-centered work, corresponding treatment techniques, and knowledge gained in supporting families at one residential program, the Wediko School. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Bridging+the+Distance%3A+A+Clinical+Phase+Model+of+Family+Therapy+With+Adolescent+Residential+Treatment&amp;rft.au=Baez%2C+Johanna+Creswell&amp;rft.aulast=Baez&amp;rft.aufirst=Johanna&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

A Model of Factors Related to Cultural and Racial Socialization Practices Among International Transracial Adoptive Parents

Author: Lee, Jaegoo; Vonk, M Elizabeth; Crolley-Simic, Josie

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 2,  (0, 2015): 141.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658590?accountid=14667

Abstract: To date, there is no clear conceptual model or framework in the literature of factors that affect parents' decisions in socializing their transracially adopted children. Such a model is needed to assist social workers and other professionals working with international transracial adoptive families by providing information about factors that can improve parents' cultural and racial socialization practices. Based on an extensive review of the literature, this article proposes a conceptual model of factors that influence transracial adoptive parents' cultural and racial socialization practices. A review and definition of these factors are included. Implications for future research and practice are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=A+Model+of+Factors+Related+to+Cultural+and+Racial+Socialization+Practices+Among+International+Transracial+Adoptive+Parents&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Jaegoo%3BVonk%2C+M+Elizabeth%3BCrolley-Simic%2C+Josie&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Jaegoo&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=141&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Parents and Court-Ordered Services: A Descriptive Study of Service Use in Child Welfare Reunification

Author: D'Andrade, Amy C

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 1,  (0, 2015): 25.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658603?accountid=14667

Abstract: Child welfare-involved parents use court-ordered services to resolve their problems and reunify with children removed from their care. Often this requires the use of multiple service types, service providers, and service locations. Very little research takes this diversity into account: Most studies of service use examine only a single service area. As a result, the field lacks information to guide the development of interventions to increase reunification service use. This descriptive study examines service use across the array of services ordered for a sample of 223 parents attempting to reunify with their children. Most parents had a mixed pattern of service use, with different patterns emerging by parent age, ethnicity, gender, and custodial status. These findings suggest that targeted interventions or service adjustments may be needed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Parents+and+Court-Ordered+Services%3A+A+Descriptive+Study+of+Service+Use+in+Child+Welfare+Reunification&amp;rft.au=D%27Andrade%2C+Amy+C&amp;rft.aulast=D%27Andrade&amp;rft.aufirst=Amy&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=25&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Parents+and+Court-Ordered+Services%3A+A+Descriptive+Study+of+Service+Use+in+Child+Welfare+Reunification&amp;rft.au=D%27Andrade%2C+Amy+C&amp;rft.aulast=D%27Andrade&amp;rft.aufirst=Amy&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=25&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

'Was Taking Me Out of the Home Necessary?' Perspectives of Foster Youth on the Necessity for Removal

Author: Jones, Loring Paul

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 2,  (0, 2015): 108.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658624?accountid=14667

Abstract: The public views on child protection are often negative and assume that children in care are uniformly unhappy and would rather be at home than in care. This qualitative research sought to give voice to youth on their foster care experience. Former foster youth were asked to recall being removed from their home and reflect on whether they thought removal was necessary. More than three quarters thought removal was necessary and beneficial; 16% disagreed with the removal decision. The reasons given by both sets of youth are discussed. These results support other research findings that suggest foster youth are more satisfied than dissatisfied with care. The implications of these findings for policy are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=%27Was+Taking+Me+Out+of+the+Home+Necessary%3F%27+Perspectives+of+Foster+Youth+on+the+Necessity+for+Removal&amp;rft.au=Jones%2C+Loring+Paul&amp;rft.aulast=Jones&amp;rft.aufirst=Loring&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=108&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=%27Was+Taking+Me+Out+of+the+Home+Necessary%3F%27+Perspectives+of+Foster+Youth+on+the+Necessity+for+Removal&amp;rft.au=Jones%2C+Loring+Paul&amp;rft.aulast=Jones&amp;rft.aufirst=Loring&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=108&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Relationship Between Caseworker Assessments of Clients' Social Networks and Child Welfare Placement Outcomes

Author: Brisebois, Kimberly; Trzcinski, Eileen; Marsack, Christina

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 1,  (0, 2015): 8.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658636?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this study, caseworkers provided information regarding a mother's number and quality of social supports and whether an infant was removed from her care. Analyses indicated that infants were less likely to be removed from the mother's care when caseworkers viewed maternal social supports as positive. This association was strongest when the caseworker identified only positive supports, with no contacts defined as nonpositive. Mothers who were assessed to have no intimate relationship or low level of commitment were nearly twice as likely to have their children in foster care compared to mothers assessed to be in a mid-to-high level of committed relationship. Results suggest that caseworkers' distinctions between positive and nonpositive social networks influence removal decisions. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=The+Relationship+Between+Caseworker+Assessments+of+Clients%27+Social+Networks+and+Child+Welfare+Placement+Outcomes&amp;rft.au=Brisebois%2C+Kimberly%3BTrzcinski%2C+Eileen%3BMarsack%2C+Christina&amp;rft.aulast=Brisebois&amp;rft.aufirst=Kimberly&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=8&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=The+Relationship+Between+Caseworker+Assessments+of+Clients%27+Social+Networks+and+Child+Welfare+Placement+Outcomes&amp;rft.au=Brisebois%2C+Kimberly%3BTrzcinski%2C+Eileen%3BMarsack%2C+Christina&amp;rft.aulast=Brisebois&amp;rft.aufirst=Kimberly&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=8&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Pacific Islander Youth and Sources of Risk for Problem Behaviors (Research Note)

Author: Davis, Robin L; Vakalahi, Halaevalu F O; Smith, Larry L

Publication info: Families in Society  Vol. 96, Iss. 2,  (0, 2015): 99.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1728658661?accountid=14667

Abstract: This analysis focused on family, community, school, and individual/peer-based factors that can contribute to problem behaviors among Pacific Islander youth. This study included Native Hawaiian, Samoan, and Tongan youth which are the largest Pacific Islander groups in Utah (U.S. Census Bureau, 2000). The larger study consisted of 30,000 youth participants of which 530 were Pacific Islanders. Participating Pacific Islander youth reported higher levels of actual, as well as risk for, problem behaviors compared to other youth in the study. Pacific Islander youth also reported significantly lower levels of opportunities for prosocial involvement and rewards for involvement in the community but high levels of family attachment and religiosity. Implications for the future are provided. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Pacific+Islander+Youth+and+Sources+of+Risk+for+Problem+Behaviors+%28Research+Note%29&amp;rft.au=Davis%2C+Robin+L%3BVakalahi%2C+Halaevalu+F+O%3BSmith%2C+Larry+L&amp;rft.aulast=Davis&amp;rft.aufirst=Robin&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=99&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

NCWWI Tribal Traineeship Programs: Promoting Diversity in the Child Welfare Workforce

Author: Cross, Suzanne L; Drywater-Whitekiller, Virginia; Holder, Lea Ann; Norris, Debra; Caringi, James; Trautman, Ashley

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. sup2,  (2015): 225-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732540140?accountid=14667

Abstract: Twelve universities and one American Indian (AI) tribal college were selected for the National Child Welfare Workforce Institute&apos;s 5-year stipend traineeship program. These tribal traineeships were designed to provide social work child welfare education for tribal and nontribal students. Twenty-two AI students and 58 nontribal students completed a bachelor or master&apos;s of social work degree. The students&apos; field placements were in tribal agencies or public agencies that served a segment of the AI population. These programs were enhanced through the use of valuable relationships (i.e., partnerships, mentorships, allies), and cultural competence was a key aspect of the students&apos; education. The students&apos; education was enriched with a specific child welfare curriculum, cultural teachings, tribal traineeship collaborations, and tribal community events.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=NCWWI+Tribal+Traineeship+Programs%3A+Promoting+Diversity+in+the+Child+Welfare+Workforce&amp;rft.au=Cross%2C+Suzanne+L%3BDrywater-Whitekiller%2C+Virginia%3BHolder%2C+Lea+Ann%3BNorris%2C+Debra%3BCaringi%2C+James%3BTrautman%2C+Ashley&amp;rft.aulast=Cross&amp;rft.aufirst=Suzanne&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=225&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1072404

California's Title IV-E Partnership: A Statewide University-Agency Collaboration-Characteristics and Implications for Replication

Author: Mathias, Christine; Gilman, Elizabeth; Shin, Carolyn; Evans, William Todd

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. sup2,  (2015): 252-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732540321?accountid=14667

Abstract: University-agency partnerships funded by Title IV-E encourage students to enter the child welfare field by providing student stipends, thus supporting child welfare agency workforce development. This article examines the literature and historical roots of Title IV-E and other partnerships, identifies common structures and outcomes, and discusses the extent to which a structured development and change process supports the California partnership&apos;s core mission to integrate the education and practice communities in child welfare. The partnership is teleological in nature, using a social exchange approach to advance mutuality and a full spectrum of benefits for universities and agencies. Models and best practice elements are presented as examples of how university-agency partnerships may enhance child welfare service delivery.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=California%27s+Title+IV-E+Partnership%3A+A+Statewide+University-Agency+Collaboration-Characteristics+and+Implications+for+Replication&amp;rft.au=Mathias%2C+Christine%3BGilman%2C+Elizabeth%3BShin%2C+Carolyn%3BEvans%2C+William+Todd&amp;rft.aulast=Mathias&amp;rft.aufirst=Christine&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=252&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1073082

____________________________________________________________

Ready, Set, Go ... Again: Renewing an Academy-Agency Child Welfare Partnership

Author: Pierce, Barbara; McGuire, Lisa E; Howes, Patricia

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. sup2,  (2015): 239-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732540451?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents a case study of the renewed partnership between a midwestern public child welfare agency and a midwestern university school of social work. The partnership, which includes educating BSW and MSW students, preparing frontline child welfare case managers, and providing leadership training for supervisors and managers, demonstrates relational capital, relational embeddedness, and transparency, all of which are criteria for trust and strong partnerships. We discuss the unique development of collaborative relationships through the history of the partnership. This study provides an exemplar of how the academy and the agency communities can inform each other to enhance the well-being of children and families.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Ready%2C+Set%2C+Go+...+Again%3A+Renewing+an+Academy-Agency+Child+Welfare+Partnership&amp;rft.au=Pierce%2C+Barbara%3BMcGuire%2C+Lisa+E%3BHowes%2C+Patricia&amp;rft.aulast=Pierce&amp;rft.aufirst=Barbara&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=239&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1072424

Preparing Social Work Students for Rural Child Welfare Practice: Emerging Curriculum Competencies

Author: Riebschleger, Joanne; Norris, Debra; Pierce, Barbara; Pond, Debora L; Cummings, Cristy

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. sup2,  (2015): 209-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732540534?accountid=14667

Abstract: Multiple issues that are unique to child welfare social work practice in rural areas markedly affect workforce recruitment and retention, yet little attention is given to the proficiencies needed to equip emerging social workers for this growing area of the field. Curriculum content is needed that provides students with the opportunity to master the skills needed to thrive as child welfare social workers in rural areas. Using an evidence-based practice critical thinking model as a guide, a systematic review of literature and documents addresses many of the competencies needed to prepare social work students for child welfare practice in rural areas. These competencies are identified. Suggestions for integration into the social work curriculum are offered.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Preparing+Social+Work+Students+for+Rural+Child+Welfare+Practice%3A+Emerging+Curriculum+Competencies&amp;rft.au=Riebschleger%2C+Joanne%3BNorris%2C+Debra%3BPierce%2C+Barbara%3BPond%2C+Debora+L%3BCummings%2C+Cristy&amp;rft.aulast=Riebschleger&amp;rft.aufirst=Joanne&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=209&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1072422

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Preparing+Social+Work+Students+for+Rural+Child+Welfare+Practice%3A+Emerging+Curriculum+Competencies&amp;rft.au=Riebschleger%2C+Joanne%3BNorris%2C+Debra%3BPierce%2C+Barbara%3BPond%2C+Debora+L%3BCummings%2C+Cristy&amp;rft.aulast=Riebschleger&amp;rft.aufirst=Joanne&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=209&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1072422

Increasing Research Capacity in Ontario Child Welfare Organizations: A Unique University-Child Welfare Agency Partnership

Author: Fallon, Barbara; Trocmé, Nico; Van Wert, Melissa; Budau, Krista; Ballantyne, Mary; Lwin, Kristen

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. sup2,  (2015): 271-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732540637?accountid=14667

Abstract: The objective of this article is to describe the successes and challenges of a unique knowledge mobilization initiative that was funded through the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada. This initiative focused on promoting knowledge mobilization by increasing the capacity of child welfare organizations in Ontario to conduct and use research. Building on existing knowledge mobilization models in Ontario, this initiative brought university-based researchers together with child welfare practitioners to use existing data sets from the Ontario Incidence Studies of Reported Child Abuse and Neglect. Overall, this knowledge mobilization initiative resulted in several positive outcomes. Along with the successes, the research team faced several challenges in implementing this initiative, which are described in detail.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Increasing+Research+Capacity+in+Ontario+Child+Welfare+Organizations%3A+A+Unique+University-Child+Welfare+Agency+Partnership&amp;rft.au=Fallon%2C+Barbara%3BTrocm%C3%A9%2C+Nico%3BVan+Wert%2C+Melissa%3BBudau%2C+Krista%3BBallantyne%2C+Mary%3BLwin%2C+Kristen&amp;rft.aulast=Fallon&amp;rft.aufirst=Barbara&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=271&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1072412

Alumni of a BSW-Level Specialized Title IV-E Program Voice Their Experiences in the Workplace

Author: Falk, Diane S

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. sup2,  (2015): 173-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732540825?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study surveyed 289 alumni of a specialized Title IV-E program that prepares undergraduate social work students for careers in public child welfare, examining factors such as turnover rates, adherence to strengths-based practice principles, perceptions of work conditions, and intent to stay. Findings indicate that graduates of this program were less likely than other caseworkers to leave their positions. Most maintained adherence to strengths-based practice principles, reported satisfaction with the work, felt supported by colleagues, and intended to stay in the field of child welfare. Based on alumni comments, ways that agencies can retain such workers are suggested.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Alumni+of+a+BSW-Level+Specialized+Title+IV-E+Program+Voice+Their+Experiences+in+the+Workplace&amp;rft.au=Falk%2C+Diane+S&amp;rft.aulast=Falk&amp;rft.aufirst=Diane&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=173&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1072410

Promising Innovations in Child Welfare Education: Findings From a National Initiative

Author: Strand, Virginia C; Dettlaff, Alan J; Counts-Spriggs, Margaret

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. sup2,  (2015): 195-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732541079?accountid=14667

Abstract: For many years, schools of social work have engaged in partnerships, especially with public child welfare agencies, to prepare a competent and professional child welfare workforce through the mechanism of Title IV-E training. In 2008 the National Child Welfare Workforce Institute (NCWWI) established an additional resource for preparing students in social work schools for child welfare practice. Twelve NCWWI traineeship programs supported a diverse group of BSW and MSW students from 2008 to 2013 and prepared them for client-centered practice informed by child welfare and leadership competencies. This article highlights a curriculum innovation in an MSW program and a field innovation in a BSW program that were designed to increase the readiness of BSW and MSW students for child welfare practice.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Promising+Innovations+in+Child+Welfare+Education%3A+Findings+From+a+National+Initiative&amp;rft.au=Strand%2C+Virginia+C%3BDettlaff%2C+Alan+J%3BCounts-Spriggs%2C+Margaret&amp;rft.aulast=Strand&amp;rft.aufirst=Virginia&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=195&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1072411

Practice Change in Child Welfare: The Interface of Training and Social Work Education

Author: Deglau, Ericka; Ray, Anasuya; Conway, Fiona; Carre-Lee, Nancy; Waldman, William; Cunningham, Katelyn; Harrison, Talisah; Bales, Heather; Powell, Tedecia

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. sup2,  (2015): 153-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732541092?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines perceptions of the relationship between professional education and workplace training among a select group of public child welfare employees who pursued graduate social work education during a period of major practice change at their agency. Focus groups were conducted with representative members of graduating cohorts as students completed their studies to explore the connections and distinctions between their professional education and the workplace training that introduced case practice reform. Experienced caseworkers, supervisors, and management-level staff, study participants were well situated to contemplate the changes in process at their agency. They offered insights into the progress of reform and the challenges of sustaining change as well as their roles as professional social workers in carrying reforms forward.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Practice+Change+in+Child+Welfare%3A+The+Interface+of+Training+and+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.au=Deglau%2C+Ericka%3BRay%2C+Anasuya%3BConway%2C+Fiona%3BCarre-Lee%2C+Nancy%3BWaldman%2C+William%3BCunningham%2C+Katelyn%3BHarrison%2C+Talisah%3BBales%2C+Heather%3BPowell%2C+Tedecia&amp;rft.aulast=Deglau&amp;rft.aufirst=Ericka&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1072402

____________________________________________________________

NCWWI Traineeships: A National Cross-Site Evaluation of Child Welfare Stipend Programs for Ethnically Diverse Students

Author: Leake, Robin; de Guzman, Anna; Rienks, Shauna; Archer, Gretchen; Potter, Cathryn

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. sup2,  (2015): 299-.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732543199?accountid=14667

Abstract: The task of recruiting and retaining ethnically diverse, qualified, and committed social workers in child welfare is challenging. Federal funding supporting BSW and MSW education has been a catalyst for university-agency partnerships across the country. An important goal of these partnerships is to prepare social work students with the knowledge, skills, and competencies for effective child welfare practice. The National Child Welfare Workforce Institute&apos;s innovative child welfare traineeships program prepares students from 12 social work programs around the country. This study focused on diversity, competency attainment, and readiness for the job. Results showed that programs recruited ethnically diverse students, and after receiving child welfare-specific content and hands-on experiences in the field, students felt competent and prepared for child welfare work.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=NCWWI+Traineeships%3A+A+National+Cross-Site+Evaluation+of+Child+Welfare+Stipend+Programs+for+Ethnically+Diverse+Students&amp;rft.au=Leake%2C+Robin%3Bde+Guzman%2C+Anna%3BRienks%2C+Shauna%3BArcher%2C+Gretchen%3BPotter%2C+Cathryn&amp;rft.aulast=Leake&amp;rft.aufirst=Robin&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=sup2&amp;rft.spage=299&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1072419

A Preliminary Study of Burnout in Residential Social Workers Experiencing Workplace Aggression: Might It Be Cyclical?

Author: Winstanley, Sue1; Hales, Lisa1 Division of Psychology, Faculty of Health & Life Sciences, De Montfort University, The Gateway, Leicester, LE1 9BH, UK

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 24-33.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650567?accountid=14667

Abstract: The problem of workplace aggression and increasing levels of burnout in social workers have both been explored independently in prior research but until now have not been examined in relation to each other. This investigation focused upon levels of burnout in staff victims of assault and threatening behaviour working in residential children's homes. Data showed that, of eighty-seven staff , seventy of them (81 per cent) had been either threatened or assaulted in the preceding year, fifty of them (58 per cent) ten or more times. Maslach's Burnout Inventory demonstrated significantly elevated levels of both emotional exhaustion and depersonalisation (although not in personal accomplishment) in staff reporting aggression in the previous year than those reporting no aggression. This remained true even with moderate levels of aggression. Models of burnout suggest that high levels of emotional exhaustion lead to increased depersonalisation, which might be manifest, albeit unknowingly, in subsequent behaviour, such as a lack of empathy or concern. Consideration is given to how staff behaviour might thus be interpreted by assailants in these situations, leaving staff victims more vulnerable to further victimisation. Implications for staff and managers in dealing with aggressive incidents are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Preliminary+Study+of+Burnout+in+Residential+Social+Workers+Experiencing+Workplace+Aggression%3A+Might+It+Be+Cyclical%3F&amp;rft.au=Winstanley%2C+Sue%3BHales%2C+Lisa&amp;rft.aulast=Winstanley&amp;rft.aufirst=Sue&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=24&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcu036

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Preliminary+Study+of+Burnout+in+Residential+Social+Workers+Experiencing+Workplace+Aggression%3A+Might+It+Be+Cyclical%3F&amp;rft.au=Winstanley%2C+Sue%3BHales%2C+Lisa&amp;rft.aulast=Winstanley&amp;rft.aufirst=Sue&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=24&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbcu036

Interventions That Retain African Americans in HIV/AIDS Treatment: Implications for Social Work Practice and Research

Author: Gaston, Gina B; Gutierrez, Sarah M; Nisanci, Aslihan

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 35-42.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650569?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers play an important role in recognizing and addressing barriers to retention in HIV care. Although there is a large body of literature and research supporting interventions that promote medication adherence, there is limited intervention research that addresses retention in care, the precursor to adherence. Despite many advances in HIV treatment, many African Americans are not engaged in regular care. In a systematic review, the literature was critically appraised to examine intervention research designed to retain HIV-infected African Americans in treatment. Only peer-reviewed studies published from January 2002 through October 2012 were examined. The initial search generated a total of 798 studies. However, of these, only 13 met the inclusion criteria. Results highlight interventions that can be replicated by social workers-such as the use of ancillary support services, the use of adherence manuals, and theory-based interventions-to engage this population in care. Policy implications are also discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Interventions+That+Retain+African+Americans+in+HIV%2FAIDS+Treatment%3A+Implications+for+Social+Work+Practice+and+Research&amp;rft.au=Gaston%2C+Gina+B%3BGutierrez%2C+Sarah+M%3BNisanci%2C+Aslihan&amp;rft.aulast=Gaston&amp;rft.aufirst=Gina&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=35&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu050

Rethinking Skill in Anti-Oppressive Social Work Practice with Skilled Immigrant Professionals

Author: Chatterjee, Soma11 Department of Leadership, Higher and Adult Education, Ontario Institute for Studies in Education, University of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, Canada rupa.chatterjee@mail.utoronto.ca

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 363-377.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650588?accountid=14667

Abstract: Scholarly and policy responses to skilled immigrants' labour market integration in Canada have a tendency to normalise and individualise skill as a key issue to address immigrants' labour market challenges. In contrast, a small body of anti-oppressive social work advocates the need for examining the racist and assimilationist assumptions that lead to de-skilling and propose structurally oriented recommendations. In this paper, I draw from the historical materialist method of ideological critique and critical scholarship on work and learning for work to make a case that, since the notion of skill does not have a stable referent and is ideologically malleable, it helps to mask the exploitative relation between labour and capital in the job market. I argue that such an understanding of skill would sharpen the repertoire of anti-oppressive practice with skilled immigrant professionals by encouraging practitioners to acknowledge de-skilling as a fundamental aspect of the system they are critiquing, and thereby reorienting their critique to incorporate larger political economic structures. I conclude by proposing a dialogue between practitioners and researchers about the efficacy and viability of this proposition. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Rethinking+Skill+in+Anti-Oppressive+Social+Work+Practice+with+Skilled+Immigrant+Professionals&amp;rft.au=Chatterjee%2C+Soma&amp;rft.aulast=Chatterjee&amp;rft.aufirst=Soma&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=363&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct111

Children's, Young People's and Parents' Perspectives on Contact: Findings from the Evaluation of Social Work Practices

Author: Larkins, Cath1; Ridley, Julie; Farrelly, Nicola; Austerberry, Helen; Bilson, Andy; Hussein, Shereen; Manthorpe, Jill; Stanley, Nicky1 School of Social Work, University of Central Lancashire, Preston, PR1 2HE, UK

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 296-312.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650591?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports children's, young people's and parents' perspectives on birth family contact from interviews conducted across eleven local authorities in England between 2009 and 2012 as part of the national evaluation of Social Work Practice (SWP) pilots: independent organisations providing social work support for looked after children and care leavers. The matched control evaluation, reported fully elsewhere (Stanley et al., 2013), showed most children and young people interviewed in both SWP and comparison sites felt they had the 'right' amount of contact with the 'right' members of their birth families. Factors found to be key to child and parental satisfaction with contact include: involvement in decision making; speed of social work response; resolution of practical problems; provision of information and emotional support; and investment in building relationships. Evaluation of the SWPs demonstrated progress over time in increasing satisfaction with contact for some young people and some parents also reported improvements, but progress was not uniform and good practice was also evident in comparison sites. Regardless of the organisational model adopted, social work which increases children's, young people's and families' satisfaction with contact arrangements requires an ethic of care, a rights-based approach and access to resources, such as worker time and transport. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Children%27s%2C+Young+People%27s+and+Parents%27+Perspectives+on+Contact%3A+Findings+from+the+Evaluation+of+Social+Work+Practices&amp;rft.au=Larkins%2C+Cath%3BRidley%2C+Julie%3BFarrelly%2C+Nicola%3BAusterberry%2C+Helen%3BBilson%2C+Andy%3BHussein%2C+Shereen%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill%3BStanley%2C+Nicky&amp;rft.aulast=Larkins&amp;rft.aufirst=Cath&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=296&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct135

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Children%27s%2C+Young+People%27s+and+Parents%27+Perspectives+on+Contact%3A+Findings+from+the+Evaluation+of+Social+Work+Practices&amp;rft.au=Larkins%2C+Cath%3BRidley%2C+Julie%3BFarrelly%2C+Nicola%3BAusterberry%2C+Helen%3BBilson%2C+Andy%3BHussein%2C+Shereen%3BManthorpe%2C+Jill%3BStanley%2C+Nicky&amp;rft.aulast=Larkins&amp;rft.aufirst=Cath&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=296&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct135

Children's Narrative within a Multi-Centred, Dynamic Ecological Framework of Assessment and Planning for Child Trafficking

Author: Rigby, Paul1; Whyte, Bill1 4S25, Applied Social Sciences, Colin Bell Building, University of Stirling, Stirling, FK9 4LS, UK paul.rigby1@stir.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 34-51.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650603?accountid=14667

Abstract: An ecological approach to understanding child abuse and working with separated children are not new concepts. This paper proposes a dynamic development of the model for use by front line practitioners that takes account of the movement and exploitation of children caught up in child trafficking, while recognising the primacy of children's narratives when information is difficult to obtain. Adopting a holistic planning and assessment approach utilising dynamic life story work addresses the realities of children's lives as they move around, with the potential for numerous social contacts and influences in home, transit and destination countries. The model recognises not only the physical journey and exploitation of the child, but also their emotional and psychological journey through exploitation and abuse, hopefully, towards healthy and safe outcomes. While such a model recognises the complexities of the lives of children on the move who have been trafficked, its major drawback for professionals is its complexity and the difficulty of obtaining, and making sense of information from the potentially numerous countries, situations and people children have encountered. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Children%27s+Narrative+within+a+Multi-Centred%2C+Dynamic+Ecological+Framework+of+Assessment+and+Planning+for+Child+Trafficking&amp;rft.au=Rigby%2C+Paul%3BWhyte%2C+Bill&amp;rft.aulast=Rigby&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=34&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct105

____________________________________________________________

Developing the Confidence and Competence of Newly Qualified Child and Family Social Workers in England: Outcomes of a National Programme

Author: Carpenter, John1; Shardlow, Steven M; Patsios, Demi; Wood, Marsha1 School for Policy Studies, University of Bristol, 8 Priory Rd, Bristol, BS8 1TZ, UK j.s.w.carpenter@bristol.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 153-176.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650622?accountid=14667

Abstract: A measure of self-efficacy was used to assess the development of competence and confidence for participants in a one-year national programme of supervision and support for newly qualified child and family social workers (NQSWs) in England. The study also explored the associations between self-efficacy, demographic variables and role clarity, role conflict, job satisfaction and stress. Method: A longitudinal repeated measures design with three cohorts of NQSWs participating in the programme (2008-12) (N = 2,019); in 2008-09, comparison was made with a 'contrast group' of NQSWs (N = 47) in non-participating agencies. Findings: Self-efficacy ratings showed substantial and statistically significant increases between the beginning and end of the programme for all three cohorts. The proportion of 'confident' NQSWs increased from a half to three-quarters of respondents. However, interim retrospective ratings indicated overestimation of self-efficacy at baseline. Self-efficacy ratings at the end of the year favoured the programme group versus the contrast group. High self-efficacy was predicted statistically by age, role clarity and intrinsic (but not extrinsic) job satisfaction. It was unexpectedly associated with high role conflict and was not related to stress. Findings supported a developmental process model for the accumulation of professional expertise. Implications: An Assessed and Supported Year in Employment (ASYE) based on the programme has been established for all NQSWs in England. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Developing+the+Confidence+and+Competence+of+Newly+Qualified+Child+and+Family+Social+Workers+in+England%3A+Outcomes+of+a+National+Programme&amp;rft.au=Carpenter%2C+John%3BShardlow%2C+Steven+M%3BPatsios%2C+Demi%3BWood%2C+Marsha&amp;rft.aulast=Carpenter&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct106

Quality of Professional Services following Traumatic Brain Injury: Adult Sibling Perspectives

Author: Degeneffe, Charles Edmund; Bursnall, Samantha

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 19-27.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650629?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the quality and availability of professional supports provided to individuals with traumatic brain injury (TBI) and their families from the perspective of a national sample of 267 adult siblings. Using a constant comparative approach to text analysis, the authors analyzed what siblings perceived to have been beneficial or in need of improvement with regard to the TBI professional services provided to their injured brother or sister and their family. The siblings' comments suggested that the system-level response to TBI serving injured people and their families was inadequate, that many professionals lacked the skills and understanding to provide effective services, and that professionals did not provide sufficient information to the people with TBI or their families. However, most siblings endorsed a positive view of at least one of the professional services provided. Clinical, advocacy, and research implications of these findings are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Quality+of+Professional+Services+following+Traumatic+Brain+Injury%3A+Adult+Sibling+Perspectives&amp;rft.au=Degeneffe%2C+Charles+Edmund%3BBursnall%2C+Samantha&amp;rft.aulast=Degeneffe&amp;rft.aufirst=Charles&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu047

Medicare Constrains Social Workers' and Nurses' Home Care for Clients with Alzheimer's Disease

Author: Cabin, William D11 School of Social Work, Temple University, 1301 Cecil B. Moore Avenue, 5th Floor, Ritter Annex, Philadelphia, PA williamcabin@yahoo.com

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 75-83.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650630?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Medicare home health prospective payment system (PPS) has existed for 13 years, yielding significant profits to providers. However, studies indicate many unresolved questions about whether PPS improves patient quality of care, is cost-effective, and reduces patient levels of unmet need. In addition, PPS has undermined the provision of social work home health services. The article presents the views of 29 home health care nurses regarding the impact of PPS on their care decisions for people with Alzheimer's disease and their caregivers. The nurses identify Alzheimer's disease symptom management and psychosocial needs as phantoms, omnipresent below the surface but not attended to by home care clinicians. The interviews support the greater involvement of social workers to more adequately address the psychosocial needs of Medicare home health patients. The article contends that the current failure to simultaneously address the cost, needs, and quality-of-life issues of people with Alzheimer's disease who are cared for at home is analogous to the end-of-life care situation before passage of the Medicare Hospice Benefit. A collaborative demonstration project -- social work and nursing -- is proposed to determine how PPS might better address quality of life and costs of home-based people with Alzheimer's disease and their caregivers. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Medicare+Constrains+Social+Workers%27+and+Nurses%27+Home+Care+for+Clients+with+Alzheimer%27s+Disease&amp;rft.au=Cabin%2C+William+D&amp;rft.aulast=Cabin&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=75&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu044

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Medicare+Constrains+Social+Workers%27+and+Nurses%27+Home+Care+for+Clients+with+Alzheimer%27s+Disease&amp;rft.au=Cabin%2C+William+D&amp;rft.aulast=Cabin&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=75&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu044

Exploring Social Workers' Use of the Socioecological Model as an Intervention and Research Framework for Treating Overweight or Obese Clients

Author: Melius, Janella

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 55-63.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650654?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to identify the empirical contribution made by the social work profession in the prevention and treatment of overweight and obesity. The constructs of the socioecological model of health, which suggest that there are multiple levels of influence on individual behaviors, were used as a conceptual framework to synthesize studies authored by social work researchers investigating overweight and obesity risk factors. A review of obesity-related research written by social workers published over an unrestricted time was conducted. The author found 51 articles in published peer-review journals written by social workers from 1993 to 2013. The reviewed studies included participants living in the United States, China, Israel, and Australia. Findings indicate that the majority of research conducted by social workers address overweight and obesity treatment and consequences at the individual level, and there is little on how social workers plan to address this issue from community-level or policy-related perspectives. This review is the first comprehensive study of social workers' empirical coverage of varying levels of influences affecting obesity. Practice and policy implications are discussed for social work professionals employed in community settings. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Social+Workers%27+Use+of+the+Socioecological+Model+as+an+Intervention+and+Research+Framework+for+Treating+Overweight+or+Obese+Clients&amp;rft.au=Melius%2C+Janella&amp;rft.aulast=Melius&amp;rft.aufirst=Janella&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=55&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu048

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Exploring+Social+Workers%27+Use+of+the+Socioecological+Model+as+an+Intervention+and+Research+Framework+for+Treating+Overweight+or+Obese+Clients&amp;rft.au=Melius%2C+Janella&amp;rft.aulast=Melius&amp;rft.aufirst=Janella&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=55&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu048

Organizational Awareness: A Missing Generalist Social Work Competency

Author: Silverman, Ed

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 93-95.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650655?accountid=14667

Abstract: I practice management and, on my better days, leadership. At least that is what I tell my higher education colleagues who question my clinical background. Ironically, I matriculated at a social work school precisely because they had a 'clinical concentration.' But somewhere along the journey, organizations and their stewardship became more compelling. I have seen nurse professionals assume leadership roles once dominated by social work. A major social service agency where I once served as both a board member and staff executive is now without a single social worker at cabinet-level leadership. This commentary proposes the need to bridge the gap between the more seasoned macro social worker and the novice. To do so, I advocate for the development of a new generalist social work competency: organizational awareness. The premise is not to establish more social work managers or administrators-though that is a noble goal. The critical need is to develop a generalist macro-related knowledge base that will allow practitioners, especially those less experienced, to have more impact and influence within their organizations and agencies. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Organizational+Awareness%3A+A+Missing+Generalist+Social+Work+Competency&amp;rft.au=Silverman%2C+Ed&amp;rft.aulast=Silverman&amp;rft.aufirst=Ed&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu055

A Lasting Legacy? Sustaining Innovation in a Social Work Context

Author: Brown, Louise11 Department of Social and Policy Sciences, University of Bath, Claverton Down, Bath, BA2 7AY, UK L.Brown@bath.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 138-152.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650660?accountid=14667

Abstract: The current agenda for change in the public sector challenges organisations to operate differently. Alongside managing severe cutbacks in investment, the UK social work sector faces a period of unprecedented change aimed at raising standards and improving practice whilst demonstrating value for money. Resulting in such a significant reform agenda and set within a climate of austerity, the UK government can be heard to call upon 'innovation' as the solution to achieving 'more for less' during such testing times. Whilst there is a body of literature examining the process of managing innovation, there remains an absence of knowledge relating to the tail end of the process concerned with moving from piloting to achieving sustainability. Drawing upon case examples of innovation in practice, this paper is unique in applying this literature to a social work setting. It sets out what is meant by innovation, what we know about diffusion and managing innovation, and presents a new framework that can be applied to assist with improving the process of replication in order to support sustainability. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Lasting+Legacy%3F+Sustaining+Innovation+in+a+Social+Work+Context&amp;rft.au=Brown%2C+Louise&amp;rft.aulast=Brown&amp;rft.aufirst=Louise&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=138&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct107

Beyond Equal Access to Equal Outcomes: The Role of the Institutional Culture in Promoting Full Participation, Positive Inter-Group Interaction and Timely Progression for Minority Social Work Students

Author: Fletcher, Joan1; Bernard, Claudia; Fairtlough, Anna; Ahmet, Akile1 PACE, Goldsmiths, University of London, London, SE14 6NW, UK j.fletcher@gold.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 120-137.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650663?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper is based on the first national qualitative study to examine diversity and progression within social work programmes in England, focusing on the experiences of disabled, black and ethnic minority and lesbian, gay and bisexual students. Data collected from ninety-five students and twenty-three social work education providers across eight higher education institutions (HEIs) suggested an institutional effect on rates of progression, linked to the degree of orientation towards systemic change. The study found that social work educators tended to place more emphasis on 'equality of access' than 'equality of outcomes', resulting in a lack of focus on other aspects of the student life cycle such as inter-group dynamics and rates of progression through the programme and into employment. This paper highlights the importance of a 'transformational' organisational change approach to creating an institutional culture where students from minority groups feel welcome and can thrive. Leadership, monitoring and an institution-wide sense of collective responsibility for diversity and equality policy implementation emerged as key to creating a more inclusive environment, alongside equipping staff to take a pro-active role in facilitating high-quality, respectful interaction between different members of the HEI community. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Beyond+Equal+Access+to+Equal+Outcomes%3A+The+Role+of+the+Institutional+Culture+in+Promoting+Full+Participation%2C+Positive+Inter-Group+Interaction+and+Timely+Progression+for+Minority+Social+Work+Students&amp;rft.au=Fletcher%2C+Joan%3BBernard%2C+Claudia%3BFairtlough%2C+Anna%3BAhmet%2C+Akile&amp;rft.aulast=Fletcher&amp;rft.aufirst=Joan&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=120&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct081

'Stand by Me': The Effect of Emotional Support on Children's Testimonies

Author: Katz, Carmit11 Bob Shapell School of Social Work, Tel Aviv University, Ramat Aviv 69978, Israel drckatz@gmail.com

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 349-362.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650695?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many children who come into contact with the legal system following suspected maltreatment have difficulty disclosing the alleged abuse and providing rich and coherent testimonies. This study focuses on three interviews with alleged victims: two girls who were interviewed following reports of possible sexual abuse by their fathers and one boy who was interviewed following a report of possible sexual abuse by his mother. All the interviews were conducted by social workers trained in investigative interviewing techniques. The main aim of these case studies is to explore the effect of emotional, non-suggestive support on children's disclosure patterns and narratives during the forensic interview. These illustrative interviews emphasise the importance of employing emotional non-suggestive support in the forensic context, as this practice balances between the interests of the legal system and the best interests of the children involved. This balancing is a highly complicated task and represents social workers' contributions to the experiences of maltreated children in the legal system. The practical implications for social workers in the forensic context and other contexts are also discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=%27Stand+by+Me%27%3A+The+Effect+of+Emotional+Support+on+Children%27s+Testimonies&amp;rft.au=Katz%2C+Carmit&amp;rft.aulast=Katz&amp;rft.aufirst=Carmit&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=349&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct137

A Digital Environment Approach: Four Technologies That Will Disrupt Social Work Practice

Author: Goldkind, Lauri1; Wolf, Lea1 Graduate School of Social Service, Fordham University, 113 West 60th Street, New York, NY goldkind@fordham.edu

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 85-87.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650714?accountid=14667

Abstract: Our human experience is mediated with and by technology. Social work offers a panoramic perspective on individuals and issues, insisting on the importance of the ecology of interaction between person and environment. Given this historic strength, social workers cannot ignore the explosive growth and pervasive impact of technology or fail to recognize its role in shaping culture. Beyond its capacity to enhance what we offer to our clients, technology is a prompt, a demand to reimagine our core values in the context of a changing social space and to develop a mechanics of practice that is amenable to rapid evolution. With this commentary we hope to initiate dialogue: to urge consideration of the implications of a technology-powered culture for designing social work curriculums and training, for reaching across disciplines to improve outcomes, for finding new ways for social workers to partner with clients, and for making these developments tangible and available to agencies and practitioners. Although technological innovation continuously alters the landscape of human possibility, it does not guarantee momentum toward the values of social justice. Social work is both uniquely positioned and ethically obligated to ensure that the drive of technological evolution is a project open to all, and that it does not replicate or amplify existing inequalities. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Digital+Environment+Approach%3A+Four+Technologies+That+Will+Disrupt+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Goldkind%2C+Lauri%3BWolf%2C+Lea&amp;rft.aulast=Goldkind&amp;rft.aufirst=Lauri&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=85&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu045

Content and Purpose of Supervision in Social Work Practice in England: Views of Newly Qualified Social Workers, Managers and Directors

Author: Manthorpe, Jill1; Moriarty, Jo; Hussein, Shereen; Stevens, Martin; Sharpe, Endellion1 Director, Social Care Workforce Research Unit, King's College London, Strand, London, WC2R 2LS, UK jill.manthorpe@kcl.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 52-68.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650716?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work supervision is receiving renewed attention internationally with calls for it to be remodelled and given greater priority, this paper uses data from a longitudinal study in England, which involved: three online surveys of Newly Qualified Social Workers (NQSWs); an online survey of Directors and face-to-face interviews with 23 social work managers which enabled us to investigate the receipt of supervision and its provision. Data on the frequency of supervision were analysed in relation to other job-related factors reported by NQSWs alongside information on NQSWs' views of the content of supervision. Findings suggest a tapering of supervision for social workers as they become more experienced but the overall level of supervision appears to be both limited and variable. NQSWs appreciated supervision from managers, and this affects their engagement with their work. Managers reported pressures of time in providing sufficient supervision. Directors conveyed their perception of the importance of supervision but indicated that there may be blurring of supervision as more structured support for NQSWs becomes part of the requirements for those in their first year in the profession. Greater attention should be given to investigating the effectiveness of supervision and to the support of those managers who are expected to provide it. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Content+and+Purpose+of+Supervision+in+Social+Work+Practice+in+England%3A+Views+of+Newly+Qualified+Social+Workers%2C+Managers+and+Directors&amp;rft.au=Manthorpe%2C+Jill%3BMoriarty%2C+Jo%3BHussein%2C+Shereen%3BStevens%2C+Martin%3BSharpe%2C+Endellion&amp;rft.aulast=Manthorpe&amp;rft.aufirst=Jill&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=52&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct102

Suicide Attempts and Social Worker Contact: Secondary Analysis of a General Population Study

Author: Slater, Thomas1; Scourfield, Jonathan; Greenland, Katy1 Cardiff University School of Social Sciences, Cardiff University, 1-3 Museum Place, Cardiff, CF10 3BD, UK slatertb1@cardiff.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 378-394.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650754?accountid=14667

Abstract: There is a general dearth of social work studies in relation to suicide and very little is known about the characteristics of social work service users who are also suicidal. This paper is based on secondary analysis of the survey 'Adult Psychiatric Morbidity Study in England 2007'. Results showed that (i) social work contact in the previous twelve months was significantly associated with lifetime suicide attempt; (ii) various risk and protective factors help to explain the relationship between suicide attempt and social work contact. Non-suicidal self-harm was found to be associated with suicide attempt, both with and without social work contact. Drug dependency was associated with social work contact, regardless of suicide attempt history. Other variables affected certain aspects of the relationship between social work contact and suicidality. These included age, religion, income, employment and background in local authority care. The implications for social work provision are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Suicide+Attempts+and+Social+Worker+Contact%3A+Secondary+Analysis+of+a+General+Population+Study&amp;rft.au=Slater%2C+Thomas%3BScourfield%2C+Jonathan%3BGreenland%2C+Katy&amp;rft.aulast=Slater&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=378&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct112

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Suicide+Attempts+and+Social+Worker+Contact%3A+Secondary+Analysis+of+a+General+Population+Study&amp;rft.au=Slater%2C+Thomas%3BScourfield%2C+Jonathan%3BGreenland%2C+Katy&amp;rft.aulast=Slater&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=378&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct112
