Work-Family Conflict and Its Impact on Job Satisfaction of Social Workers

Author: Kalliath, Parveen1; Kalliath, Thomas1 School of Social Work, Australian Catholic University, 127, Phillips Avenue, Watson, ACT 2602, Australia parveen.kalliath@acu.edu.au

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 241-259.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650755?accountid=14667

Abstract: Job satisfaction of social workers has captured the attention of social work researchers for many decades. Several organisation and client-related factors have been associated with reduced job satisfaction among social workers. Scant attention has been given to work-family conflict as a potential contributor despite growing evidence of its detrimental impact on the job satisfaction of varied sample groups of working men and women. The present study examined the impact of three forms of work-to-family conflict (WFC) and family-to-work conflict (FWC): Time, Behaviour and Strain, on job satisfaction of social workers in Australia. Data were gathered via an online survey from members of the Australian Association of Social Workers which yielded 439 usable data. Hierarchical multiple regression analyses showed that, in the direction of work-to-family conflict, WFC-Time and WFC-Strain were significant predictors of reduced job satisfaction. In the direction of family-to-work conflict, FWC-Behaviour significantly predicted reduced job satisfaction. These findings have implications for social work workforce planning and retention of social workers, and it emphasises the importance to have organisational policies that enhance the ability for social workers to manage their work and family commitments responsibly. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Work-Family+Conflict+and+Its+Impact+on+Job+Satisfaction+of+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=Kalliath%2C+Parveen%3BKalliath%2C+Thomas&amp;rft.aulast=Kalliath&amp;rft.aufirst=Parveen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=241&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct125

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Work-Family+Conflict+and+Its+Impact+on+Job+Satisfaction+of+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=Kalliath%2C+Parveen%3BKalliath%2C+Thomas&amp;rft.aulast=Kalliath&amp;rft.aufirst=Parveen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=241&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct125

Title: Work-Family Conflict and Its Impact on Job Satisfaction of Social Workers

CODEN: BJSWAS

Source type: Scholarly Journals

Peer reviewed: Yes

Language of publication: English

Document type: Journal Article

DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/bjsw/bct125

Update: 2015-12-01

____________________________________________________________

What Can and Cannot Be Learned from Serious Case Reviews of the Care and Treatment of Adults with Learning Disabilities in England? Messages for Social Workers

Author: Manthorpe, Jill1; Martineau, Stephen1 King's College London, Social Care Workforce Research Unit, Strand, London WC2B 4LL, UK jill.manthorpe@kcl.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 331-348.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650770?accountid=14667

Abstract: Serious Case Reviews (SCRs) for adults are commissioned to examine the ways in which local professionals and agencies worked together to safeguard a vulnerable adult or take place following harm or death of a vulnerable adult where there are concerns about agencies' actions or engagement. There is no national system in England for their collation or analysis. This paper presents the results of a study investigating SCRs for vulnerable adults where the person who was at risk of harm, harmed or died had a learning disability. Eighteen SCRs were identified and a further three where there are grounds for considering that the victim may have had such a disability. Three themes are presented: staff relationships; family and carers; and biography and chronology to draw out material relevant to social work policy and practice. At a time when the English government has announced plans for SCRs for adults to move to a statutory basis, this paper draws attention to their potential as learning materials, but also the risks of seeing them as presenting a full picture of practice. The case for local flexibility is argued. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=What+Can+and+Cannot+Be+Learned+from+Serious+Case+Reviews+of+the+Care+and+Treatment+of+Adults+with+Learning+Disabilities+in+England%3F+Messages+for+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=Manthorpe%2C+Jill%3BMartineau%2C+Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Manthorpe&amp;rft.aufirst=Jill&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=331&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct142

Fighting Fire: Emotional Risk Management at Social Service Agencies

Author: Williams, Nicole

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 89-91.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650779?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers advocate for, organize, assist, and counsel people and communities who have suffered historical and personal traumas, violence, poverty, discrimination, and the entire spectrum of oppression. In simpler terms, social workers strive to quell the fires of crisis and help people heal. Despite the well-known emotional risks, most social workers are ready to embrace the personal challenges and potential harms that come with social work practice. What we do not anticipate is the compounded vulnerability and risk we are exposed to when working at agencies where our emotional well-being is not supported by administrators or prioritized in agency operating policies and procedures. Various concepts aim to capture the prevalence and impact of psychological, emotional, and physical harms associated with common aspects of the social work profession (that is, high caseloads, daily exposure to trauma narratives, and working with few resources and little support); these concepts include burnout (Webster & Hackett, 1999), secondary traumatic stress (STS) (Arvay, 2002; Slattery & Goodman, 2009), compassion fatigue (see generally Figley, 1995; also see Conrad & Kellar-Guenther, 2006), and vicarious traumatization (Bell, Kulkarni, & Dalton, 2003). This literature demonstrates that social workers are vulnerable to burnout and STS and points to empathetic leadership and supportive organizational practices as protective factors. Yet, there are no professional guidelines aimed at ensuring that emotional risk management programs are systemically incorporated in social service agency operations. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Fighting+Fire%3A+Emotional+Risk+Management+at+Social+Service+Agencies&amp;rft.au=Williams%2C+Nicole&amp;rft.aulast=Williams&amp;rft.aufirst=Nicole&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=89&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu053

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Fighting+Fire%3A+Emotional+Risk+Management+at+Social+Service+Agencies&amp;rft.au=Williams%2C+Nicole&amp;rft.aulast=Williams&amp;rft.aufirst=Nicole&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=89&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu053

Caregivers of Veterans with 'Invisible' Injuries: What We Know and Implications for Social Work Practice

Author: Patel, Bina R11 Caregiver Support Coordinator, Social Work, U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, 1601 SW Archer Road, Mail Code 116A-4, Gainesville, FL beepat617@hotmail.com

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 9-17.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650788?accountid=14667

Abstract: Today, as a result of the longest volunteer-fought conflict in U.S. history, there are many wounded coming home not only with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), but also with traumatic brain injury (TBI), which together have been called the 'signature' or 'invisible' injuries of the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. Caregivers are an important part of their recovery, yet little is known about them, as previous research on caregivers mostly focused on geriatric populations. According to one estimate 275,000 to 1 million people are currently caring or have cared for loved ones who have returned from Iraq and Afghanistan. These caregivers are unique in that they are younger, some with children, and they are caring for a unique understudied population for longer periods of time. This article summarizes literature on caregivers of veterans who suffer from PTSD, TBI, or both; provides a theoretical framework; and discusses implications for social workers in assisting caregivers and their families. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Caregivers+of+Veterans+with+%27Invisible%27+Injuries%3A+What+We+Know+and+Implications+for+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Patel%2C+Bina+R&amp;rft.aulast=Patel&amp;rft.aufirst=Bina&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu043

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Caregivers+of+Veterans+with+%27Invisible%27+Injuries%3A+What+We+Know+and+Implications+for+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Patel%2C+Bina+R&amp;rft.aulast=Patel&amp;rft.aufirst=Bina&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu043

Service User Involvement in Social Work Research: Learning from an Adoption Research Project

Author: Cossar, Jeanette1; Neil, Elsbeth1 Department of Social Work, Elizabeth Fry Building, University of East Anglia, Norwich Research Park, NR4 7TJ, UK jeanette.cossar@uea.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 225-240.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650802?accountid=14667

Abstract: Service user involvement in research has triggered debate about epistemology, power relationships between researchers and participants, ethics and the validity of research findings. The social work profession encourages respect for service users and promotion of their rights-values which arguably should be reflected in social work research. This paper presents a case study of service user involvement in a government-funded adoption research project. The research team included a birth relative consultant group and the paper discusses both the process and outcomes of their involvement. The benefits and costs of service user involvement are highlighted. Reflections from the consultants about their experiences of being involved in the research are included. The discussion positions the project in relation to existing theories and models of service user involvement. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Service+User+Involvement+in+Social+Work+Research%3A+Learning+from+an+Adoption+Research+Project&amp;rft.au=Cossar%2C+Jeanette%3BNeil%2C+Elsbeth&amp;rft.aulast=Cossar&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanette&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=225&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct108

____________________________________________________________

The Importance of Advancing One Social Work: NASW 60 Years Later

Author: Bent-Goodley, Tricia B

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 5-7.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650808?accountid=14667

Abstract: The National Association of Social Workers (NASW) was established in 1955 with a focus on 'promoting the professional development of its members, establishing and maintaining professional standards of practice, advancing sound social policies, and providing services that protect its members and enhance their professional status' (NASW, 2014, para. 2). As NASW embarks on its 60th year of continuing its mission of advancing the profession and addressing critical social issues, the importance of advancing 'one' social work could not be more important. Social work continues to be a profession of relevance and great contribution. It is also one of the fastest growing professions in the nation. According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (2014), the profession is anticipated to grow by 19 percent between 2012 and 2022. This growth represents an anticipated 114,100 new social work positions, largely attributed to growth in aging and behavioral health areas. The profession addresses both long-standing and emerging issues. Using both a micro and a macro lens, the profession is uniquely positioned to promote lasting solutions and necessary changes, and give voice to important topics affecting a vast number of constituencies. In other words, as stated in NASW's brochure about social work, 'Social work contributions enable our nation to live up to its true promise' (NASW, n.d., p. 4). Consider the volume of change that social work has had to endure. Professional social work practice is not limited to local and national communities but extends across the world (Healy, 2008). International social work has grown to both demonstrate ways that we can assist and ways that we can learn from communities around the world. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Importance+of+Advancing+One+Social+Work%3A+NASW+60+Years+Later&amp;rft.au=Bent-Goodley%2C+Tricia+B&amp;rft.aulast=Bent-Goodley&amp;rft.aufirst=Tricia&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu052

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Importance+of+Advancing+One+Social+Work%3A+NASW+60+Years+Later&amp;rft.au=Bent-Goodley%2C+Tricia+B&amp;rft.aulast=Bent-Goodley&amp;rft.aufirst=Tricia&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu052

Understanding Foster Placement Instability for Looked After Children: A Systematic Review and Narrative Synthesis of Quantitative and Qualitative Evidence

Author: Rock, Stephen1; Michelson, Daniel; Thomson, Stacey; Day, Crispin1 CAMHS Research Unit, Department of Psychology (PO78), Institute of Psychiatry, King's College London

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 177-203.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650823?accountid=14667

Abstract: Ensuring the stability of foster placements for looked after children is a priority for social services. Many previous studies have highlighted the negative psychological, social and academic consequences of placement breakdown for foster children, but less is known about how services can effectively promote placement stability. A systematic review and narrative synthesis of research examining correlates of placement moves and breakdown were undertaken in order to inform practice in this area. Qualitative studies were included alongside quantitative research, providing additional insights into the processes that facilitate and impede placement stability. Correlates of increased placement instability with the strongest evidence included older age of children, externalising behaviour, longer total time in care, residential care as first placement setting, separation from siblings, foster-care versus kinship care and experience of multiple social workers. Key protective factors included placements with siblings, placements with older foster-carers, more experienced foster-carers with strong parenting skills, and placements where foster-carers provide opportunities for children to develop intellectually. Following from these findings, a conceptual framework is proposed that distinguishes vulnerability and protective factors as well as background and immediate factors. Implications for front line social work practice, including the development of manualised tools, are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+Foster+Placement+Instability+for+Looked+After+Children%3A+A+Systematic+Review+and+Narrative+Synthesis+of+Quantitative+and+Qualitative+Evidence&amp;rft.au=Rock%2C+Stephen%3BMichelson%2C+Daniel%3BThomson%2C+Stacey%3BDay%2C+Crispin&amp;rft.aulast=Rock&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=177&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct084

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+Foster+Placement+Instability+for+Looked+After+Children%3A+A+Systematic+Review+and+Narrative+Synthesis+of+Quantitative+and+Qualitative+Evidence&amp;rft.au=Rock%2C+Stephen%3BMichelson%2C+Daniel%3BThomson%2C+Stacey%3BDay%2C+Crispin&amp;rft.aulast=Rock&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=177&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct084

Subject: Placement; Foster Children; Risk Factors; Siblings; Narratives; Vulnerability; Childrearing Practices; Residential Institutions; Kinship

Classification: 6120: social work practice

Identifier / keyword: Foster-care foster placements looked after children placement breakdown placement stability substitute care

Title: Understanding Foster Placement Instability for Looked After Children: A Systematic Review and Narrative Synthesis of Quantitative and Qualitative Evidence

Correspondence author: Rock, Stephen  

Author e-mail address: daniel.m.d.michelson@kcl.ac.uk

Publication title: The British Journal of Social Work

Volume: 45

Issue: 1

Pages: 177-203

Spirituality and Religion in End-of-Life Care Ethics: The Challenge of Interfaith and Cross-Generational Matters

Author: Nelson-Becker, Holly1; Ai, Amy L; Hopp, Faith P; McCormick, Thomas R; Schlueter, Judith O; Camp, Jessica K1 Loyola University Chicago School of Social Work, 820 N. Michigan Ave, Chicago, IL 60611, USA

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 104-119.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650842?accountid=14667

Abstract: The complexity of illness and care needs at the end of life often include religious and spiritual issues. Religion and spirituality can be important coping mechanisms for meeting these challenges. However, although many people may want spirituality incorporated as a component of their care, spiritual needs are not always recognised or supported by the existing social care and medical systems. To address the need for more information on these issues, we present two social work cases that draw from our clinical experiences among patients with life-limiting disease conditions. Through these cases highlighting interfaith and cross-generational family issues, we identify different ways social workers may become involved in their interactions with patients' spiritual or religious concerns at the end of life. We conclude with suggestions for providing appropriate and culturally competent social and health care that promote aging in place for persons with life-limiting illness conditions. Adapted from the source document.

Inequalities in Child Welfare: Towards a New Policy, Research and Action Agenda

Author: Bywaters, Paul11 Faculty of Business, the Environment and Society, Coventry University, Priory Street, Coventry, CV1 5FB, UK P.Bywaters@coventry.ac.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 6-23.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650844?accountid=14667

Abstract: Over many years, large differences have been observed between local authorities (LAs) in England in the proportion of children who are 'looked after' out of home, or the subjects of child protection plans, with deprivation being identified as the major explanatory factor. This article proposes that such differences be reconceptualised as 'child welfare inequalities' and suggests that drawing parallels with health inequalities would have value in a number of respects. Four aspects of child welfare inequalities are suggested. An analysis of officially published data provides new evidence of inequalities between LAs in two key markers of child welfare, and the relationship with deprivation, measured by the Index of Multiple Deprivation scores. Although this correlation is unsurprising, there has been a lack of recent research into the extent and the underlying causes of child welfare inequalities, a reluctance to describe differences as inequalities or to propose action on the underlying social determinants. Reading across from the field of health inequalities opens up new directions for child welfare policy, practice, theory and research internationally as well as creating the potential for alliances with others taking action to reduce health inequalities. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Inequalities+in+Child+Welfare%3A+Towards+a+New+Policy%2C+Research+and+Action+Agenda&amp;rft.au=Bywaters%2C+Paul&amp;rft.aulast=Bywaters&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=6&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct079

Health and Psychosocial Service Use among Suicides without Psychiatric Illness

Author: Wa Law, Yik; Wong, Paul W C; Yip, Paul S F

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 65-74.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650850?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although mental illness is a major suicide risk factor, some cases of suicide list no symptoms of mental disorder at the time of death. Studying suicides without psychiatric illness has important implications for social work because this group's service needs seem to have been overlooked. The authors of this article conducted a psychological autopsy study of 150 people who committed suicide and 150 age- and gender-matched living controls. Suicides without psychiatric illness showed similar detectable psychopathology as the suicide and living control groups with nonpsychotic psychiatric disorders. Though suicides without psychiatric disorders showed fewer warning signs that could be noticed by their informants, they experienced more negative life events than living controls. The suicide cases without psychiatric illness also seemed to be less protected by enabling factors (such as social support and employment) than living controls with and without psychiatric disorders. Furthermore, they had lower use of services than the control and deceased-with-diagnosis groups. With fewer at-risk signs and poorer enabling resources, they were undetected or unengaged by the existing physical, psychiatric, and psychosocial services. This group should be of concern to social workers, who may develop community-based health education programs and preventive services to meet this vulnerable population's psychosocial needs. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Health+and+Psychosocial+Service+Use+among+Suicides+without+Psychiatric+Illness&amp;rft.au=Wa+Law%2C+Yik%3BWong%2C+Paul+W+C%3BYip%2C+Paul+S+F&amp;rft.aulast=Wa+Law&amp;rft.aufirst=Yik&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=65&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu054

Intersecting Deviance: Social Work, Difference and the Legacy of Eugenics

Author: Gibson, Margaret F11 Factor-Inwentash Faculty of Social Work, 246 Bloor Street West, Toronto, ON M5S 1V4, Canada margaret.gibson@utoronto.ca

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 313-330.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650871?accountid=14667

Abstract: How do we understand human difference, and what should we do with it? These are central questions of social work knowledge, practice and pedagogy. In recent years, 'intersectionality' has emerged as a useful construct in theorising how difference operates in social hierarchies. Too often, however, 'intersectional' discussions have led to increasingly fine divisions that isolate individuals and reify categories of difference. This article argues that an active engagement with history can promote a more nuanced and helpful approach to intersectionality, as a greater understanding of the past shakes up static perceptions of identity categories. The legacy of eugenics visible in present-day notions of 'desirable reproduction' is explored using the example of 'queer parents of disabled children'. Two ways of looking at such a grouping illustrate different possible applications of intersectionality theory. A temporal, relational intersectionality is proposed-one that can be both historically responsive and situated in everyday narratives. The article concludes by addressing the social work implications of a historically aware, relational approach to difference. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Intersecting+Deviance%3A+Social+Work%2C+Difference+and+the+Legacy+of+Eugenics&amp;rft.au=Gibson%2C+Margaret+F&amp;rft.aulast=Gibson&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=313&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct131

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Intersecting+Deviance%3A+Social+Work%2C+Difference+and+the+Legacy+of+Eugenics&amp;rft.au=Gibson%2C+Margaret+F&amp;rft.aulast=Gibson&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=313&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct131

____________________________________________________________

Are Sexual Assault Victims Presenting to the Emergency Department in a Timely Manner?

Author: Lee, Jarone; Willis, Lucy; Newman, David; Hazan, Alberto; Kurobe, Aileen; Giordano, Lorraine; Kaafarani, Haytham; Laidlaw, Caitlin; Shah, Kaushal

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 29-33.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650872?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers regularly assist sexual assault victims and would benefit from a greater understanding of causes for delayed presentation to seek medical care. Delays in presentation of sexual assault victims affect the legal value of collected evidence. The authors of this study sought to characterize the nature and frequency of delayed presentation among victims. To do so, they performed a chart review from 2001 to 2007 of the Sexual Assault Forensic Examiner program at their institution. Delayed presentation was defined as presentation more than 12 hours after the assault. Chi-square test was used to contrast frequencies, and multivariate regression was used to control for confounders. Among 482 victims, more than half presented delayed. Of the victims who documented whether they knew the perpetrator, 63 percent knew the perpetrator, with 58 percent of these presenting delayed. Knowing the perpetrator was significantly associated with delayed presentation. Age, ethnicity, and gender were not associated with delayed presentation. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Are+Sexual+Assault+Victims+Presenting+to+the+Emergency+Department+in+a+Timely+Manner%3F&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Jarone%3BWillis%2C+Lucy%3BNewman%2C+David%3BHazan%2C+Alberto%3BKurobe%2C+Aileen%3BGiordano%2C+Lorraine%3BKaafarani%2C+Haytham%3BLaidlaw%2C+Caitlin%3BShah%2C+Kaushal&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Jarone&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=29&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu051

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Are+Sexual+Assault+Victims+Presenting+to+the+Emergency+Department+in+a+Timely+Manner%3F&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Jarone%3BWillis%2C+Lucy%3BNewman%2C+David%3BHazan%2C+Alberto%3BKurobe%2C+Aileen%3BGiordano%2C+Lorraine%3BKaafarani%2C+Haytham%3BLaidlaw%2C+Caitlin%3BShah%2C+Kaushal&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Jarone&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=29&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu051

____________________________________________________________

Alternative Psychological Approaches for Social Workers and Social Work Students Dealing with Stress in the UK: Sense of Coherence, Challenge Appraisals, Self-Efficacy and Sense of Control

Author: Collins, Stewart11 19 Milton Hill, Milton by Dumbarton, G82 2TS, UK stewartcollins@blueyonder.co.uk

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 69-85.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650881?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work students and social workers are being encouraged to become more resistant to stress. Sense of coherence, challenge appraisals, self-efficacy and sense of control are important psychological concepts that are of significance in helping social workers and social work students become more resilient in their approach. Sense of coherence is focused on health and strengths. Challenge appraisals involve perceiving 'difficult' situations in more positive ways. Self-efficacy relates to beliefs and confidence in one's abilities to undertake tasks. Sense of control involves the exercise of personal and professional agency and one's capacity to influence and change situations. These psychological concepts are explored and their implications for social workers and social work students are considered. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Alternative+Psychological+Approaches+for+Social+Workers+and+Social+Work+Students+Dealing+with+Stress+in+the+UK%3A+Sense+of+Coherence%2C+Challenge+Appraisals%2C+Self-Efficacy+and+Sense+of+Control&amp;rft.au=Collins%2C+Stewart&amp;rft.aulast=Collins&amp;rft.aufirst=Stewart&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=69&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct103

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Alternative+Psychological+Approaches+for+Social+Workers+and+Social+Work+Students+Dealing+with+Stress+in+the+UK%3A+Sense+of+Coherence%2C+Challenge+Appraisals%2C+Self-Efficacy+and+Sense+of+Control&amp;rft.au=Collins%2C+Stewart&amp;rft.aulast=Collins&amp;rft.aufirst=Stewart&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=69&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct103

The Accumulation of Multiple Sources of Psychosocial Disadvantage and Their Correlation to Reported Overall Health: Establishing a Threshold

Author: Wardian, Jana; Thaller, Jonel; Urbaeva, Zhyldyz

Publication info: Social Work  Vol. 60, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 45-54.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650911?accountid=14667

Abstract: Psychosocial disadvantage and lower socioeconomic status are associated with increased risk of poor health. The purposes of this study are to identify a threshold at which cumulative psychosocial risk factors become significantly associated with a decrease in health status and to examine whether women are at higher risk than men. Using secondary cross-sectional data, a correlation of self-reported health rating and psychosocial risk factors was conducted. Participant characteristics by number of health-related psychosocial risks were constructed. The accumulation of risk factors had a negative effect on health status at the threshold of two; health status significantly decreased with the addition of each risk factor. Gender significantly moderated the relationship between number of risks and self-reported health status, with women's health decreasing as the number of risks increased. Risk factors in this study are typically part of client assessments and can be used in assisting social workers to identify those most at risk. Those with two or more risk factors are significantly more at risk for poorer health. Moreover, women and ethnic minorities were at more risk for poor health with the addition of just one risk factor. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Accumulation+of+Multiple+Sources+of+Psychosocial+Disadvantage+and+Their+Correlation+to+Reported+Overall+Health%3A+Establishing+a+Threshold&amp;rft.au=Wardian%2C+Jana%3BThaller%2C+Jonel%3BUrbaeva%2C+Zhyldyz&amp;rft.aulast=Wardian&amp;rft.aufirst=Jana&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu049

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Accumulation+of+Multiple+Sources+of+Psychosocial+Disadvantage+and+Their+Correlation+to+Reported+Overall+Health%3A+Establishing+a+Threshold&amp;rft.au=Wardian%2C+Jana%3BThaller%2C+Jonel%3BUrbaeva%2C+Zhyldyz&amp;rft.aulast=Wardian&amp;rft.aufirst=Jana&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=60&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00378046&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fsw%2Fswu049

Bringing Context and Power Relations to the Fore: Intergroup Dialogue as a Tool in Social Work Education

Author: Nadan, Yochay1; Weinberg-Kurnik, Galia; Ben-Ari, Adital1 School of Social Work, Sapir College, Israel yochay.nadan@gmail.com

Publication info: The British Journal of Social Work  Vol. 45, Iss. 1,  (January 2015): 260-277.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650928?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this research was to examine the unique contribution of intergroup dialogue encounters, held in an international context, to multicultural social work education. We conducted a qualitative study based on fifteen in-depth interviews with Israeli social work students who had participated in a German-Israeli intergroup encounter. The analysis yielded two main themes: a movement between different viewpoints, and a reflection on categories of difference and collective narratives. Our findings indicate that intergroup encounter fosters critical reflectivity on two main interwoven constructs that are especially relevant to multicultural social work education-contextuality and power relations. This is achieved through four dynamic processes in intergroup encounter: shifting from deductive to inductive reasoning, from an essentialist to a constructivist perception, from focusing on the 'other' to inquiring about ourselves, and experiencing intersectionality. International intergroup encounters can therefore contribute to professional efforts to educate critical, reflective and socially committed practitioners, and can help to meet the challenges of working in contemporary societies characterised by growing diversity, intergroup tensions, ethnic and political conflicts. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Bringing+Context+and+Power+Relations+to+the+Fore%3A+Intergroup+Dialogue+as+a+Tool+in+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.au=Nadan%2C+Yochay%3BWeinberg-Kurnik%2C+Galia%3BBen-Ari%2C+Adital&amp;rft.aulast=Nadan&amp;rft.aufirst=Yochay&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=260&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct116

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Bringing+Context+and+Power+Relations+to+the+Fore%3A+Intergroup+Dialogue+as+a+Tool+in+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.au=Nadan%2C+Yochay%3BWeinberg-Kurnik%2C+Galia%3BBen-Ari%2C+Adital&amp;rft.aulast=Nadan&amp;rft.aufirst=Yochay&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=260&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=The+British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1093%2Fbjsw%2Fbct116

Guidelines for Conducting Rigorous Health Care Psychosocial Cross-Cultural/Language Qualitative Research

Author: Arriaza, Pablo1; Nedjat-Haiem, Frances; Lee, Hee Yun; Martin, Shadi S1 Walden University, School of Social Work and Human Services, 100 Washington Avenue South, Suite 900, Minneapolis, MN 55401, USA arriaza@waldenu.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 75-87.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761681774?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is to synthesize and chronicle the authors' experiences as four bilingual and bicultural researchers, each experienced in conducting cross-cultural/cross-language qualitative research. Through narrative descriptions of experiences with Latinos, Iranians, and Hmong refugees, the authors discuss their rewards, challenges, and methods of enhancing rigor, trustworthiness, and transparency when conducting cross-cultural/cross-language research. The authors discuss and explore how to effectively manage cross-cultural qualitative data, how to effectively use interpreters and translators, how to identify best methods of transcribing data, and the role of creating strong community relationships. The authors provide guidelines for health care professionals to consider when engaging in cross-cultural qualitative research. Adapted from the source document.

Challenges and Resilience in the Lives of Adults with Sickle Cell Disease

Author: Williams-Gray, Brenda1; Senreich, Evan1 Lehman College, City University of New York, Carman Hall, B-18, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, Bronx, NY 10468, USA brenda.williams-gray@lehman.cuny.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 88-105.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761681826?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative study focused on the experiences of adults living with sickle cell disease (SCD) in the New York City area. Twenty-three individuals participated in one of three focus groups. The purpose of this study was to learn if appropriate health care for individuals with sickle cell disease, based on years of research, has been implemented. The findings indicate that best practices in the treatment of SCD are often not followed by medical personnel. Critical race theory provides a framework to understand the 10 emergent themes. The participants' responses illustrate resilience in facing adversity. Implications for social work practice are presented. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Challenges+and+Resilience+in+the+Lives+of+Adults+with+Sickle+Cell+Disease&amp;rft.au=Williams-Gray%2C+Brenda%3BSenreich%2C+Evan&amp;rft.aulast=Williams-Gray&amp;rft.aufirst=Brenda&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=88&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938396

The Making of a Medical Disorder: Tracing the Emergence of Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder in Alberta

Author: Shankar, Irene11 Mount Royal University, Sociology, 4825 Mount Royal Gate SW, Calgary, Alberta, T3E6K6 Canada ishankar@mtroyal.ca

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 38-50.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761681860?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the processes through which health disorders become accepted as a public health concern, and the defining role played by social actors responsible for bringing such disorders to public attention. Such analysis provides us with a particular history of health disorders and the implications of this early history in the current conceptualization of such disorders within contemporary health programs and policies. This article traces the emergence and acceptance of fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) as a public health concern in Alberta and the ongoing tensions resulting from this early history. Specifically, the author examines the integral role of social workers and various government officials in getting FASD recognized as a health concern. This Alberta case study demonstrates the importance of investigating the sociopolitical context in which health disorders emerge and become accepted. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Making+of+a+Medical+Disorder%3A+Tracing+the+Emergence+of+Fetal+Alcohol+Spectrum+Disorder+in+Alberta&amp;rft.au=Shankar%2C+Irene&amp;rft.aulast=Shankar&amp;rft.aufirst=Irene&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=38&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938390

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Making+of+a+Medical+Disorder%3A+Tracing+the+Emergence+of+Fetal+Alcohol+Spectrum+Disorder+in+Alberta&amp;rft.au=Shankar%2C+Irene&amp;rft.aulast=Shankar&amp;rft.aufirst=Irene&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=38&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938390

Social work - social development. Vol. I: Human rights and social equality: challenges for social work, edited by Sven Hessle, Farnham, Ashgate, 2014, 216 pp., L60.00 (hardback), L54.00 (online), ISBN 978-1-4724-1235-5 Social work - social development. Vol. II: Environmental change and sustainable development, edited by Sven Hessle, Farnham, Ashgate, 2014, 196 pp., L60.00 (hardback), L54.00 (online), ISBN 978-1-4724-1637-7

Author: Tabin, Jean-Pierre

Publication info: European Journal of Social Work  Vol. 18, Iss. 3,  (0, 2015): 468-471.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761681885?accountid=14667

Abstract: A review essay covering books by: 1) Sven Hessle, Social work - social development. Vol. I: Human rights and social equality: challenges for social work (2014); 2) Sven Hessle, Social work - social development. Vol. II: Environmental change and sustainable development (2014).

Health Promotion and Primary Health Care: Examining the Discourse

Author: Ashcroft, Rachelle11 School of Social Work, Renison University College, University of Waterloo, 240 Westmount Road North, Waterloo, Ontario, N2L 3G4, Canada rachelle.ashcroft@uwaterloo.ca

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 107-116.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682703?accountid=14667

Abstract: The health promotion discourse is comprised of assumptions about health and health care that are compatible with primary health care. An examination of the health promotion discourse illustrates how assumptions of health can help to inform primary health care. Despite health promotion being a good fit for primary health care, this analysis demonstrates that the scope in which it is being implemented in primary health care settings is limited. The health promotion discourse appears largely compatible with primary health care-in theory and in the health care practices that follow. The aim of this article is to contribute to the advancement of theoretical understanding of the health promotion discourse, and the relevance of health promotion to primary health care. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Health+Promotion+and+Primary+Health+Care%3A+Examining+the+Discourse&amp;rft.au=Ashcroft%2C+Rachelle&amp;rft.aulast=Ashcroft&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachelle&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=107&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938395

Opportunities for Social Workers in the Patient Centered Medical Home

Author: Hawk, Mary1; Ricci, Edmund; Huber, George; Myers, Marcella1 Department of Behavioral and Community Health Services, University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public Health, 226-A Crabtree Hall, Pittsburgh, PA 15261, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 175-184.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682704?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Patient Centered Medical Home (PCMH) has been hailed as one method of improving chronic care outcomes in the United States. A number of studies have underscored the importance of the social work role within the PCMH, yet little existing research explores the social worker as a driver of improved patient care. The Pennsylvania Chronic Care Initiative was created with a primary goal of increasing the number of practices that were recognized as PCMH by the National Committee for Quality Assurance. This article describes findings from in-depth qualitative interviews with representatives from seven primary care practices, in which the authors examined barriers and facilitators to implementation of the initiative. Barriers to implementation included small practice size, payer-driven care, not having a strong physician champion, variability within patient populations, and high implementation costs. Facilitators included having a social worker coordinate behavioral health services, clinical nurse case managers, preexisting models of outcomes-driven care, and being part of an integrated health delivery and financing system. Recommendations strengthening the role of medical social workers in primary care practices are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Opportunities+for+Social+Workers+in+the+Patient+Centered+Medical+Home&amp;rft.au=Hawk%2C+Mary%3BRicci%2C+Edmund%3BHuber%2C+George%3BMyers%2C+Marcella&amp;rft.aulast=Hawk&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=175&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.969862

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Opportunities+for+Social+Workers+in+the+Patient+Centered+Medical+Home&amp;rft.au=Hawk%2C+Mary%3BRicci%2C+Edmund%3BHuber%2C+George%3BMyers%2C+Marcella&amp;rft.aulast=Hawk&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=175&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.969862

Happiness among Poor Women Victims of Intimate Partner Violence in Nicaragua

Author: Vazquez, Jose Juan1; Panadero, Sonia; Rivas, Esther1 Area de Psicologia Social, Universidad de Alcala, Aulario Maria de Guzman, C/ San Cirilo, s/n., 28801 Alcala de Henares, Madrid, Espana jj.vazquez@uah.es

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 18-29.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682787?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article analyzes various aspects of overall happiness expressed by 136 women in poverty who are victims of intimate partner violence (IPV) in Nicaragua, a country with low levels of development. The information was gathered using a structured interview. Results obtained show that despite the hardships they face, one half of the women in poverty who are victims of IPV say they are happy, and the vast majority are optimistic about their future. The main sources of happiness among the interviewees are in areas outside their economic life and are mainly associated with social relations. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Happiness+among+Poor+Women+Victims+of+Intimate+Partner+Violence+in+Nicaragua&amp;rft.au=Vazquez%2C+Jose+Juan%3BPanadero%2C+Sonia%3BRivas%2C+Esther&amp;rft.aulast=Vazquez&amp;rft.aufirst=Jose&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=18&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938389

Family Caregiver's Perception of Alzheimer's Disease and Caregiving in Chinese Culture

Author: Dai, Baozhen1; Mao, Zongfu; Wu, Bei; Mei, Y John; Levkoff, Sue; Wang, Huali1 School of Management, Jiangsu University, 301 Xuefu Road, Zhenjiang 212013, China hixiaodai@sina.com

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 185-196.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682802?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the perception of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and caregiving among family caregivers of individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and AD in China. In-depth semistructured interviews were conducted with 46 family caregivers of individuals with cognitive impairment in 2009 in Wuhan and Beijing, China. Participants included 38 spouses, 7 adult children, and 1 sibling, aged between 41 and 85 years old. The findings showed that all family caregivers thought the Chinese terminology of AD laonian chidai, brought discrimination to individuals with cognitive impairment. Caregivers of individuals with AD experienced burden and desired an increase of formal services. Traditional beliefs of respecting elders and caring for extended family members were held among family caregivers of individuals with cognitive impairment, and there was nearly no difference found between caregivers of AD and those of MCI. It implied that traditional culture provided positive influences on caring for elders with cognitive impairment. An alternative term for MCI may contribute to further reducing the discrimination brought by the old Chinese terminology of AD laonian chidai. Development of formal services for elders with cognitive impairment may contribute to reducing caregivers' worries about future caregiving. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Family+Caregiver%27s+Perception+of+Alzheimer%27s+Disease+and+Caregiving+in+Chinese+Culture&amp;rft.au=Dai%2C+Baozhen%3BMao%2C+Zongfu%3BWu%2C+Bei%3BMei%2C+Y+John%3BLevkoff%2C+Sue%3BWang%2C+Huali&amp;rft.aulast=Dai&amp;rft.aufirst=Baozhen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=185&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.969858

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Family+Caregiver%27s+Perception+of+Alzheimer%27s+Disease+and+Caregiving+in+Chinese+Culture&amp;rft.au=Dai%2C+Baozhen%3BMao%2C+Zongfu%3BWu%2C+Bei%3BMei%2C+Y+John%3BLevkoff%2C+Sue%3BWang%2C+Huali&amp;rft.aulast=Dai&amp;rft.aufirst=Baozhen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=185&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.969858

____________________________________________________________

Science from Evaluation: Testing Hypotheses about Differential Effects of Three Youth-Focused Suicide Prevention Trainings

Author: Coleman, Daniel1; Del Quest, Aisling1 Fordham University Graduate School of Social Service, 113 West 60th Street, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10023, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 117-128.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682813?accountid=14667

Abstract: As part of an evaluation component of a youth suicide prevention, a quasi-experimental repeated measures design tested hypotheses about two brief suicide prevention gatekeeper trainings (Question, Persuade, Refer [QPR] and RESPONSE) and one longer suicide intervention skills training (Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training [ASIST]). All three trainings showed large changes in prevention attitudes and self-efficacy, largely maintained at follow-up. ASIST trainees had large increases in asking at-risk youth about suicide at follow-up. Convergent with other research, modeling and role-play in training are crucial to increased prevention behaviors. Practice and research implications are discussed, including social work roles in suicide prevention and research. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Science+from+Evaluation%3A+Testing+Hypotheses+about+Differential+Effects+of+Three+Youth-Focused+Suicide+Prevention+Trainings&amp;rft.au=Coleman%2C+Daniel%3BDel+Quest%2C+Aisling&amp;rft.aulast=Coleman&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=117&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938397

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Science+from+Evaluation%3A+Testing+Hypotheses+about+Differential+Effects+of+Three+Youth-Focused+Suicide+Prevention+Trainings&amp;rft.au=Coleman%2C+Daniel%3BDel+Quest%2C+Aisling&amp;rft.aulast=Coleman&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=117&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938397

Parental Expectations of Maternal and Child Health Services

Author: Bradt, Lieve1; Vandenbroeck, Michel; Lammertyn, Jan; Bouverne-De Bie, Maria1 Department of Social Welfare Studies, Ghent University, Henri Dunantlaan, 2, 9000 Gent, Belgium

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 197-206.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682827?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports on survey research (N = 1,418) aimed at examining whether parental expectations of maternal and child health (MCH) services are influenced by group characteristics (e.g., socioeconomic status [SES], ethnicity, at risk of poverty) and/or individual parenting context variables (e.g., received social support) in a context where these services are available to all. The findings reveal that parents have different expectations about the technical and relational expertise of MCH nurses. However, the authors found only very weak associations between family characteristics and parental expectations, suggesting that individual differences matter more than SES and other more traditional distinctions. Implications for MCH services are made. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Parental+Expectations+of+Maternal+and+Child+Health+Services&amp;rft.au=Bradt%2C+Lieve%3BVandenbroeck%2C+Michel%3BLammertyn%2C+Jan%3BBouverne-De+Bie%2C+Maria&amp;rft.aulast=Bradt&amp;rft.aufirst=Lieve&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=197&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.992586

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Parental+Expectations+of+Maternal+and+Child+Health+Services&amp;rft.au=Bradt%2C+Lieve%3BVandenbroeck%2C+Michel%3BLammertyn%2C+Jan%3BBouverne-De+Bie%2C+Maria&amp;rft.aulast=Bradt&amp;rft.aufirst=Lieve&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=197&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.992586

Using Community-Based Participatory Research to Advocate for Homeless Children

Author: Fetherman, Debra L1; Burke, Stephen C1 Human Development, Health Promotion, University of Scranton, Exercise Science and Sport, 143 Long Center, Scranton, PA 18510, USA debra.fetherman@scranton.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 30-37.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682864?accountid=14667

Abstract: The social determinants of health represent the societal and economic influences responsible for most health inequities. Advocacy to eliminate health inequities for homeless children oftentimes involves the use of community-based approaches. This article details the Floating Hospital's (TFH) community-based participatory research (CBPR) project that resulted in an advocacy brief. Within the project, the community practice concepts of a strengths perspective, empowerment, capacity building, and advocacy are embedded. The brief enhances TFH's capacity to advocate for the needs of homeless children. This example serves as a guide for social work and public health professionals to use CBPR to address health inequities within their communities. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Using+Community-Based+Participatory+Research+to+Advocate+for+Homeless+Children&amp;rft.au=Fetherman%2C+Debra+L%3BBurke%2C+Stephen+C&amp;rft.aulast=Fetherman&amp;rft.aufirst=Debra&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=30&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938391

Preventing Rapid Repeat Pregnancy and Promoting Positive Parenting among Young Mothers in Foster Care

Author: Finigan-Carr, Nadine M1; Murray, Kantahyanee W; O'Connor, Julia M; Rushovich, Berenice R; Dixon, Desyree A; Barth, Richard P1 School of Social Work, University of Maryland, Baltimore, 525 W. Redwood Street, Baltimore, MD 21201, USA

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 1-17.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682871?accountid=14667

Abstract: Young mothers in foster care face considerable challenges above and beyond that of their non-foster care peers. Child welfare workers have few resources to guide them in the selection of evidence-informed programs, models, and strategies that address the unique risk factors and needs of youth in foster care who are at risk for rapid repeat pregnancy and inadequate parenting practices. Workers need knowledge of the evidence about which programs are most likely to improve key health and well-being outcomes. The article assesses the evidence-based programs identified and yields a list that reflects the best evidence for efficacy and effectiveness. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Preventing+Rapid+Repeat+Pregnancy+and+Promoting+Positive+Parenting+among+Young+Mothers+in+Foster+Care&amp;rft.au=Finigan-Carr%2C+Nadine+M%3BMurray%2C+Kantahyanee+W%3BO%27Connor%2C+Julia+M%3BRushovich%2C+Berenice+R%3BDixon%2C+Desyree+A%3BBarth%2C+Richard+P&amp;rft.aulast=Finigan-Carr&amp;rft.aufirst=Nadine&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938388

The Relationship between Psychosocial Factors and Breast Cancer Screening Behaviors of Older Hispanic Women

Author: Cadet, Tamara J11 Simmons College School of Social Work, 300 The Fenway, Boston, MA 02115, USA tamara.cadet@simmons.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 207-223.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682875?accountid=14667

Abstract: Guided by the theory of planned behavior, this study utilized data from the 2008 wave of the Health and Retirement Study to investigate psychosocial factors associated with older Hispanic women's participation in breast cancer screening services. Hierarchical logistic regression models were used to assess the odds of breast cancer screening participation. Findings indicate that satisfaction with aging and constraints were associated with a reduced likelihood of participating in breast cancer screening. These findings suggest the continued importance to assess older women's attitudes when discussing preventive services. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Relationship+between+Psychosocial+Factors+and+Breast+Cancer+Screening+Behaviors+of+Older+Hispanic+Women&amp;rft.au=Cadet%2C+Tamara+J&amp;rft.aulast=Cadet&amp;rft.aufirst=Tamara&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=207&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.969857

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=The+Relationship+between+Psychosocial+Factors+and+Breast+Cancer+Screening+Behaviors+of+Older+Hispanic+Women&amp;rft.au=Cadet%2C+Tamara+J&amp;rft.aulast=Cadet&amp;rft.aufirst=Tamara&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=207&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.969857

Visibility and Findability of the Nursing Home Compare Website

Author: Liu, Darren1; Lu, Chi-Jung1 Department of Health Care Administration and Policy, School of Community Health Sciences, University of Nevada, 4505 Maryland Parkway, Box 453023, Las Vegas, NV 89154-3023, USA darren.liu@unlv.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 144-156.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682878?accountid=14667

Abstract: Nursing Home Compare (NHC) is a federal government website providing information for selecting a nursing home. However, not many consumers were aware of or can locate the site. This study analyzed 50 official state and District of Columbia websites from September through December 2013. Using Google 'inlink:' operator, this study evaluated the visibility and findability of NHC links in each state-level website. The results show that a link to NHC is available in all states except for Connecticut, Florida, and Michigan. Although it took only 4.7 clicks on average to the page with a NHC link, consumers may still have difficulty to find NHC from a state website. This article provides a snapshot of the visibility and findability of NHC and indicates a need for further investigation of promising website dissemination strategies not yet adequately evaluated. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Visibility+and+Findability+of+the+Nursing+Home+Compare+Website&amp;rft.au=Liu%2C+Darren%3BLu%2C+Chi-Jung&amp;rft.aulast=Liu&amp;rft.aufirst=Darren&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=144&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.969861

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Visibility+and+Findability+of+the+Nursing+Home+Compare+Website&amp;rft.au=Liu%2C+Darren%3BLu%2C+Chi-Jung&amp;rft.aulast=Liu&amp;rft.aufirst=Darren&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=144&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.969861

____________________________________________________________

Contextually Appropriate Measurement as the Basis for Culturally Appropriate Interventions: A Case Study in Managua, Nicaragua

Author: Jani, Jayshree S1; Deforge, Bruce R1 School of Social Work, University of Maryland, Baltimore County, 1000 Hilltop Circle, Academic IV-B-362, Baltimore, MD 21250, USA jani@umbc.edu

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 157-174.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682962?accountid=14667

Abstract: Despite recent advances in U.S. health care, racial and ethnic minorities experience significantly worse health and mental health outcomes. Policy responses to this problem are based on available research, which is often premised on a misinterpretation of the cultural concepts that underlie people's health and mental health. Health researchers often rely upon measurements with questionable cultural validity. This contributes to a lack of understanding of health disparities that nondominant populations experience and creates obstacles to the development of effective policies to alleviate them. Even statistically valid or literally translated measurements often fail to account for different social and cultural contexts and/or neglect to consider vital information about the population studied or its history. This article reports on the content validity of measures used in a study that investigated predictors of mental health in Managua, Nicaragua. Results reveal a polarized response structure and lack of cultural relevance in underlying concepts measured. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Contextually+Appropriate+Measurement+as+the+Basis+for+Culturally+Appropriate+Interventions%3A+A+Case+Study+in+Managua%2C+Nicaragua&amp;rft.au=Jani%2C+Jayshree+S%3BDeforge%2C+Bruce+R&amp;rft.aulast=Jani&amp;rft.aufirst=Jayshree&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=157&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.969859

____________________________________________________________

Alcohol, Violence, and a Fast Growing Male Population: Exploring a Risky-Mix in 'Boomtown' Darwin

Author: Ennis, Gretchen1; Finlayson, Mary1 Research Centre for Health & Wellbeing, Charles Darwin University, Darwin, 0909 Northern Territory, Australia gretchen.ennis@cdu.edu.au

Publication info: Social Work in Public Health  Vol. 30, Iss. 2-3,  (0, 2015): 51-63.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761687959?accountid=14667

Abstract: Boomtowns are places where populations grow rapidly, mostly as a result of large-scale natural resource developments. Increases in alcohol consumption and alcohol-fuelled violence are often linked to influxes of (predominantly male) workers associated with such developments. This article provides an integrated review of literature concerning alcohol and violence in boomtowns. The authors aim to understand the links between these issues and explore how negative impacts have been addressed. New learning from the review is considered in the context of Darwin, a newly booming city in Australia's Northern Territory. The authors find that although alcohol-related violence is likely to increase, there is limited literature concerning the prevention or mitigation of negative impacts in boomtown contexts. The need for research, planning, and policy making involving all stakeholders is highlighted. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Alcohol%2C+Violence%2C+and+a+Fast+Growing+Male+Population%3A+Exploring+a+Risky-Mix+in+%27Boomtown%27+Darwin&amp;rft.au=Ennis%2C+Gretchen%3BFinlayson%2C+Mary&amp;rft.aulast=Ennis&amp;rft.aufirst=Gretchen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=51&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938392

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.atitle=Alcohol%2C+Violence%2C+and+a+Fast+Growing+Male+Population%3A+Exploring+a+Risky-Mix+in+%27Boomtown%27+Darwin&amp;rft.au=Ennis%2C+Gretchen%3BFinlayson%2C+Mary&amp;rft.aulast=Ennis&amp;rft.aufirst=Gretchen&amp;rft.date=2015-01-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=2-3&amp;rft.spage=51&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+in+Public+Health&amp;rft.issn=19371918&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F19371918.2014.938392
