H. S. Sullivan and His Contribution to the Relational School

Author: Berzoff, Joan11 Smith College School for Social Work, Northampton, Massachusetts, USA

Publication info: Smith College Studies in Social Work  Vol. 85, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 54-71.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680150441?accountid=14667

Abstract: Harry Stack Sullivan's contributions to the interpersonal school foreshadowed much of relational theory and practice today. His key ideas included consensual validation, dissociation, anxiety, a developmental theory about the need for others, and also practice techniques including empathy and a detailed inquiry into understanding clients. These are discussed as they relate to current relational and intersubjective practice including how the therapist and client always shape each other. Ideas from relational and intersubjective practice are discussed in light of Sullivan's contributions. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Smith+College+Studies+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=H.+S.+Sullivan+and+His+Contribution+to+the+Relational+School&amp;rft.au=Berzoff%2C+Joan&amp;rft.aulast=Berzoff&amp;rft.aufirst=Joan&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=85&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=54&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Smith+College+Studies+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00377317&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F00377317.2015.957600

Moving Forward: A Qualitative Research Inquiry to Inform the Development of a Resource Pack for Women Following Primary Breast Cancer Treatment

Author: Fenlon, Deborah1; Reed, Elizabeth; Blows, Emma; Scanlon, Karen; Wray, Julie; Dewey, Ann1 University of Southampton, Highfield, Southampton, UK

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 33, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 85-105.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692283317?accountid=14667

Abstract: While the UK charity Breast Cancer Care has extensive resources for women with breast cancer, this research partnership developed the first resource driven and informed by primary research with these women, exploring their needs and developing the resource according to need. Data were collected from focus groups with breast cancer survivors and telephone interviews with health professionals and experts, which explored the needs of women after primary cancer treatment, and were analyzed using thematic analysis. As well as information, these women needed resources to help them regain control over life, adapt to a changed body, and restore lost confidence. Adapted from the source document.

Accuracy of the Emotion Thermometers (ET) Screening Tool in Patients Undergoing Surgery for Upper Gastrointestinal Malignancies

Author: Schubart, Jane R1; Mitchell, Alex J; Dietrich, Laura; Gusani, Niraj J1 Departments of Surgery, Medicine, and Public Health Sciences, College of Medicine, The Pennsylvania State University, Hershey, PA, USA

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 33, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 1-14.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692283323?accountid=14667

Abstract: Distress is common in patients with gastrointestinal cancers. Most conventional scales are too long for routine clinic use. We tested the Emotion Thermometers (ET) tool, a brief visual-analogue scale. There are four emotional upset thermometers: distress, anxiety, depression, and anger. Sixty-nine surgical patients were recruited from an academic hospital clinic in 2012; 64 had complete data for Beck depression inventory and ET. The sample size was modest due to the specialist nature of the sample. We examined sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver-operator-curve. A dimensional multi-domain approach to screening for emotional disorders is preferable to using the distress thermometer alone and can be achieved with little extra time burden to clinicians. The ET is a diagnostic tool that is primarily designed for screening to identify cancer patients who would benefit by enhanced psychosocial care. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Accuracy+of+the+Emotion+Thermometers+%28ET%29+Screening+Tool+in+Patients+Undergoing+Surgery+for+Upper+Gastrointestinal+Malignancies&amp;rft.au=Schubart%2C+Jane+R%3BMitchell%2C+Alex+J%3BDietrich%2C+Laura%3BGusani%2C+Niraj+J&amp;rft.aulast=Schubart&amp;rft.aufirst=Jane&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.977415

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Accuracy+of+the+Emotion+Thermometers+%28ET%29+Screening+Tool+in+Patients+Undergoing+Surgery+for+Upper+Gastrointestinal+Malignancies&amp;rft.au=Schubart%2C+Jane+R%3BMitchell%2C+Alex+J%3BDietrich%2C+Laura%3BGusani%2C+Niraj+J&amp;rft.aulast=Schubart&amp;rft.aufirst=Jane&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.977415

Screening for Psychosocial Distress: A National Survey of Oncology Social Workers

Author: BrintzenhofeSzoc, Karlynn1; Davis, Cindy; Kayser, Karen; Lee, Hee Yun; Nedjat-Haiem, Frances; Oktay, Julianne S; Zabora, James; Zebrack, Bradley J1 National Catholic School of Social Service, Catholic University of America, Washington, DC, USA

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 33, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 34-47.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692283342?accountid=14667

Abstract: Oncology social workers are the primary providers of psychosocial care for cancer patients, thus they are well positioned to implement and oversee psychosocial distress screening. A national survey of members of the Association of Oncology Social Work was conducted to examine screening knowledge, attitudes, behaviors, and perceived competency. The findings indicated that most participants screened for psychosocial distress using a standardized instrument and identified institutional and individual barriers to implementing screening. Analyses revealed that social workers who perceived patient benefits from screening and were knowledgeable about guidelines were significantly more likely to implement screening procedures and use a standardized instrument. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Screening+for+Psychosocial+Distress%3A+A+National+Survey+of+Oncology+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=BrintzenhofeSzoc%2C+Karlynn%3BDavis%2C+Cindy%3BKayser%2C+Karen%3BLee%2C+Hee+Yun%3BNedjat-Haiem%2C+Frances%3BOktay%2C+Julianne+S%3BZabora%2C+James%3BZebrack%2C+Bradley+J&amp;rft.aulast=BrintzenhofeSzoc&amp;rft.aufirst=Karlynn&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=34&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.977416

Mindful Caring: Using Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy With Caregivers of Cancer Survivors

Author: Wood, Andrew W1; Gonzalez, Jessica; Barden, Sejal M1 Department of Child, Family, and Community Sciences, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, USA

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 33, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 66-84.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692283353?accountid=14667

Abstract: Caregivers of cancer survivors face many burdens that often require treatment by mental health professionals. One intervention, mindfulness-based cognitive therapy, aims to help individuals change the ways in which they relate to their thoughts rather than changing their thoughts. In this manuscript, we discuss the use and adaption of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy with caregivers of cancer survivors as a way to decrease caregiver burden and increase caregiver quality of life. A session-by-session breakdown of how to tailor mindfulness-based cognitive therapy to caregivers of cancer survivors is provided. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

What Explains the Intention to Be Physically Active in Cancer Patients? Different Determinants for Active and Insufficiently Active Patients

Author: Ungar, Nadine1; Sieverding, Monika; Ulrich, Cornelia M; Wiskemann, Joachim1 Institute of Psychology, University of Heidelberg, Heidelberg, Germany; Division of Preventive Oncology, National Center for Tumor Diseases and German Cancer Research Center, Heidelberg, Germany

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 33, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 15-33.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284530?accountid=14667

Abstract: In a qualitative elicitation study with 61 cancer patients, a broad range of attitudes toward physical activity could be obtained, especially negative attitudes among insufficiently active patients. Based on these results, a second quantitative study was conducted; 64 patients [40 men; 42% insufficiently active (<150 minutes/week)] completed a Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) questionnaire. Regression analyses revealed that different variables of the TPB are relevant for explaining the intention to exercise for physically active (subjective norm) and insufficiently active (attitudes) cancer patients. Health professionals should adapt their support to the special needs of insufficiently active and active cancer patients. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=What+Explains+the+Intention+to+Be+Physically+Active+in+Cancer+Patients%3F+Different+Determinants+for+Active+and+Insufficiently+Active+Patients&amp;rft.au=Ungar%2C+Nadine%3BSieverding%2C+Monika%3BUlrich%2C+Cornelia+M%3BWiskemann%2C+Joachim&amp;rft.aulast=Ungar&amp;rft.aufirst=Nadine&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=15&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.977417

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=What+Explains+the+Intention+to+Be+Physically+Active+in+Cancer+Patients%3F+Different+Determinants+for+Active+and+Insufficiently+Active+Patients&amp;rft.au=Ungar%2C+Nadine%3BSieverding%2C+Monika%3BUlrich%2C+Cornelia+M%3BWiskemann%2C+Joachim&amp;rft.aulast=Ungar&amp;rft.aufirst=Nadine&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=15&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.977417

____________________________________________________________

What Women Think: Cancer Causal Attributions in a Diverse Sample of Women

Author: Rodriguez, Vivian M1; Gyure, Maria E; Corona, Rosalie; Bodurtha, Joann N; Bowen, Deborah J; Quillin, John M1 Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY, USA

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology  Vol. 33, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 48-65.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284553?accountid=14667

Abstract: Women hold diverse beliefs about cancer etiology, potentially affecting their use of cancer preventive behaviors. Research has primarily focused on cancer causal attributions survivors and participants from non-diverse backgrounds hold. Less is known about attributions held by women with and without a family history of cancer from a diverse community sample. Participants reported factors they believed cause cancer. Open-ended responses were coded and relations between the top causal attributions and key factors were explored. Findings suggest certain socio-cultural factors play a role in the causal attributions women make about cancer, which can, in turn, inform cancer awareness and prevention messages. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=What+Women+Think%3A+Cancer+Causal+Attributions+in+a+Diverse+Sample+of+Women&amp;rft.au=Rodriguez%2C+Vivian+M%3BGyure%2C+Maria+E%3BCorona%2C+Rosalie%3BBodurtha%2C+Joann+N%3BBowen%2C+Deborah+J%3BQuillin%2C+John+M&amp;rft.aulast=Rodriguez&amp;rft.aufirst=Vivian&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=48&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F07347332.2014.977419

The Motivation and Persuasion Process (MAP): Proposing a Practice Model for Community Intervention

Author: Hoefer, Richard1; Chigbu, Kingsley1 School of Social Work, University of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, TX, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice  Vol. 23, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 51-75.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993020?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article proposes a new model of community intervention called the Motivation and Persuasion Process (MAP), a community intervention model to equip community members with specific skills on how to engage in productive community advocacy. This article describes the principles behind the MAP, its objectives, and its application. Implications for community practice, policy advocacy, and research are addressed. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Meditative Dialogue: Cultivating the Transformative Theater of Psychotherapy

Author: Lord, Susan11 Department of Social Work, University of New Hampshire, Durham, New Hampshire, USA

Publication info: Psychoanalytic Social Work  Vol. 22, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 71-87.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993078?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article offers a selective review of literature on the use of improvisation and play to promote 'the bursting forth from the unknown in the moment' (Kindler, 2010, p. 224) in what I term the 'theater of psychotherapy.' It presents an innovative Meditative Dialogue process through which clients and their therapists are able to cultivate and access this 'theater' as they co-create creative spaces in which transformative experiences are accessible. A brief vignette offers an illustration of how the Meditative Dialogue process helps to develop intimacy, presence, and focus through a collaborative positioning of curiosity, openness, and enlivenment in the therapeutic relationship. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Meditative+Dialogue%3A+Cultivating+the+Transformative+Theater+of+Psychotherapy&amp;rft.au=Lord%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Lord&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=22&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2013.877395

____________________________________________________________

Conscious and Unconscious Use of Self: The Evolution of a Process

Author: Schneider, Dana A1; Grady, Melissa D1 Department of Social Work, Southern Connecticut State University, New Haven, Connecticut, USA

Publication info: Psychoanalytic Social Work  Vol. 22, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 52-70.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993097?accountid=14667

Abstract: Recent emphasis has been placed on the central role of the therapeutic relationship in successful treatment. One aspect of the development of an effective relationship is the clinical social worker's use of self. We argue that the use of self happens both consciously and unconsciously and is a dynamic and evolving process in psychotherapy. This evolution can result in the clinical social worker shifting from a stance of doing to being. Drawing from a Japanese tradition of learning, three stages of learning provide a framework for understanding how therapists may transition from a state of doing to being in the therapy. Through this process, the conscious use of self may develop into unconscious use of self. Two case examples demonstrate how expanding and using one's self-awareness and the new knowledge through meaningful learning experiences can shift a clinical social worker's ability to develop and enhance his or her use of self, inviting therapeutic presence and depth. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Conscious+and+Unconscious+Use+of+Self%3A+The+Evolution+of+a+Process&amp;rft.au=Schneider%2C+Dana+A%3BGrady%2C+Melissa+D&amp;rft.aulast=Schneider&amp;rft.aufirst=Dana&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=22&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=52&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2013.869177

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Conscious+and+Unconscious+Use+of+Self%3A+The+Evolution+of+a+Process&amp;rft.au=Schneider%2C+Dana+A%3BGrady%2C+Melissa+D&amp;rft.aulast=Schneider&amp;rft.aufirst=Dana&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=22&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=52&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2013.869177

On Unrequited Love: Mastery, Submission, and Transcendence

Author: Ringel, Shoshana11 School of Social Work, University of Maryland, Baltimore, Maryland, USA

Publication info: Psychoanalytic Social Work  Vol. 22, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 12-22.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993107?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines a sexual relationship based on mastery and submission through the lens of hunger, shame, abjection, and ecstasy. The author examines the dissociative process in which shameful and unwanted aspects of the self are projected onto the other, and explores the possibility of transcending dichotomized self states through mutual surrender. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=On+Unrequited+Love%3A+Mastery%2C+Submission%2C+and+Transcendence&amp;rft.au=Ringel%2C+Shoshana&amp;rft.aulast=Ringel&amp;rft.aufirst=Shoshana&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=22&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=12&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2013.838685

Motivations for Involvement in Nonmetropolitan LGBTQ Organizations: A Multimethod Qualitative Exploration

Author: Paceley, Megan S1; Keene, Lance C; Lough, Benjamin J1 School of Social Work, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Champaign, IL, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice  Vol. 23, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 102-125.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993168?accountid=14667

Abstract: Organizations serving lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) communities provide services aimed at improving the health and well-being of LGBTQ people, yet may face limited resources and community support in nonmetropolitan communities. This study seeks to understand LGBTQ individuals' motivations for becoming and staying involved in nonmetropolitan LGBTQ organizations. Data collection methods included interviews, participant observation, and focus groups. Six categories of motivations emerged: (1) to access support and resources; (2) to establish an LGBTQ community; (3) to be generative; (4) to affirm identity; (5) to support an LGBTQ organization; and (6) to combine one's personal and professional lives. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Motivations+for+Involvement+in+Nonmetropolitan+LGBTQ+Organizations%3A+A+Multimethod+Qualitative+Exploration&amp;rft.au=Paceley%2C+Megan+S%3BKeene%2C+Lance+C%3BLough%2C+Benjamin+J&amp;rft.aulast=Paceley&amp;rft.aufirst=Megan&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=102&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2014.985412

Healthcare Experiences of Latinos in a Nontraditional Destination Area

Author: Jacquez, Farrah1; Vaughn, Lisa M; Pelley, Terri; Topmiller, Michael1 Department of Psychology, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice  Vol. 23, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 76-101.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993198?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to describe the health and healthcare experiences of immigrant Latinos compared to USA-born Latinos, Whites, and African Americans in Greater Cincinnati, Ohio, a nontraditional immigrant destination area. Immigrant Latinos had significantly worse physical and mental health than other groups and significantly more barriers to healthcare. Latinos rated the degree to which their town is socially accepting of Latinos. Lower social acceptance was correlated with worse mental health and more barriers to healthcare. Geographic information system (GIS) mapping techniques revealed geographic patterns in the association between social acceptance of Latinos and health outcomes. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Healthcare+Experiences+of+Latinos+in+a+Nontraditional+Destination+Area&amp;rft.au=Jacquez%2C+Farrah%3BVaughn%2C+Lisa+M%3BPelley%2C+Terri%3BTopmiller%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Jacquez&amp;rft.aufirst=Farrah&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=76&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2014.983629

____________________________________________________________

Toward a Conceptual Framework for Understanding Community Belonging and Well-Being: Insights from a Queer-Mixed Perspective

Author: Hudson, Kimberly D11 School of Social Work, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice  Vol. 23, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 27-50.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993298?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although previous research indicates a positive relationship between community belonging and well-being, little is known about how this relationship is experienced within diverse communities. In this study, interviews were conducted with 12 queer-mixed-identified individuals. Proposed is a conceptual framework for understanding how and why experiences of community belonging contribute to and detract from well-being. Specifically, the dimensions being close, being read, being seen, and being heard are explored through participants' intersectional and often-contradictory narratives. This study may enhance scholarship regarding lived experiences of community; research and practice related to multiracial, queer, and trans* experiences; and community efforts to promote well-being. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Toward+a+Conceptual+Framework+for+Understanding+Community+Belonging+and+Well-Being%3A+Insights+from+a+Queer-Mixed+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Hudson%2C+Kimberly+D&amp;rft.aulast=Hudson&amp;rft.aufirst=Kimberly&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2014.986595

____________________________________________________________

An Exile in the Room: A Clinical Illustration and a Literary Footnote

Author: Alfandary, Rony11 School of Social Work, Bar Ilan University, Ramat Gan, Israel

Publication info: Psychoanalytic Social Work  Vol. 22, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 23-38.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993350?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article, I describe the case of Dan, an Israeli citizen in his late thirties, born and bred in Argentina. I focus upon some psychological effects of exile as played out and repeated in the transference, leading to an instance of an articulation of his human idiom (Bollas, 1989). During the course of his therapy, through the working of elements in the transference paradigm, it became possible that Dan's existential gloom and despair, accompanied by various physical symptoms, were the traces of the imprints of his exile from Argentine. Those traces were linked to the articulation of deeply buried sensations and once recognized allowed him to explore instances of unresolved mourning. The mourning process thus resumed and allowed him to regain his positive outlook. In conjunction with this, I describe the impact that Julio Cortazar's (1914-1984) posthumously published book, Diary of Andres Fava (2005), had upon him. The reading of that book served Dan and me as an unconscious object. This object could be represented by Ogden's (2004) term The Analytical Third, and was a part of the therapeutic relationship where he was able to discover, express, and elaborate upon his unique idiomatic sense of self. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=An+Exile+in+the+Room%3A+A+Clinical+Illustration+and+a+Literary+Footnote&amp;rft.au=Alfandary%2C+Rony&amp;rft.aulast=Alfandary&amp;rft.aufirst=Rony&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=22&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2013.846225

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=An+Exile+in+the+Room%3A+A+Clinical+Illustration+and+a+Literary+Footnote&amp;rft.au=Alfandary%2C+Rony&amp;rft.aulast=Alfandary&amp;rft.aufirst=Rony&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=22&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Psychoanalytic+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15228878&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15228878.2013.846225

'We're Who We've Been Waiting For': Intergenerational Community Organizing for a Healthy Community

Author: Kang, Hye-Kyung11 Smith College School for Social Work, Northampton, MA, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice  Vol. 23, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 126-140.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993400?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study, guided by principles of community-based participatory research (CBPR), presents the processes, challenges, and effects of intergenerational community organizing practice of a local grassroots organization to promote community health in multiracial and historically marginalized communities. Three major lessons emerged: (1) the central role of experiential communal learning and critical analysis in collective knowledge creation, (2) development of collective efficacy through a genuine sense of connection and mutual affirmation, and 3) the importance of a co-learner stance in fostering intergenerational leadership. The interconnection between process and product is emphasized as the central tenet in both community organizing and CBPR processes. Adapted from the source document.

Practices of Engagement: Comparing and Integrating Deliberation and Organizing

Author: Rusch, Lara1; Swarts, Heidi1 Political Science, University of Michigan-Dearborn, Dearborn, MI, USA

Publication info: Journal of Community Practice  Vol. 23, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 5-26.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993493?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this article is to provide a comparison of institution-based community organizing and deliberative practices and to demonstrate how these are complementary approaches for civic engagement. In contrast to older typologies describing these two approaches oppositionally, we seek to reveal a shared democratic ethos and propose greater collaboration between action-oriented organizers and deliberative advocates. The article also identifies where deliberative and organizing practices diverge and proposes a model for how the two approaches can be integrated for mutual benefit. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Practices+of+Engagement%3A+Comparing+and+Integrating+Deliberation+and+Organizing&amp;rft.au=Rusch%2C+Lara%3BSwarts%2C+Heidi&amp;rft.aulast=Rusch&amp;rft.aufirst=Lara&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Community+Practice&amp;rft.issn=10705422&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10705422.2014.985411

Title: Practices of Engagement: Comparing and Integrating Deliberation and Organizing

Volume: 23

Publication year: 2015

Publisher: Taylor & Francis, Philadelphia PA

Shrinking Religious Communities and Thriving Interreligious Social Work in Postsecular Sweden

Author: Garde, Johan11 Department of Social Sciences, Ersta Skondal University College, Stockholm, Sweden

Publication info: Journal of Religion & Spirituality in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 1-23.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761687936?accountid=14667

Abstract: Sweden is considered to be one of the most secular countries when measuring items such as church service attendance, expressed beliefs in God, and agreement with statements such as 'religion is an important part of life,' compared to other countries in Europe and elsewhere. Official church attendance in major church congregations, such as the Church of Sweden and most other Protestant Free Churches, has shown a pattern of decrease in membership in modern times, with some congregations risking to disappear as a result. New configurations of social work practice are challenging current congregations with crossover-interfaith schemes, shared buildings, and community-oriented services with a field presence in marginalized urban areas, replacing homogeneous and diaconal or charitable work. Three cases of interreligious social work are analyzed, and in particular the social and religious leadership skills required for collaboration between the religious communities as well as the surrounding society. The interreligious social work practice is also an important factor of social service provision in the concerned local communities and has strengthened the role of religion in the social sphere in what can be expressed as a postsecular Sweden. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Religion+%26+Spirituality+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Shrinking+Religious+Communities+and+Thriving+Interreligious+Social+Work+in+Postsecular+Sweden&amp;rft.au=Garde%2C+Johan&amp;rft.aulast=Garde&amp;rft.aufirst=Johan&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=1&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Religion+%26+Spirituality+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15426432&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15426432.2014.921129

Student Attitudes Toward Religious Diversity and Implications for Multicultural Competence

Author: Abell, Melissa L1; Manuel, Jennifer; Schoeneman, Andrew1 School of Social Work, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, Virginia

Publication info: Journal of Religion & Spirituality in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 91-104.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761688002?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article we present the findings from a survey of Master of Social Work (MSW) students regarding their attitudes toward religion in social work practice and their feelings of competence when working with clients who are Muslim. Our findings indicated that some students are uncomfortable working with Muslim groups. Interestingly, those students who are minority and non-Christian appear to identify with other oppressed groups and expressed attitudes of greater comfort and tolerance than their White and Christian counterparts. This suggests a need for a more comprehensive view of multicultural practice in social work education perhaps with a focus on cultural humility. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Religion+%26+Spirituality+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Student+Attitudes+Toward+Religious+Diversity+and+Implications+for+Multicultural+Competence&amp;rft.au=Abell%2C+Melissa+L%3BManuel%2C+Jennifer%3BSchoeneman%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Abell&amp;rft.aufirst=Melissa&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Religion+%26+Spirituality+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15426432&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15426432.2014.943920

Applying the Buddhist Four Immeasurables to Mental Health Care: A Critical Review

Author: Cheng, Fung Kei1; Tse, Samson1 Department of Social Work and Social Administration, Faculty of Social Sciences, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China

Publication info: Journal of Religion & Spirituality in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 24-50.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761688006?accountid=14667

Abstract: With the advent of the use of Buddhist teachings in therapy, including the four immeasurables (loving-kindness, compassion, empathetic joy, and equanimity), mental health scholars have achieved encouraging results. This critical review analyses 16 empirical studies on this theory with regard to their relation to mental health care, focusing on compassion-focused approaches, programs for caring professionals, and a psychometric instrument. The data displayed positive indicators in this new research theme; however, many results are tentative due to small sample sizes, or nonrandomized design, and so further investigation is needed. Moreover, existing studies have largely emphasized compassion, which undermines the effectiveness of the four premises as a whole, along with their interplay for therapeutic purposes. Thus, suggestions for future research are proposed here. Adapted from the source document.

Socioeconomic Human Well-Being and Posterity: A Newly Proposed Faith-Based Measurement Index

Author: Khan, Zahoor1; Sulaiman, Jamalludin; Bahari, Zakaria1 School of Social Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Penang, Malaysia

Publication info: Journal of Religion & Spirituality in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 72-90.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761688031?accountid=14667

Abstract: Faith-based socioeconomic development is imperative for sustainable human and material development. The ultimate goal of socioeconomic progress, in the light of Maqasid al Shariah, may provide a comprehensive framework and a way to benchmark human progress on a wider socioeconomic scale. This study aims to provide insights about one of the components of the Maqasid al Shariah such as posterity; to develop an index to measure the level of development of future generations in terms of sociohealth and eco-environmental aspects. The index is named as 'Posterity Development Index (PDI).' The PDI is based on various posterity dimensions developed by Chapra, Khan, and Al Shaikh-Ali (2008). These dimensions are namely proper upbringings of children, their health, education, and eco-environmental protection. The PDI reveals information about socioeconomic human well-being based on the selected indicators to measure and monitor human well-being of the next generation across the different periods and across the different nations. Conceptualization and measurement of posterity as a faith-based socioeconomic development instrument has valuable policy implications. Notwithstanding the limitations of the study, it may contribute to the existing field of knowledge and help in designing an optimal global development agenda for the world in general and believers in divine injections in particular. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Religion+%26+Spirituality+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Socioeconomic+Human+Well-Being+and+Posterity%3A+A+Newly+Proposed+Faith-Based+Measurement+Index&amp;rft.au=Khan%2C+Zahoor%3BSulaiman%2C+Jamalludin%3BBahari%2C+Zakaria&amp;rft.aulast=Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Zahoor&amp;rft.date=2015-01-02&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=72&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Religion+%26+Spirituality+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15426432&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F15426432.2014.955244

Religiosity as an Identity: Young Arab Muslim Women in the United States and France

Author: Zimmerman, Danielle Dunand11 School of Social Work, Loyola University Chicago, Chicago, Illinois

Publication info: Journal of Religion & Spirituality in Social Work  Vol. 34, Iss. 1,  (January 2, 2015): 51-71.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761688042?accountid=14667

Abstract: Young Arab Muslim women who are religious are particularly challenged by hostility toward Muslims in the United States' and France's secular societies. They feel Muslim first but are not recognized as religious citizens and their personal quest for religious identity faces both stereotypical assumptions from non-Muslims and expectations from their own community. The current study, conducted in the United States and France, shows that as religion is central to their identity negotiation process, young Arab women who are religious Muslims struggle to express who they feel they are, as citizens of their country of residence as well as members of an ethnic and religious minority. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Intimate partner violence and women's experiences of grief

Author: Messing, Jill Theresa; Mohr, Rebeca; Durfee, Alesha

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 1,  (Feb 2015): 30-39.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1643101265?accountid=14667

Abstract: A greater understanding of women's emotional and behavioural responses to intimate partner violence (IPV) may be aided by an examination of the grief course. Women going through the process of leaving their abusers, like women leaving non-violent partners, experience grief during and at the termination of their relationship, even if they feel relief at the cessation of violence. Through qualitative interviews with 14 female survivors of IPV, we critically examine the utility of Kubler-Ross' grief model to understand how women come to terms with their experiences of violence and the end of their violent relationships. Results suggest that Kubler-Ross' model helps explain the emotional reactions and decision-making of IPV survivors in regard to staying, leaving and returning to their partners. While a model developed to explain grief due to death may not entirely explain the reactions of IPV survivors going through the process of leaving abusive partners, and does not account for psychological reactions to trauma, social workers and mental-health professionals can use this grief model as a framework to better tailor services to survivors of IPV.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Intimate+partner+violence+and+women%27s+experiences+of+grief&amp;rft.au=Messing%2C+Jill+Theresa%3BMohr%2C+Rebeca%3BDurfee%2C+Alesha&amp;rft.aulast=Messing&amp;rft.aufirst=Jill&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=30&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12051

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Intimate+partner+violence+and+women%27s+experiences+of+grief&amp;rft.au=Messing%2C+Jill+Theresa%3BMohr%2C+Rebeca%3BDurfee%2C+Alesha&amp;rft.aulast=Messing&amp;rft.aufirst=Jill&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=30&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12051

Intergenerational pathways leading to foster care placement of foster care alumni's children

Author: Jackson Foster, Lovie J; Beadnell, Blair; Pecora, Peter J

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 1,  (Feb 2015): 72-82.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1643101320?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined a path model that postulated intergenerational relationships between biological parent psychosocial functioning and foster care alumni mental health, economic status and social support; and from these to the likelihood of children of foster care alumni being placed in foster care. The sample included 742 adults who spent time in foster care as children with a private foster care agency and who reported having at least one biological child. A full pathway was found between poorer father's functioning to greater alumni depression, which was in turn associated with negative social support, and then a greater likelihood of child out-of-home placement. Other parent to alumni paths were that poorer father functioning was associated with alumni anxiety and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and poorer mother's mental health was associated with PTSD; however, anxiety and PTSD were not implicated as precursors of foster care placement of the child. Findings support the need for increased practice and policy support to address the mental health needs of parents of children in or at risk of foster care, as well as the children themselves, as family history may have a lasting influence on quality of life, even when children are raised apart from biological parents.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Intergenerational+pathways+leading+to+foster+care+placement+of+foster+care+alumni%27s+children&amp;rft.au=Jackson+Foster%2C+Lovie+J%3BBeadnell%2C+Blair%3BPecora%2C+Peter+J&amp;rft.aulast=Jackson+Foster&amp;rft.aufirst=Lovie&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=72&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12057

Early intervention and holistic, relationship-based practice with fathers: evidence from the work of the Family Nurse Partnership

Author: Ferguson, Harry; Gates, Peter

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 1,  (Feb 2015): 96-105.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1643102464?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper seeks to add to the literature on working with fathers by focusing on early intervention. It draws on research into fathers involved in a home visitation service delivered by the Family Nurse Partnership in England and evaluates the men's experiences of the intervention. The vulnerability of fathers was striking and many were helped to develop their practical skills and confidence in caring for their babies. The intervention was effective because of the quality time that was invested in developing relationships with fathers (as well as mothers), the focus on their strengths as well as areas for improvement and the skilled, therapeutically oriented, holistic approach through which the service was delivered. The 'early' nature of the help was crucial to its success because of how it so effectively tapped into the men's redefinition of themselves as caring fathers during pregnancy and following the birth. We argue that there is important learning here for social care and health services in general about how to engage men and promote fathers' capacities to care for their children.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Early+intervention+and+holistic%2C+relationship-based+practice+with+fathers%3A+evidence+from+the+work+of+the+Family+Nurse+Partnership&amp;rft.au=Ferguson%2C+Harry%3BGates%2C+Peter&amp;rft.aulast=Ferguson&amp;rft.aufirst=Harry&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=96&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12059

____________________________________________________________

Origins and rationale of centres for parents and young children together

Author: Hoshi-Watanabe, Miwako; Musatti, Tullia; Rayna, Sylvie; Vandenbroeck, Michel

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 1,  (Feb 2015): 62-71.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1643102484?accountid=14667

Abstract: The range of centres where parents and children come together has mushroomed in different parts of the world, as new social work practices address the emerging non-material needs of parents in changing demographic contexts. In this paper, we explore the origins and modi operandi of these centres in Belgium, France, Italy and Japan. Analysis of previous studies and policy documents reveal diverse political rationales, including addressing declining birth rates, preventing psychosocial problems and social isolation of mothers and promoting social cohesion and equality of educational opportunities. Remarkably, despite the diverse cultural and socio-political contexts and rationales, these centres also share very similar ways of functioning and provide an informal type of social support to parents with young children. As these recently emerged centres are seldom studied, further research is welcomed to explore parents' and professionals' perspectives.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Origins+and+rationale+of+centres+for+parents+and+young+children+together&amp;rft.au=Hoshi-Watanabe%2C+Miwako%3BMusatti%2C+Tullia%3BRayna%2C+Sylvie%3BVandenbroeck%2C+Michel&amp;rft.aulast=Hoshi-Watanabe&amp;rft.aufirst=Miwako&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=62&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12056

A Comprehensive Conceptual Program Model for Supporting Families Surviving a Homicide Victim

Author: Vincent, Neil J1; McCormack, Joy; Johnson, Susan1 Department of Social Work, DePaul University, 14 E. Jackson Ave, Chicago, IL, 60604, USA

Publication info: Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal  Vol. 32, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 57-64.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680149030?accountid=14667

Abstract: The homicide of a loved one is a devastating event for families. Adult and youth survivors struggle with posttraumatic stress, complicated grief, isolation, and stigma. Existing programs serving survivors of homicide victims offer needed services, but a comprehensive program is lacking. Based on an analysis of existing programs in the United States, a literature review, and the authors' practice experience, this paper presents a comprehensive, conceptual practice model for supporting survivors of homicide victims. The program model consists of the following components: Counseling/Therapeutic Services; Case Management Services; Advocacy Services; Education/Training; Community of Survivors; and a Website/Hotline. Implications for social work practice and directions for future research are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=A+Comprehensive+Conceptual+Program+Model+for+Supporting+Families+Surviving+a+Homicide+Victim&amp;rft.au=Vincent%2C+Neil+J%3BMcCormack%2C+Joy%3BJohnson%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Vincent&amp;rft.aufirst=Neil&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=57&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-014-0362-4

Promoting Resilience Among Maltreated Youth Using Meditation, Yoga, Tai Chi and Qigong: A Scoping Review of the Literature

Author: Waechter, Randall L1; Wekerle, Christine1 Windward Islands Research and Education Foundation (WINDREF) & Department of Bioethics, School of Medicine, St. George's University, P.O. Box 7, St. Georges, Grenada, West Indies

Publication info: Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal  Vol. 32, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 17-31.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680149093?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examining factors that support resilience is critical to ameliorating the impact of child maltreatment. This paper evaluated existing evidence for the effects of 'Eastern Arts' (i.e., meditation, yoga, tai chi, qigong) on resilience (i.e., positive health and socioeconomic outcomes) among maltreated youth. Using a scoping review framework as outlined by Arksey and O'Malley (Int J Soc Res Methodol 8:19-32, 2005), we searched through five peer-reviewed databases, limiting the search to English-language articles, with no limit on time frame of publication. We then used pre-specified six-point inclusion/exclusion criteria to select journal articles for review. The initial literature search returned 330 articles, eight of which met the criteria and were selected for further review. All but one of the studies showed some improvement in the targeted dependent variable for the Eastern Arts intervention group versus the control group/pre-post intervention. Though the number of articles examining Eastern Arts interventions is extremely limited, the majority of studies included in this review showed an improvement in the targeted health outcome. Given the strong theoretical background, positive (though limited) research outcomes, and minimal side effects, further examination of the Eastern Arts for supporting resilience among maltreated youth, and use in the child welfare context, is warranted. Adapted from the source document.

Umoja: A Culturally Specific Approach to Mentoring Young African American Males

Author: Watson, Jerry1; Washington, Gregory; Stepteau-Watson, Desiree1 Jackson State University, 3825 Ridgewood Road, Jackson, MS, 39211, USA jwatson2@olemiss.edu

Publication info: Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal  Vol. 32, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 81-90.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680149095?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports that urban inner-city African American male youth residing in communities of color are at-risk and warrant interventions custom tailored to meet their unique cultural needs. This article describes a promising community and school-based intervention and prevention program utilizing Washington's (J Soc Work Gr 2006:14, 2007) pyramid mentoring model designed to foster the positive development of this group, prevent violence, and to reduce contacts with the juvenile and criminal justice system. It discusses and presents African drumming, Spir-rhythms as a Afrocentric cultural arts tool to engage, establish rapport, and provide pyramid group mentoring experiences for African American male youth. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Umoja%3A+A+Culturally+Specific+Approach+to+Mentoring+Young+African+American+Males&amp;rft.au=Watson%2C+Jerry%3BWashington%2C+Gregory%3BStepteau-Watson%2C+Desiree&amp;rft.aulast=Watson&amp;rft.aufirst=Jerry&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=81&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-014-0367-z

The Truth N' Trauma Project: Addressing Community Violence Through a Youth-Led, Trauma-Informed and Restorative Framework

Author: Harden, Troy1; Kenemore, Thomas; Mann, Kimberly; Edwards, Michael; List, Christine; Martinson, Karen Jean1 Master of Social Work Program, Chicago State University, Chicago, IL, USA

Publication info: Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal  Vol. 32, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 65-79.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680150333?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes the implementation and evaluation of a youth violence prevention and intervention program on Chicago's south side. Forty-four high school-age youth from violence-exposed urban communities participated in a nine-month, multidisciplinary, after-school program aimed at supporting their development and positively impacting their communities. Restorative practice principles informed planning, implementation, and evaluation of the program. The youth developed skills in leadership, trauma-informed practice, documentary production, theatre, and participatory action research. This paper discusses the program, an initial evaluation of its impact, and potential practice and research implications. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=The+Truth+N%27+Trauma+Project%3A+Addressing+Community+Violence+Through+a+Youth-Led%2C+Trauma-Informed+and+Restorative+Framework&amp;rft.au=Harden%2C+Troy%3BKenemore%2C+Thomas%3BMann%2C+Kimberly%3BEdwards%2C+Michael%3BList%2C+Christine%3BMartinson%2C+Karen+Jean&amp;rft.aulast=Harden&amp;rft.aufirst=Troy&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=65&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-014-0366-0

Connection Between Adolescent's Exposure to Community Violence and Future Civic Engagement Behaviors During Their Young Adulthood

Author: Chen, Wan-Yi1; Propp, Jennifer; Lee, Yookyong1 Graduate Social Work Department, West Chester University, Reynolds Hall, West Chester, PA, 19383, USA wchen@wcupa.edu

Publication info: Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal  Vol. 32, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 45-55.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680150547?accountid=14667

Abstract: With a sample of 10,298 individuals who participated in three waves of interviews from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health conducted between 1994 and 2002, this study examines how exposure to community violence during adolescence could affect individual's subsequent engagement in civic activities during their young adulthood. Exposure to violence in the community during adolescence decreased the likelihood for a young adult to participate in volunteering for community services. A positive parent-child relationship would promote the likelihood for individual's civic engagement during young adulthood but there was no significant buffering effect from such relationship against the negative influence from violence exposure on young adults' civic engagement. Implications for practice and future research are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Connection+Between+Adolescent%27s+Exposure+to+Community+Violence+and+Future+Civic+Engagement+Behaviors+During+Their+Young+Adulthood&amp;rft.au=Chen%2C+Wan-Yi%3BPropp%2C+Jennifer%3BLee%2C+Yookyong&amp;rft.aulast=Chen&amp;rft.aufirst=Wan-Yi&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-014-0361-5

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Connection+Between+Adolescent%27s+Exposure+to+Community+Violence+and+Future+Civic+Engagement+Behaviors+During+Their+Young+Adulthood&amp;rft.au=Chen%2C+Wan-Yi%3BPropp%2C+Jennifer%3BLee%2C+Yookyong&amp;rft.aulast=Chen&amp;rft.aufirst=Wan-Yi&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-014-0361-5

Utilization of Photovoice to Explore Hope and Spirituality Among Low-Income African American Adolescents

Author: Harley, Dana1; Hunn, Vanessa1 Department of Counseling, Social Work, and Leadership, College of Education and Human Resources, Northern Kentucky University, BEP Center 222F, Nunn Drive, Highland Heights, KY, 41099, USA harleyd1@nku.edu

Publication info: Child and Adolescent Social Work Journal  Vol. 32, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 3-15.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1680150559?accountid=14667

Abstract: Spirituality has been identified in the literature as a protective mechanism for promoting hope among African American adolescents. However, few studies have examined the perceptions of hope and spirituality from the viewpoint of African American adolescents. This study explores the perceptions of hope and spirituality among low-income African American adolescents through photovoice methodology and in-depth interviews. Sixteen (n = 16) African American adolescents of ages 13-17 participated in this study. Results of the study broaden the construct of hope to include spirituality as a source of protection in dangerous environments. Implications are made for social workers and other professionals working with African American adolescents and their families. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=Utilization+of+Photovoice+to+Explore+Hope+and+Spirituality+Among+Low-Income+African+American+Adolescents&amp;rft.au=Harley%2C+Dana%3BHunn%2C+Vanessa&amp;rft.aulast=Harley&amp;rft.aufirst=Dana&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=3&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Adolescent+Social+Work+Journal&amp;rft.issn=07380151&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1007%2Fs10560-014-0354-4

The Importance of Place in the Life and Career of a Social Work Pioneer: Insights From Interviews With Hortense King McClinton

Author: Carlton-LaNey, Iris11 School of Social Work, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, NC, USA ibc9717@email.unc.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 30, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 117-129.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692284757?accountid=14667

Abstract: This column explores the importance of place in the life of social work pioneer Hortense McClinton. McClinton's story is underscored by the centrality of place, especially her all-black hometown. McClinton's insights were garnered through interviews and unprecedented access to McClinton's personal archives. McClinton's words explicate the role place plays in shaping values, character, and behavior. Her story exemplifies strength and endurance during times when women and African Americans had staunchly circumscribed roles and limited access to social involvement and resources. This article illustrates the intersection of multiple factors that shaped her life, her career, and her contribution to social work. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Importance+of+Place+in+the+Life+and+Career+of+a+Social+Work+Pioneer%3A+Insights+From+Interviews+With+Hortense+King+McClinton&amp;rft.au=Carlton-LaNey%2C+Iris&amp;rft.aulast=Carlton-LaNey&amp;rft.aufirst=Iris&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=117&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914546127

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Importance+of+Place+in+the+Life+and+Career+of+a+Social+Work+Pioneer%3A+Insights+From+Interviews+With+Hortense+King+McClinton&amp;rft.au=Carlton-LaNey%2C+Iris&amp;rft.aulast=Carlton-LaNey&amp;rft.aufirst=Iris&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=117&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914546127

Voice and Community in the Corporate Academy: A Collective Biography

Author: O'Connor, Mary Katherine1; Netting, F Ellen; Cole, Portia L; Hopkins, Karen; Jones, Jenny L; Kim, Youngmi; Leisey, Monica; Mulroy, Elizabeth A; Rotabi, Karen Smith; Thomas, M Lori; Weil, Marie O; Wike, Traci L1 School of Social Work, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, VA, USA

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 30, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 9-25.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285294?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is the story of the simultaneous feminization and corporatization of universities, themes that emerged in a test of a collective biography, a qualitative research method. Organizers brought together 12 macro social work academic women across generations and, through sampling, attempted to avoid the intergenerational splitting that seems to be leaving junior faculty to be socialized by administrators while simultaneously isolating senior faculty from their generative role. Our analysis identified several trends developed from our collective experiences including changes in faculty governance, formalized mentoring, intergenerational faculty relationships, and shifting expectations. With these changes, we sense a reduction in what we used to think of as a collegium, now in danger of becoming an historical artifact. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Voice+and+Community+in+the+Corporate+Academy%3A+A+Collective+Biography&amp;rft.au=O%27Connor%2C+Mary+Katherine%3BNetting%2C+F+Ellen%3BCole%2C+Portia+L%3BHopkins%2C+Karen%3BJones%2C+Jenny+L%3BKim%2C+Youngmi%3BLeisey%2C+Monica%3BMulroy%2C+Elizabeth+A%3BRotabi%2C+Karen+Smith%3BThomas%2C+M+Lori%3BWeil%2C+Marie+O%3BWike%2C+Traci+L&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Connor&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914544717

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Voice+and+Community+in+the+Corporate+Academy%3A+A+Collective+Biography&amp;rft.au=O%27Connor%2C+Mary+Katherine%3BNetting%2C+F+Ellen%3BCole%2C+Portia+L%3BHopkins%2C+Karen%3BJones%2C+Jenny+L%3BKim%2C+Youngmi%3BLeisey%2C+Monica%3BMulroy%2C+Elizabeth+A%3BRotabi%2C+Karen+Smith%3BThomas%2C+M+Lori%3BWeil%2C+Marie+O%3BWike%2C+Traci+L&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Connor&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914544717

Feeding Relationships: Foodways and Social Networks in a Women's Prison

Author: Smoyer, Amy B11 Center for Interdisciplinary Research on AIDS, Yale School of Public Health, New Haven, CT, USA amy.smoyer@yale.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 30, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 26-39.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285305?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research has demonstrated the importance of supportive relationships and social networks to prisoners' psychosocial outcomes, especially for women. Understanding how these relationships are constructed, negotiated, and sustained is, therefore, critical for social workers and other professionals who work with incarcerated and formerly incarcerated clients, and/or their family and friends. This article analyzes formerly incarcerated women's narratives about prison foodways, demonstrating the centrality of these systems to prisoners' relationships and building knowledge about everyday inmate interactions with people inside and outside of prison. Research, clinical, and policy recommendations suggest ways prison foodways could be altered to strengthen prisoners' relationships. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Feeding+Relationships%3A+Foodways+and+Social+Networks+in+a+Women%27s+Prison&amp;rft.au=Smoyer%2C+Amy+B&amp;rft.aulast=Smoyer&amp;rft.aufirst=Amy&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=26&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914537490

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Feeding+Relationships%3A+Foodways+and+Social+Networks+in+a+Women%27s+Prison&amp;rft.au=Smoyer%2C+Amy+B&amp;rft.aulast=Smoyer&amp;rft.aufirst=Amy&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=26&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914537490

Honoring Our Intellectual Ancestors: A Feminist of Color Treaty for Creating Allied Collaboration

Author: Beltran, Ramona1; Mehrotra, Gita1 Graduate School of Social Work, University of Denver, Denver, CO, USA ramona.beltran@du.edu

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 30, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 106-116.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285355?accountid=14667

Abstract: There are many unspoken norms in the culture of academia that are subtly communicated and integrated into academic socialization, from the doctoral training process into advanced professional development. The predominance of white, Western, masculine, heteronormative, and (post)positivist norms of academia historically and contemporarily can create challenges for women of color who engage in scholarship that reflects feminist and cultural values. In this article, we briefly explore the complexities affecting feminist of color scholars negotiating such values within the context of academia and particularly in navigating collaborative scholarship. We respond to these obstacles and complexities by providing a treaty of concrete strategies for creating allied, cooperative working relationships across diverse positionalities that honor these values. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Honoring+Our+Intellectual+Ancestors%3A+A+Feminist+of+Color+Treaty+for+Creating+Allied+Collaboration&amp;rft.au=Beltran%2C+Ramona%3BMehrotra%2C+Gita&amp;rft.aulast=Beltran&amp;rft.aufirst=Ramona&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=106&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914531958

Childhood Abuse and Postpartum Psychosis: Is There a Link?

Author: Kennedy, Stephanie C1; Tripodi, Stephen J1 College of Social Work, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL, USA

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 30, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 96-105.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285386?accountid=14667

Abstract: Postpartum psychosis (PPP) is a serious mental health issue associated with maternal suicide and infanticide. Although a growing research base suggests that childhood abuse is predictive of psychosis, bipolar disorder, and postpartum depression, the link between abuse and PPP is less clear. Currently, prevention and treatment strategies are pharmacological and require hospitalization once symptoms arise. Unfortunately, these strategies are not ideal for affected women and their infants. Testing the relationship between experiences of childhood abuse and PPP may reveal abuse variables to be both statistically and clinically meaningful predictors of the disorder. A dose-response model suggests that women who report more severe abuse or multivictimization will be more likely to develop PPP. The authors suggest trauma screening in psychiatric, obstetrical, and community practice settings to identify women at risk for PPP and advocate for the addition of gender-responsive and trauma-focused psychotherapy to pharmacological interventions for this population. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Childhood+Abuse+and+Postpartum+Psychosis%3A+Is+There+a+Link%3F&amp;rft.au=Kennedy%2C+Stephanie+C%3BTripodi%2C+Stephen+J&amp;rft.aulast=Kennedy&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=96&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914544719

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Childhood+Abuse+and+Postpartum+Psychosis%3A+Is+There+a+Link%3F&amp;rft.au=Kennedy%2C+Stephanie+C%3BTripodi%2C+Stephen+J&amp;rft.aulast=Kennedy&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=96&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914544719

Interdisciplinary Team Conflicts Among Forensic Nurses and Rape Victim Advocates

Author: Patterson, Debra1; Pennefather, Megan1 School of Social Work, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI, USA

Publication info: Affilia  Vol. 30, Iss. 1,  (February 2015): 40-53.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1692285451?accountid=14667

Abstract: To address the acute needs of rape survivors, forensic nurses and victim advocates provide integrated holistic care. Research suggests that conflicts between nurses and advocates can be common, but the nature and causes of these conflicts are largely unknown. Utilizing a qualitative case study approach, this study examined how and why an advocate-nurse team experiences conflict. The advocates reported experiences of subordination and disruption of their services, while nurses indicated that the advocates portrayed them negatively and distrusted their professional judgment. Role ambiguity contributed to these conflicts, whereas trust mitigated these conflicts but only existed among experienced nurses and advocates. The findings will be discussed from a feminist organizational lens. [Reprinted by permission of Sage Publications Inc., copyright holder.]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Interdisciplinary+Team+Conflicts+Among+Forensic+Nurses+and+Rape+Victim+Advocates&amp;rft.au=Patterson%2C+Debra%3BPennefather%2C+Megan&amp;rft.aulast=Patterson&amp;rft.aufirst=Debra&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=40&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914531955

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Interdisciplinary+Team+Conflicts+Among+Forensic+Nurses+and+Rape+Victim+Advocates&amp;rft.au=Patterson%2C+Debra%3BPennefather%2C+Megan&amp;rft.aulast=Patterson&amp;rft.aufirst=Debra&amp;rft.date=2015-02-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=40&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1177%2F0886109914531955
