Deprivation, Resilience and Capabilities: An Analysis of Observations and Experiences in Mumbai

Author: Lloyd, Margaret H

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2015): 223.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946468?accountid=14667

Abstract: This essay follows a 14-day study abroad course at the Tata Institute of Social Sciences. Seeking to understand social work practice in Mumbai, this paper describes observations and experiences at three non-governmental organisations and undertakes a capability approach (CA) theoretical analysis. The CA accounts for many features of each case illustration, however, the CA does not fully explain the strengths of people who rose above significant adversity. To reconcile these multiple complexities, a combined approach to capabilities and resilience is offered.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Deprivation%2C+Resilience+and+Capabilities%3A+An+Analysis+of+Observations+and+Experiences+in+Mumbai&amp;rft.au=Lloyd%2C+Margaret+H&amp;rft.aulast=Lloyd&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=223&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Early Warning Systems among the Coastal Fishing Communities in Kerala: A Governmentalty Perspective

Author: Santha, Sunil

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2015): 199.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946473?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores early warning systems from the governmentality perspective. It examines how state issued early warning systems are governmental techniques for exerting control over the population and at the same time used to project an image of a responsible state. The study was carried out among twenty coastal fishing communities in the state of Kerala, India. The findings of this paper reveals that community-based early warning systems need to be contextualised as a struggle between the state and fishing communities, whose outcome depends upon the capacities, tactics and rationality of respective actors to harness knowledge and physical resources.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Early+Warning+Systems+among+the+Coastal+Fishing+Communities+in+Kerala%3A+A+Governmentalty+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Santha%2C+Sunil&amp;rft.aulast=Santha&amp;rft.aufirst=Sunil&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=199&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Ethical Considerations in Researching Sensitive Topics in India: Some Reflections from a Study of Girls Living on the Streets of Kolkata

Author: Bhattacharya, Anindita; Nair, Roshni

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2015): 183.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946508?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social Science research is intertwined with several ethical complexities. The following paper discusses some of the ethical principles in Social Science research drawn from a study conducted on the life experiences of girls on the streets of Kolkata, India. The paper also discusses a few of the dilemmas encountered when exploring sensitive issues such as vulnerability to abuse and highlights that while researching sensitive issues is important, ethical dilemmas become more complex and ethical guidelines therefore assume a greater significance.

Art Therapy in St. Petersburg&apos;s Museums

Author: Biryukova, Marina; Nikonova, Antonina

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2015): 293.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946591?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the different theoretical perspectives, practical applications and social aspects of art therapy used in the museums of St. Petersburg. The main purpose of the art therapy experience in a museum is to facilitate the harmonious development of the personality of children and adults through visual art. The special features of contemporary museums are analysed in the context of their involvement in the social and cultural experience of the application of art therapy.

Relevance of Workplace Spirituality in the Indian Insurance Sector

Author: Gupta, Manu; Singh, Mandeep; Kumar, Vinod

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2015): 261.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946714?accountid=14667

Abstract: The insurance sector in India is highly competitive and, as a result, stressful. Encouraging spirituality in the workplace may help employees cope with stress. This study reveals a positive relationship between workplace spirituality and job satisfaction and, highlights its importance for the insurance sector in India. Thus, Insurance companies should attempt to increase workplace spirituality in order to encourage work commitment, high job performance, high job satisfaction, and reduced levels of absenteeism and employee turnover.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Relevance+of+Workplace+Spirituality+in+the+Indian+Insurance+Sector&amp;rft.au=Gupta%2C+Manu%3BSingh%2C+Mandeep%3BKumar%2C+Vinod&amp;rft.aulast=Gupta&amp;rft.aufirst=Manu&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=261&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Nutritional Status of Children Under Five Years in Maharashtra, India: Evidence from a Large Scale Cross-sectional Study

Author: Gowri, V; Rastogi, Saumya; Dwivedi, LK

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 2,  (Apr 2015): 245.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946851?accountid=14667

Abstract: Data for 2,405 children under the age of five years from the NFHS-3 in Maharashtra has been analysed to explore the effects of socioeconomic, maternal and child related factors on anthropometric indicators of weight-for-age, height-for-age and weight-for-height of children. Important correlates of undernourishment among children were poverty, living in urban areas, belonging to backward castes, age under two years, birth order of more than one, less educated and poorly nourished mothers. The present paper confirms the presence of a socioeconomic gradient in child health with the poor and backward classes bearing the largest burden of child undernourishment.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Nutritional+Status+of+Children+Under+Five+Years+in+Maharashtra%2C+India%3A+Evidence+from+a+Large+Scale+Cross-sectional+Study&amp;rft.au=Gowri%2C+V%3BRastogi%2C+Saumya%3BDwivedi%2C+LK&amp;rft.aulast=Gowri&amp;rft.aufirst=V&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=245&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Correlates of Attitudes Toward Personal Aging in Older Assisted Living Residents

Author: Park, Nan Sook1; Jang, Yuri2; Lee, Beom S3; Chiriboga, David A4; Molinari, Victor51 School of Social Work, University of South Florida, Tampa, Florida, USA2 School of Social Work, The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas, USA3 Department of Mental Health Law and Policy, University of South Florida, Tampa, Florida, USA4 Department of Child and Family Studies, University of South Florida, Tampa, Florida, USA5 School of Aging Studies, University of South Florida, Tampa, Florida, USA

Publication info: Journal of Gerontological Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2015): 232-252.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1900185954?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study explored factors contributing to older adults' self-perceptions about their own aging in assisted living (AL) communities. Data analysis was completed based on interviews with 150 older residents from 17 AL communities. Multiple regression analyses found that functional disability and hearing impairment negatively affected attitudes toward personal aging among AL residents, and satisfaction with social support positively influenced attitudes. Health perception mediated attitudes toward personal aging. Findings suggest the importance of social workers helping older AL residents recognize social support as a means of promoting their positive self-regard.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Correlates+of+Attitudes+Toward+Personal+Aging+in+Older+Assisted+Living+Residents&amp;rft.au=Park%2C+Nan+Sook%3BJang%2C+Yuri%3BLee%2C+Beom+S%3BChiriboga%2C+David+A%3BMolinari%2C+Victor&amp;rft.aulast=Park&amp;rft.aufirst=Nan&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=232&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2014.978926

Assessment of Alzheimer's Disease Symptom Recognition in Korean Americans and Psychometric Analysis of Alzheimer's Disease Symptom Recognition Scale (ADSRS)

Author: Lee, Sang E1; Casado, Banghwa Lee21 School of Social Work, San Jose State University, San Jose, California, USA2 School of Social Work, University of Maryland, Baltimore, Maryland, USA

Publication info: Journal of Gerontological Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2015): 289-305.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1900186827?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined recognition of Alzheimer's disease symptoms among Korean Americans (KAs) and assessed psychometric properties of the Alzheimer's Disease Symptom Recognition Scale (ADSRS). A cross-sectional survey collected data from 209 KAs, using a self-administered questionnaire. Results show that KAs recognized symptoms related to memory and cognitive functioning well, but had very limited recognition of neuropsychiatric symptoms. Psychometric analysis of ADSRS identified 4 factors in their symptom recognition. Findings suggest a need to raise awareness of Alzheimer's symptoms over the course of the disease. Assessment using ADSRS can be incorporated in communication in the practice context and public outreach.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Assessment+of+Alzheimer%27s+Disease+Symptom+Recognition+in+Korean+Americans+and+Psychometric+Analysis+of+Alzheimer%27s+Disease+Symptom+Recognition+Scale+%28ADSRS%29&amp;rft.au=Lee%2C+Sang+E%3BCasado%2C+Banghwa+Lee&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Sang&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=289&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2015.1005785

"As Needed" Case Management Across Aging Services in Response to Depression

Author: Hasche, Leslie K1; Lavery, Angela11 Graduate School of Social Work, University of Denver, Denver, Colorado, USA

Publication info: Journal of Gerontological Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2015): 272-288.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1900187129?accountid=14667

Abstract: A lack of clarity on how and where case management for older adults is delivered persists, even as evidence supports its use to respond to depression. We used in-depth interviews with managers (n = 20) and staff surveys (n = 142) from 17 service agencies to explore the provision of case management services in adult day services, homecare, senior centers, and supportive housing. Limited case management services were found. Barriers included limited time and resources, especially for senior centers and supportive housing. Results revealed a concern about the role, feasibility, and availability of case management for older adults within these settings.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=%22As+Needed%22+Case+Management+Across+Aging+Services+in+Response+to+Depression&amp;rft.au=Hasche%2C+Leslie+K%3BLavery%2C+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Hasche&amp;rft.aufirst=Leslie&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=272&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2014.1001931

Pathological Gambling and Treatment Outcomes for Adults Age 50 or Older in Methadone Maintenance Treatment

Author: Engel, Rafael J1; Rosen, Daniel11 School of Social Work, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

Publication info: Journal of Gerontological Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2015): 306-314.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1900187231?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the relationship of pathological gambling to negative treatment outcomes for methadone maintenance patients aged 50 or older. The study included 130 methadone maintenance patients. Pathological gambling was determined using the Lie-Bet, a screen for pathological gambling; the outcomes were remaining in treatment and negative urine screens for drug use. Twenty percent of the sample identified as pathological gamblers. Pathological gambling was unrelated to remaining in treatment or negative urine screens. Although pathological gambling had no adverse influence on these treatment outcomes, the prevalence of pathological gambling suggests that screening for it may provide insights about other concerns.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Pathological+Gambling+and+Treatment+Outcomes+for+Adults+Age+50+or+Older+in+Methadone+Maintenance+Treatment&amp;rft.au=Engel%2C+Rafael+J%3BRosen%2C+Daniel&amp;rft.aulast=Engel&amp;rft.aufirst=Rafael&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=306&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2014.960989

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Pathological+Gambling+and+Treatment+Outcomes+for+Adults+Age+50+or+Older+in+Methadone+Maintenance+Treatment&amp;rft.au=Engel%2C+Rafael+J%3BRosen%2C+Daniel&amp;rft.aulast=Engel&amp;rft.aufirst=Rafael&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=306&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2014.960989

____________________________________________________________

Predictors of Depression Among Caregivers of Older Adults With Severe Mental Illness

Author: Cummings, Sherry M1; Kropf, Nancy P21 College of Social Work, University of Tennessee, Nashville, Tennessee, USA2 School of Social Work, Georgia State University, Atlanta, Georgia, USA

Publication info: Journal of Gerontological Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 3,  (Apr 2015): 253-271.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1900193883?accountid=14667

Abstract: Caregivers of older persons with severe mental illness (SMI) contend with the double challenge of providing assistance related to both the psychiatric condition and older age of their family member. Study explored factors influencing negative psychological outcomes experienced by caregivers (n = 96) of older adults with SMI. One-quarter of caregivers scored at or above the clinical point for depression. Low income, care recipient gender, poor health, problems dealing with care recipient's symptoms and the interaction of health and problems dealing with symptoms were associated with higher rates of depression. Implications for service provision and future research are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Predictors+of+Depression+Among+Caregivers+of+Older+Adults+With+Severe+Mental+Illness&amp;rft.au=Cummings%2C+Sherry+M%3BKropf%2C+Nancy+P&amp;rft.aulast=Cummings&amp;rft.aufirst=Sherry&amp;rft.date=2015-04-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=253&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2014.978927

Reflections on a Quantitative, Group-Based Mindfulness Study with Social Work Students

Author: Botta, Ariel A1; Cadet, Tamara J; Maramaldi, Peter1 Simmons College School of Social Work, Boston, Massachusetts, USA

Publication info: Social Work with Groups  Vol. 38, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2015): 93-105.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993052?accountid=14667

Abstract: Emerging research demonstrates that mindfulness is effective in reducing health care worker burnout. The aim of this quantitative pilot study was to examine the effectiveness of a mindfulness intervention on social work students. The investigation utilized a pretest/posttest design. Findings from the study demonstrated an increase in knowledge (p < .001), self-efficacy (p < .001), and beliefs (p < .005) related to mindfulness following a group-based mindfulness intervention. Reflections on the first author's need to resist her group work instincts to test the effectiveness of the mindfulness intervention are shared. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Reflections+on+a+Quantitative%2C+Group-Based+Mindfulness+Study+with+Social+Work+Students&amp;rft.au=Botta%2C+Ariel+A%3BCadet%2C+Tamara+J%3BMaramaldi%2C+Peter&amp;rft.aulast=Botta&amp;rft.aufirst=Ariel&amp;rft.date=2015-04-03&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2014.975885

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Reflections+on+a+Quantitative%2C+Group-Based+Mindfulness+Study+with+Social+Work+Students&amp;rft.au=Botta%2C+Ariel+A%3BCadet%2C+Tamara+J%3BMaramaldi%2C+Peter&amp;rft.aulast=Botta&amp;rft.aufirst=Ariel&amp;rft.date=2015-04-03&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2014.975885

____________________________________________________________

Applying Evidence-Based Practice in Group Work at an Alternative High School

Author: Weller, Bridget E1; Huang, Jessica; Cherubin, Sinaida1 Duke Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Duke University, Durham, North Carolina, USA

Publication info: Social Work with Groups  Vol. 38, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2015): 122-135.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993257?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers often are reluctant to use evidence-based practice in group work. Part of this reluctance is because of the perceived rigidity of the process and its emphasis on research. However, social workers can rely on the four cornerstones of evidence-based practice-research, clinical experience, personal views, and client's perspective-to provide an evidence-based group intervention. In this article, the authors illustrate how social workers used the four cornerstones at one alternative high school to provide an evidence-based group intervention. These cornerstones were used from the beginning of the process, which started with choosing the type of intervention, through the end of the process, which concluded with assessing the intervention. In this article, the authors show that it is possible for social workers to provide an evidence-based group intervention, while remaining flexible, thereby contributing to social workers' knowledge of how to use evidence-based practice with groups. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Applying+Evidence-Based+Practice+in+Group+Work+at+an+Alternative+High+School&amp;rft.au=Weller%2C+Bridget+E%3BHuang%2C+Jessica%3BCherubin%2C+Sinaida&amp;rft.aulast=Weller&amp;rft.aufirst=Bridget&amp;rft.date=2015-04-03&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=122&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2014.965871

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Applying+Evidence-Based+Practice+in+Group+Work+at+an+Alternative+High+School&amp;rft.au=Weller%2C+Bridget+E%3BHuang%2C+Jessica%3BCherubin%2C+Sinaida&amp;rft.aulast=Weller&amp;rft.aufirst=Bridget&amp;rft.date=2015-04-03&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=122&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2014.965871

____________________________________________________________

Accountability and Risk Assessment: Members' and Leaders' Perspectives about Psychoeducational Batterers' Group

Author: Black, Beverly M1; Weisz, Arlene N; Mengo, Cecilia W; Lucero, Jessica L1 School of Social Work, University of Texas at Arlington, Arlington, Texas, USA

Publication info: Social Work with Groups  Vol. 38, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2015): 136-151.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993293?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study reports group leaders' assessment of group members' risk for reassault and level of accountability during a psychoeducational group intervention with male domestic violence perpetrators. It also examines members' assessment of their own risk for reassault and level of accountability over the 18-week program. Group leaders and group members completed surveys every 2 weeks. Bivariate analyses examining differences in accountability rating and risk assessment between group leaders and group members show little agreement between leaders and members and few changes over time. Group leaders assessed group members as showing some increases in level of accountability near the end of the group. These findings suggest group leaders perceived increased accountability among group members, but they were rarely able to fulfill their goal of educating members about the connection between accountability and risk of reassault. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Accountability+and+Risk+Assessment%3A+Members%27+and+Leaders%27+Perspectives+about+Psychoeducational+Batterers%27+Group&amp;rft.au=Black%2C+Beverly+M%3BWeisz%2C+Arlene+N%3BMengo%2C+Cecilia+W%3BLucero%2C+Jessica+L&amp;rft.aulast=Black&amp;rft.aufirst=Beverly&amp;rft.date=2015-04-03&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=136&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2014.923363

Multiple Family Group Therapy for Families with Children Placed in Out-Of-Home Care in a Chinese Context

Author: Wong, Mooly M C1; Ma, Joyce L C; Chan, Londy C L1 Department of Social Work, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, China

Publication info: Social Work with Groups  Vol. 38, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2015): 106-121.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993328?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since the 1980s, the family-centered approach has been widely adopted in the west (e.g., the United States) as an approach to serving children living in an out-of-home care context. In comparison, in Hong Kong, out-of-home care services tend to be child-centered and child-protection oriented. This article (1) examines the child welfare service, specifically out-of-home care services, in Hong Kong and (2) makes the case for integrating family-centered out-of-home care services for children. Three vignettes are presented that demonstrate the use of Multiple Family Group Therapy (MFGT) to promote family-centered practice. The article concludes with a discussion of challenges and recommendations related to a shift to family-centered practice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=Multiple+Family+Group+Therapy+for+Families+with+Children+Placed+in+Out-Of-Home+Care+in+a+Chinese+Context&amp;rft.au=Wong%2C+Mooly+M+C%3BMa%2C+Joyce+L+C%3BChan%2C+Londy+C+L&amp;rft.aulast=Wong&amp;rft.aufirst=Mooly+M&amp;rft.date=2015-04-03&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=106&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2014.921882

The Use of Humor to Help Bridge Cultural Divides: An Exploration of a Workplace Cultural Awareness Workshop

Author: Rocke, Cathy11 Faculty of Social Work, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Canada

Publication info: Social Work with Groups  Vol. 38, Iss. 2,  (April 3, 2015): 152-169.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993442?accountid=14667

Abstract: Humor can be used to ease tensions and create a safe place to dialogue across cultural differences in educational initiatives that seek to address social inequality. Little is written however on the appropriate use of humor within these educational programs. This article explores how group facilitators utilized specific types of humor to challenge ill-informed or intolerant statements while still maintaining a safe space to dialogue across difference. Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal worldviews on the understanding and use of humor are contrasted to help inform group facilitators on the knowledge and skills needed to appropriately utilize humor within their work. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.atitle=The+Use+of+Humor+to+Help+Bridge+Cultural+Divides%3A+An+Exploration+of+a+Workplace+Cultural+Awareness+Workshop&amp;rft.au=Rocke%2C+Cathy&amp;rft.aulast=Rocke&amp;rft.aufirst=Cathy&amp;rft.date=2015-04-03&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=152&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+with+Groups&amp;rft.issn=01609513&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01609513.2014.968944

____________________________________________________________

Integrating the teaching, learning and assessment of communication with children within the qualifying social work curriculum

Author: Lefevre, Michelle

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 211-222.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1671986285?accountid=14667

Abstract: Qualifying social work education must provide students with a variety of experiential, personalized, participatory, didactic and critically reflective learning opportunities across both the taught curriculum and in practice placements if deep learning of the capabilities needed for effective communication with children and young people is to be ensured. At present, programmes in England are not consistent in the curriculum structures, content and pedagogical approaches they are employing to teach and assess this topic. This paper discusses first how current proposals for the reform of qualifying education in England do not address the ambiguities and discretion in regulatory guidance, which have meant that the place and relevance of this topic within the curriculum remain uncertain and contested. It then draws on a model of the sequencing of students' learning and development in qualifying training, developed through the author's recent empirical research, to present an integrated and coherent approach to the teaching, learning and assessment of this topic. It is proposed that this strategy will enable students to develop the generic, 'child-focused' and 'applied child-specialist' capabilities they need for the 'knowing', 'being' and 'doing' of effective communication with children.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Integrating+the+teaching%2C+learning+and+assessment+of+communication+with+children+within+the+qualifying+social+work+curriculum&amp;rft.au=Lefevre%2C+Michelle&amp;rft.aulast=Lefevre&amp;rft.aufirst=Michelle&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=211&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12071

Mapping the journey: outcome-focused practice and the role of interim outcomes in family support services

Author: Tunstill, Jane; Blewett, James

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 234-243.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1671986329?accountid=14667

Abstract: Longitudinal costly evaluations will always be important in order to understand the factors that impact on child, family and community well-being over the long and medium term. However, in a policy era that accords major importance to the achievement of outcomes, e.g. payment by results, 'outcome theology' can pose threats to service access and professional morale in family support. It is essential therefore, to ascertain the short-term outcomes of services in order to capture the trajectory of progress by families under stress. This paper critiques the concept of 'the outcome'. It traces the development of this trend in policy and describes an alternative but complementary approach, which is based on capturing interim outcomes in family support services.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Mapping+the+journey%3A+outcome-focused+practice+and+the+role+of+interim+outcomes+in+family+support+services&amp;rft.au=Tunstill%2C+Jane%3BBlewett%2C+James&amp;rft.aulast=Tunstill&amp;rft.aufirst=Jane&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=234&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12073

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Mapping+the+journey%3A+outcome-focused+practice+and+the+role+of+interim+outcomes+in+family+support+services&amp;rft.au=Tunstill%2C+Jane%3BBlewett%2C+James&amp;rft.aulast=Tunstill&amp;rft.aufirst=Jane&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=234&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12073

____________________________________________________________

Understanding and working with adolescent neglect: perspectives from research, young people and professionals

Author: Hicks, Leslie; Stein, Mike

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 223-233.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1671986354?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper provides an overview of research about adolescent neglect funded by the Department of Children, Schools and Families (now the Department for Education) and the Department of Health. The paper examines what is known from literature about the causes of adolescent neglect, together with its potential consequences for well-being. Drawing on qualitative data, the concept of neglect is explored from the perspectives of young people themselves and the professionals who work with them. Consideration is given to examples of interventions and preventative models geared towards addressing adolescent neglect. Key findings indicate that there is a need for both a re-examination of current definitions of neglect in the light of age-related distinctions and perspectives, and a fuller understanding of the particular needs of adolescents who are experiencing neglect. Additionally, the research highlights that there is a lack of research knowledge about neglectful parenting and the behaviour of young people, as well as limited understanding of interventions with neglected adolescents. Key themes from the research are discussed in terms of their implications for future practice, policy and research in relation to working to improve the welfare of neglected young people.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+and+working+with+adolescent+neglect%3A+perspectives+from+research%2C+young+people+and+professionals&amp;rft.au=Hicks%2C+Leslie%3BStein%2C+Mike&amp;rft.aulast=Hicks&amp;rft.aufirst=Leslie&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=223&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12072

____________________________________________________________

Children's and young people's participation within child welfare and child protection services: a state-of-the-art review

Author: Bijleveld, Ganna G; Dedding, Christine W M; Bunders-Aelen, Joske F G

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 129-138.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1671986364?accountid=14667

Abstract: This state-of-the-art literature review, based on a literature search of multiple scientific bibliographic databases, aims to shed light on what is known about barriers and factors facilitating child participation within the child protection and child welfare services from both children's and social workers' perspectives. The personal relationship between the child and the social worker is mentioned as one of the most important facilitators for participation, although multiple barriers in creating this relationship are demonstrated by both children and case managers and social workers. In studies, children say they should always participate while social workers and case managers identify many situations where, according to them, participation is inappropriate. Professionals' objections to participation mainly stem from the socio-cultural image of children as vulnerable and in need of adult protection, and a lack of understanding of what participation actually entails. Interventions to strengthen participation should be directed at making social workers and case managers aware that children are knowledgeable social actors.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Children%27s+and+young+people%27s+participation+within+child+welfare+and+child+protection+services%3A+a+state-of-the-art+review&amp;rft.au=Bijleveld%2C+Ganna+G%3BDedding%2C+Christine+W+M%3BBunders-Aelen%2C+Joske+F+G&amp;rft.aulast=Bijleveld&amp;rft.aufirst=Ganna&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12082

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Children%27s+and+young+people%27s+participation+within+child+welfare+and+child+protection+services%3A+a+state-of-the-art+review&amp;rft.au=Bijleveld%2C+Ganna+G%3BDedding%2C+Christine+W+M%3BBunders-Aelen%2C+Joske+F+G&amp;rft.aulast=Bijleveld&amp;rft.aufirst=Ganna&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12082

____________________________________________________________

Resisting your good intentions: substance-misusing parents and early intervention to support and monitor children in need

Author: Barnard, Marina; Bain, Carole

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 171-180.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1671987591?accountid=14667

Abstract: Children from substance-misusing families face elevated risks in growing up well and safe. Early intervention is an opportunity for local authorities to offer support and keep a watching brief on children's welfare. However, the basis upon which agencies voluntarily engage with families in advance of major problems becoming evident is far from straightforward. This qualitative pilot study in Scotland followed professional decision-making over 6 months (n = 20 professionals) with a small number of families (n = 6) defined as in need of supportive intervention. This support was allied with an intention to monitor the family situation, which, in these data, appeared to affect the willingness of families to engage with services. As services sought to increase their voluntary oversight, sometimes by threatening escalating involvement, so families by various means appeared to resist it. Successful early intervention is reliant on voluntary family participation and thus requires close attention to means of positive and motivated parental engagement to disarm resistance.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Resisting+your+good+intentions%3A+substance-misusing+parents+and+early+intervention+to+support+and+monitor+children+in+need&amp;rft.au=Barnard%2C+Marina%3BBain%2C+Carole&amp;rft.aulast=Barnard&amp;rft.aufirst=Marina&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=171&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12064

Effective services for improving education and employment outcomes for children and alumni of foster care service: correlates and educational and employment outcomes

Author: Barnow, Burt S; Buck, Amy; O'Brien, Kirk; Pecora, Peter; Ellis, Mei Ling; Steiner, Eric

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 159-170.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1671987707?accountid=14667

Abstract: Outcomes for youth from foster care have been found to be poor. The education and employment outcomes of youth and alumni of foster care served by transition programmes located in five major US cities were examined. Data were collected by case managers and reported to evaluators quarterly on 1058 youth from foster care for over 2 years. Job preparation, transportation, child care, education support services and life skills were the most common services provided to youth. During the 2-year study period, 35% of participants obtained employment, 23% obtained a General Education Development or diploma, and 17% enrolled in post-secondary education. It was found that the longer the youth were enrolled, the more education and employment outcomes they achieved. Further, job preparation and income support services were associated significantly with achieving any positive education or employment outcome. Results indicated that certain services provided over an extended period of time can improve outcomes for youth placed in foster care. For youth to achieve positive outcomes as they transition to adulthood, additional services are necessary. Other implications are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Effective+services+for+improving+education+and+employment+outcomes+for+children+and+alumni+of+foster+care+service%3A+correlates+and+educational+and+employment+outcomes&amp;rft.au=Barnow%2C+Burt+S%3BBuck%2C+Amy%3BO%27Brien%2C+Kirk%3BPecora%2C+Peter%3BEllis%2C+Mei+Ling%3BSteiner%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Barnow&amp;rft.aufirst=Burt&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=159&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12063

____________________________________________________________

Contested attachments: rethinking adoptive kinship in the era of open adoption

Author: Sales, Sally

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 149-158.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1671987716?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since its legal inception in 1926, adoption work has been centrally concerned with the matter of the adopted child's 'first' or prior life, whilst also focussed on achieving a new and secure substitute family for that child. Adoptive kinship has been formed through this dual and contradictory concern, a concern that has produced diverse policies and practices over the last 90 years. Drawing on Foucault's concept of technologies of the subject, this paper is an exploration of adoptive kinship within the new context of open adoption, a set of practices that more actively promotes the involvements of the adopted child's former family. These practices both promote a radical reworking of adoptive kinship, as well as confirming its more orthodox moorings. Drawing on an adoption archive study, the paper concludes with an analysis of letterbox contact to explore how far this form of open practice transforms adoptive kinship in the contemporary era.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Contested+attachments%3A+rethinking+adoptive+kinship+in+the+era+of+open+adoption&amp;rft.au=Sales%2C+Sally&amp;rft.aulast=Sales&amp;rft.aufirst=Sally&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12062

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Contested+attachments%3A+rethinking+adoptive+kinship+in+the+era+of+open+adoption&amp;rft.au=Sales%2C+Sally&amp;rft.aulast=Sales&amp;rft.aufirst=Sally&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12062

Five years in care: documented lives and time trajectories in child welfare

Author: Poso, Tarja; Eronen, Tuija

Publication info: Child & Family Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 202-210.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1671987773?accountid=14667

Abstract: Child welfare practice is temporally structured and includes a variety of follow-up activities. Practice-based follow-up has not, however, been much explored when studying children's paths in the child welfare system. This paper is based on a study of children (103) who were taken into care in 2006 in 10 Finnish municipalities and their paths in care until 2011. The social workers' institutional knowledge of their 'own' clients comprises the core of the research design. The paper reflects on the nature of this data from the point of view of the notions of temporality. The analysis highlights four temporal trajectories used in retrospective analysis of children's paths in care: the linear time trajectory of the decisions and changes in the institutional positions, the temporally fragmentary trajectory of childhood and youth, the circular time trajectory of professional understanding of the child's path and the silent time trajectory. Each one documents the children's paths differently; the linear one tends to be the 'natural' and most easily available trajectory and consequently, the children's paths are documented via decisions and institutional positions. The analysis suggests that more attention should be given to the complexity of time and temporality when studying children's paths in child welfare.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Five+years+in+care%3A+documented+lives+and+time+trajectories+in+child+welfare&amp;rft.au=Poso%2C+Tarja%3BEronen%2C+Tuija&amp;rft.aulast=Poso&amp;rft.aufirst=Tarja&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=202&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12069

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Five+years+in+care%3A+documented+lives+and+time+trajectories+in+child+welfare&amp;rft.au=Poso%2C+Tarja%3BEronen%2C+Tuija&amp;rft.aulast=Poso&amp;rft.aufirst=Tarja&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=202&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+%26+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12069

Development of an evidence-informed in-home family services model for families and children at risk of abuse and neglect

Author: Ingram, Stephanie D1; Cash, Scottye J; Oats, Robert G; Simpson, Amy; Thompson, Ronald W1 Father Flanagan's Boys' Home, Boys Town, NE.

Publication info: Child and Family Social Work  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 139-148.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672113?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes the components of a programme designed to prevent child maltreatment which includes the promising practices of a continuous engagement process, cognitive-behavioural parent and skill teaching, and development of formal and informal supports for families. The programme was also designed to be implemented wide scale. Methods for assessment of strengths and needs, individualization of goals and intervention strategies, and assessment of goal achievement are also described. Finally, preliminary results of a programme implementation fidelity and outcome evaluation are summarized. The authors conclude that this programme is ready for a more rigorous efficacy trial to continue to build the evidence base for this promising intervention addressing a prevalent social problem. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Development+of+an+evidence-informed+in-home+family+services+model+for+families+and+children+at+risk+of+abuse+and+neglect&amp;rft.au=Ingram%2C+Stephanie+D%3BCash%2C+Scottye+J%3BOats%2C+Robert+G%3BSimpson%2C+Amy%3BThompson%2C+Ronald+W&amp;rft.aulast=Ingram&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephanie&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=139&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12061

____________________________________________________________

Practitioner-mother relationships and the processes that bind them

Author: Waterhouse, Lorraine1; McGhee, Janice1 School of Social and Political Science, University of Edinburgh, Edinburgh, UK.

Publication info: Child and Family Social Work  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 244-251.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672303?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper outlines a theoretical contribution to conceptualizing practitioner-mother relationships in child protection social work. It examines what is represented when these face-to-face encounters takes place. It suggests an intersubjective dimension where mothers are in effect asked to give an account of themselves. Drawing on humanities and social science writing, practitioner-mother relations are examined to analyse their symbolic and literal significance and the underlying purposes and assumptions that bind them. Butler's theory of recognition is utilized to alert us to the importance of supporting the narrative capacity of women caught up in child protection processes and of allowing the mother to give an account of herself as a woman and as a mother. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Practitioner-mother+relationships+and+the+processes+that+bind+them&amp;rft.au=Waterhouse%2C+Lorraine%3BMcGhee%2C+Janice&amp;rft.aulast=Waterhouse&amp;rft.aufirst=Lorraine&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=244&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12074

From 'Rights to Action': practitioners' perceptions of the needs of children experiencing domestic violence

Author: Clarke, Alan1; Wydall, Sarah1 Department of Law and Criminology, Hugh Owen Building, Aberystwyth University, Ceredigion, SY233DY, UK.

Publication info: Child and Family Social Work  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 181-190.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672481?accountid=14667

Abstract: Not only has research over the past decade documented the emotional and behavioural consequences for children who witness domestic violence, but a number of studies have used children as participants thus, giving them an opportunity to describe their experiences in their own words. In policy terms, there has been a growing emphasis on children's rights and the importance and understanding of children's perspectives on their own lives. Consequently, children can no longer be perceived as forgotten victims where domestic violence is concerned. This paper explores practitioners' awareness of the needs of children and young people living with, and fleeing from, domestic violence. The research, conducted in a rural area in Wales, reveals that although the views of practitioners reflect the concerns reported by young people in other studies, there can be barriers to meeting these needs. While policy prescribes engaging with children, at the institutional level, operational priorities and increasing administrative demands can actually reduce opportunities for working directly with children. These demands may hamper the development of multi-agency practice. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=From+%27Rights+to+Action%27%3A+practitioners%27+perceptions+of+the+needs+of+children+experiencing+domestic+violence&amp;rft.au=Clarke%2C+Alan%3BWydall%2C+Sarah&amp;rft.aulast=Clarke&amp;rft.aufirst=Alan&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12066

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=From+%27Rights+to+Action%27%3A+practitioners%27+perceptions+of+the+needs+of+children+experiencing+domestic+violence&amp;rft.au=Clarke%2C+Alan%3BWydall%2C+Sarah&amp;rft.aulast=Clarke&amp;rft.aufirst=Alan&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12066

____________________________________________________________

Resisting your good intentions: substance-misusing parents and early intervention to support and monitor children in need

Author: Barnard, Marina1; Bain, Carole1 Centre for Drug Misuse Research, Glasgow, UK.

Publication info: Child and Family Social Work  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 171-180.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672495?accountid=14667

Abstract: Children from substance-misusing families face elevated risks in growing up well and safe. Early intervention is an opportunity for local authorities to offer support and keep a watching brief on children's welfare. However, the basis upon which agencies voluntarily engage with families in advance of major problems becoming evident is far from straightforward. This qualitative pilot study in Scotland followed professional decision-making over 6 months (n = 20 professionals) with a small number of families (n = 6) defined as in need of supportive intervention. This support was allied with an intention to monitor the family situation, which, in these data, appeared to affect the willingness of families to engage with services. As services sought to increase their voluntary oversight, sometimes by threatening escalating involvement, so families by various means appeared to resist it. Successful early intervention is reliant on voluntary family participation and thus requires close attention to means of positive and motivated parental engagement to disarm resistance. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Resisting+your+good+intentions%3A+substance-misusing+parents+and+early+intervention+to+support+and+monitor+children+in+need&amp;rft.au=Barnard%2C+Marina%3BBain%2C+Carole&amp;rft.aulast=Barnard&amp;rft.aufirst=Marina&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=171&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12064

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Resisting+your+good+intentions%3A+substance-misusing+parents+and+early+intervention+to+support+and+monitor+children+in+need&amp;rft.au=Barnard%2C+Marina%3BBain%2C+Carole&amp;rft.aulast=Barnard&amp;rft.aufirst=Marina&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=171&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12064

____________________________________________________________

Factors associated with placement breakdown initiated by foster parents - empirical findings from Germany

Author: Santen, Eric11 Abteilung Jugend und Jugendhilfe (Department Youth and Youth Welfare), Deutsches Jugendinstitut e. V. (German Youth Institute (DJI), Munich, Germany.

Publication info: Child and Family Social Work  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 191-201.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672525?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study investigates the effects of covariates on the probability of placement breakdown in non-kinship family foster care. Breakdowns are distinguished according to the initiator: children, carers, foster parents and the local child welfare authorities. The children concerned had entered foster care at ages ranging from 0 to a maximum of 17 years (n = 14171). A significantly higher risk of breakdown on the initiative of the foster parents is found in male children, children whose parents receive financial support, children whose parents were removed from the register of carers, children who were between 6 and 15 years old when they joined the foster family, children who had earlier lived in a different foster family or residential care, children from patchwork families and children whose joining of a foster family was the result of disruptive social behaviour. Two-thirds of the children from non-kinship family foster care who stay in the foster family was ended on the initiative of the foster parents are subsequently looked after in residential care. That is three times the rate for all terminated foster relationships. Breakdowns on the initiative of the foster parents thus indicate a high risk of unstable care history developing and accordingly necessitate prevention strategies. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+associated+with+placement+breakdown+initiated+by+foster+parents+-+empirical+findings+from+Germany&amp;rft.au=Santen%2C+Eric&amp;rft.aulast=Santen&amp;rft.aufirst=Eric&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=191&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12068

Integrating the teaching, learning and assessment of communication with children within the qualifying social work curriculum

Author: Lefevre, Michelle11 School of Education and Social Work, University of Sussex, Brighton, UK.

Publication info: Child and Family Social Work  Vol. 20, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 211-222.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1700672606?accountid=14667

Abstract: Qualifying social work education must provide students with a variety of experiential, personalized, participatory, didactic and critically reflective learning opportunities across both the taught curriculum and in practice placements if deep learning of the capabilities needed for effective communication with children and young people is to be ensured. At present, programmes in England are not consistent in the curriculum structures, content and pedagogical approaches they are employing to teach and assess this topic. This paper discusses first how current proposals for the reform of qualifying education in England do not address the ambiguities and discretion in regulatory guidance, which have meant that the place and relevance of this topic within the curriculum remain uncertain and contested. It then draws on a model of the sequencing of students' learning and development in qualifying training, developed through the author's recent empirical research, to present an integrated and coherent approach to the teaching, learning and assessment of this topic. It is proposed that this strategy will enable students to develop the generic, 'child-focused' and 'applied child-specialist' capabilities they need for the 'knowing', 'being' and 'doing' of effective communication with children. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Integrating+the+teaching%2C+learning+and+assessment+of+communication+with+children+within+the+qualifying+social+work+curriculum&amp;rft.au=Lefevre%2C+Michelle&amp;rft.aulast=Lefevre&amp;rft.aufirst=Michelle&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=211&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12071

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Integrating+the+teaching%2C+learning+and+assessment+of+communication+with+children+within+the+qualifying+social+work+curriculum&amp;rft.au=Lefevre%2C+Michelle&amp;rft.aulast=Lefevre&amp;rft.aufirst=Michelle&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=211&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Child+and+Family+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=13567500&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fcfs.12071

Caste- and Ethnicity-Based Inequalities in HIV/AIDS-Related Knowledge Gap: A Case of Nepal

Author: Atteraya, Madhu; Kimm, HeeJin; Song, In Han

Publication info: Health & Social Work  Vol. 40, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 100.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993148?accountid=14667

Abstract: Caste- and ethnicity-based inequalities are major obstacles to achieving health equity. The authors investigated whether there is any association between caste- and ethnicity-based inequalities and HIV-related knowledge within caste and ethnic populations. They used the 2011 Nepal Demographic and Health Survey, a nationally represented cross-sectional study data set. The study sample consisted of 11,273 women between 15 and 49 years of age. Univariate and logistic regression models were used to examine the relationship between caste- and ethnicity-based inequalities and HIV-related knowledge. The study sample was divided into high Hindu caste (47.9 percent), 'untouchable' caste (18.4 percent), and indigenous populations (33.7 percent). Within the study sample, the high-caste population was found to have the greatest knowledge of the means by which HIV is prevented and transmitted. After controlling for socioeconomic and demographic characteristics, untouchables were the least knowledgeable. The odds ratio for incomplete knowledge about transmission among indigenous populations was 1.27 times higher than that for high Hindu castes, but there was no significant difference in knowledge of preventive measures. The findings suggest the existence of a prevailing HIV knowledge gap. This in turn suggests that appropriate steps need to be implemented to convey complete knowledge to underprivileged populations. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Caste-+and+Ethnicity-Based+Inequalities+in+HIV%2FAIDS-Related+Knowledge+Gap%3A+A+Case+of+Nepal&amp;rft.au=Atteraya%2C+Madhu%3BKimm%2C+HeeJin%3BSong%2C+In+Han&amp;rft.aulast=Atteraya&amp;rft.aufirst=Madhu&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=100&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Caste-+and+Ethnicity-Based+Inequalities+in+HIV%2FAIDS-Related+Knowledge+Gap%3A+A+Case+of+Nepal&amp;rft.au=Atteraya%2C+Madhu%3BKimm%2C+HeeJin%3BSong%2C+In+Han&amp;rft.aulast=Atteraya&amp;rft.aufirst=Madhu&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=100&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Factors Associated with Health Care Discrimination Experiences among a National Sample of Female-to-Male Transgender Individuals

Author: Shires, Deirdre A; Jaffee, Kim

Publication info: Health & Social Work  Vol. 40, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): 134.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993219?accountid=14667

Abstract: Transgender individuals experience harassment, violence, and discrimination in a number of settings. Although health care discrimination against transgender people has been documented, this issue is understudied. Using a national cross-sectional survey data set (N = 1,711), the authors sought to determine how gender identity and presentation predict health care discrimination experiences among female-to-male (FTM) transgender people after demographic and socioeconomic characteristics are controlled. Analyses were conducted using chi-square tests and a two-step logistic regression. The majority of participants were white (73.9 percent) and between 25 and 44 years old (65.2 percent). Overall, 41.8 percent of FTM participants reported verbal harassment, physical assault, or denial of equal treatment in a doctor's office or hospital. When other factors were controlled, being Native American or multiracial, identifying as queer or asexual/other, having a graduate degree, living full-time as nonbirth gender, using hormones or surgery for medical transition, and having identification documents that list one's preferred gender were associated with increased reporting of health care discrimination experiences; being 45 years or older and reporting an annual income of $60,000 or more were associated with decreased risk. The study's findings can be useful to social workers, who play a role in educating health care providers and advocating for policies that improve health care experiences for FTM and other transgender patients. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Associated+with+Health+Care+Discrimination+Experiences+among+a+National+Sample+of+Female-to-Male+Transgender+Individuals&amp;rft.au=Shires%2C+Deirdre+A%3BJaffee%2C+Kim&amp;rft.aulast=Shires&amp;rft.aufirst=Deirdre&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=134&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Access to Mental Health and Substance Abuse Services by People Living with HIV/AIDS: The Case Manager Perspective

Author: Orellana, Edwin Roberto; Goldbach, Jeremy; Rountree, Michelle Angela; Bagwell, Meredith

Publication info: Health & Social Work  Vol. 40, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): E10.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993222?accountid=14667

Abstract: There are deleterious consequences to untreated mental health and substance abuse concerns among people living with HIV/AIDS (PLWHA). Most research on this population accessing specialized services has been described from the clients' perspectives. However, case managers play an important role in PLWHA receiving services. This study examined HIV case managers' perspectives of the barriers and facilitators encountered by their HIV-positive clients when seeking mental health and substance use treatment. In addition, the study describes case managers' use of mental health and substance abuse assessment instruments. Cross-sectional survey data were collected from case managers (N = 113). Structural challenges, such as financial concerns and limited transportation, were found to be significant barriers to mental health and substance abuse treatment. Positive client-provider relationships, accessible services, and case manager availability were influential in PLWHA accessing specialized services. Service delivery systems recommendations include increased social support systems, colocated and integrated services, and training of case managers to motivate clients to seek mental health and substance abuse treatment. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Access+to+Mental+Health+and+Substance+Abuse+Services+by+People+Living+with+HIV%2FAIDS%3A+The+Case+Manager+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Orellana%2C+Edwin+Roberto%3BGoldbach%2C+Jeremy%3BRountree%2C+Michelle+Angela%3BBagwell%2C+Meredith&amp;rft.aulast=Orellana&amp;rft.aufirst=Edwin&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=E10&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Voices from the Frontlines: Examining Elder Abuse from Multiple Professional Perspectives

Author: DeLiema, Marguerite; Navarro, Adria; Enguidanos, Susan; Wilber, Kathleen

Publication info: Health & Social Work  Vol. 40, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): E15.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993318?accountid=14667

Abstract: Little is known about the experiences of health professionals in reporting suspected elder abuse and neglect (EAN) or the perceptions of Adult Protective Services (APS) in responding to reports. The purpose of this article is to examine the attitudes and perceptions of health professionals in responding to elder mistreatment and to compare these attitudes and perceptions to those of APS workers who investigate abuse. Focus groups were conducted with APS workers (n = 9) and two types of health professionals: geriatric care managers (n = 4) and hospice staff (n = 13). Transcripts were coded inductively, and emergent themes were compared across groups using thematic analysis. Health professionals and APS workers acknowledged similar challenges resolving cases of EAN -- particularly victim refusal of services or denial of abuse, limited APS authority, and large caseloads. APS workers identified unnecessary referrals and poor communication among providers as barriers to effectiveness. Health care workers noted they sometimes ignored mandatory reporting requirements, preferring to work directly with patients and families to remedy abuse. Results suggest that mandatory reporting may be a necessary but insufficient approach. Cross-agency collaboration between APS and health professionals may help enhance communications, clarify expectations, and potentially improve outcomes. Person-centered responses that link victims with community-based services should also be explored to improve victim cooperation and to increase confidence in the adult protection system. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Voices+from+the+Frontlines%3A+Examining+Elder+Abuse+from+Multiple+Professional+Perspectives&amp;rft.au=DeLiema%2C+Marguerite%3BNavarro%2C+Adria%3BEnguidanos%2C+Susan%3BWilber%2C+Kathleen&amp;rft.aulast=DeLiema&amp;rft.aufirst=Marguerite&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=E15&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Voices+from+the+Frontlines%3A+Examining+Elder+Abuse+from+Multiple+Professional+Perspectives&amp;rft.au=DeLiema%2C+Marguerite%3BNavarro%2C+Adria%3BEnguidanos%2C+Susan%3BWilber%2C+Kathleen&amp;rft.aulast=DeLiema&amp;rft.aufirst=Marguerite&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=E15&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Breaking the Silence: Interpreting African-Born Women's Knowledge about HIV and Concurrency

Author: Tecle, Aster Solomon; Andrasik, Michele

Publication info: Health & Social Work  Vol. 40, Iss. 2,  (May 2015): E32.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1752993343?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article focuses on African-born women's knowledge of HIV and multiple sexual relationships. Data were drawn from a study with the black community in Washington State that aimed to develop HIV prevention and concurrency messaging. This article is based on secondary data collected in key informant interviews (n = 8) and three focus groups (n = 13) with African-born women (N = 21) in Seattle and King County, Washington. Thematic data analysis was used for analysis. Three predominant themes for African-born women were (1) lack of knowledge or awareness of HIV prevalence and its intersection with concurrency; (2) ambivalent silence as a reaction to concurrency; and (3) gender differences in perceptions of concurrency. African-born women perceived HIV as a problem in Africa and not in the United States. The second theme illustrated sociocultural pressures on women that silence them from voicing their concerns about partners' concurrent relationships and their risks of HIV infection. Gender differences in perceptions of concurrent practices favoring men were also highlighted. Results suggest a need for prevention interventions promoting sexual health communication among African-born women and their communities and culturally appropriate education. These components may be critical for breaking the silence and improving HIV prevention interventions. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Breaking+the+Silence%3A+Interpreting+African-Born+Women%27s+Knowledge+about+HIV+and+Concurrency&amp;rft.au=Tecle%2C+Aster+Solomon%3BAndrasik%2C+Michele&amp;rft.aulast=Tecle&amp;rft.aufirst=Aster&amp;rft.date=2015-05-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=E32&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
