____________________________________________________________

Coexisting principles and logics of elder care: Help to self-help and consumer-oriented service?

Author: Dahl, Hanne Marlene; Eskelinen, Leena; Hansen, Eigil Boll

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2015): 287-295.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1688840993?accountid=14667

Abstract: Healthy and active ageing has become an ideal in Western societies. In the Nordic countries, this ideal has been supported through a policy of help to self-help in elder care since the 1980s. However, reforms inspired by New Public Management (NPM) have introduced a new policy principle of consumer-oriented service that stresses the wishes and priorities of older people. We have studied how these two principles are applied by care workers in Denmark. Is one principle or logic replacing the other, or do they coexist? Do they create tensions between professional knowledge and the autonomy of older people? Using neo-institutional theory and feminist care theory, we analysed the articulation of the two policy principles in interviews and their logics in observations in four local authorities. We conclude that help to self-help is the dominant principle, that it is deeply entrenched in the identity of the professional care worker and that it coexists with consumer-oriented service and without major tensions in the logics identified in their practices.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Coexisting+principles+and+logics+of+elder+care%3A+Help+to+self-help+and+consumer-oriented+service%3F&amp;rft.au=Dahl%2C+Hanne+Marlene%3BEskelinen%2C+Leena%3BHansen%2C+Eigil+Boll&amp;rft.aulast=Dahl&amp;rft.aufirst=Hanne&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=287&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12141

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Coexisting+principles+and+logics+of+elder+care%3A+Help+to+self-help+and+consumer-oriented+service%3F&amp;rft.au=Dahl%2C+Hanne+Marlene%3BEskelinen%2C+Leena%3BHansen%2C+Eigil+Boll&amp;rft.aulast=Dahl&amp;rft.aufirst=Hanne&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=287&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12141

Engaging men for gender justice: Overcoming barriers to girls' education in the Pashtun tribes of Pakistan

Author: Jamal, Aamir

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2015): 273-286.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1688840994?accountid=14667

Abstract: Resistance to girls' education is a social justice and human rights issue in many countries. In Pakistan, where the lowest school enrollment for girls is in Pashtun areas bordering Afghanistan, it is especially problematic. Pashtun society is patriarchal: Men have the power to construct obstacles to girls' education, and to remove them. This article therefore explores a different way of overcoming barriers to gender justice, namely through the participation of men. A qualitative Delphi process and in-depth interviews with Pashtun men led to their consensus on seven key points of leverage where action could be taken. Participants agreed that progress toward gender parity could be achieved only by making allies of powerful community leaders, especially religious leaders, and by utilizing existing institutions, such as the mosque, Jirga (council of elders), and the men's guest house. For each point of leverage, a policy recommendation is made for increasing girls' participation in education.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Engaging+men+for+gender+justice%3A+Overcoming+barriers+to+girls%27+education+in+the+Pashtun+tribes+of+Pakistan&amp;rft.au=Jamal%2C+Aamir&amp;rft.aulast=Jamal&amp;rft.aufirst=Aamir&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=273&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12118

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Engaging+men+for+gender+justice%3A+Overcoming+barriers+to+girls%27+education+in+the+Pashtun+tribes+of+Pakistan&amp;rft.au=Jamal%2C+Aamir&amp;rft.aulast=Jamal&amp;rft.aufirst=Aamir&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=273&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12118

Optimizing the "demographic dividend" in young developing countries: The role of contractual savings and insurance for financing education

Author: Ssewamala, Fred M

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare ; Oxford  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2015): 248-262.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1688840997?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many developing regions are facing a youth bulge, meaning that young people comprise the highest proportion of the population. These regions are at risk of losing what could be a tremendous opportunity for economic growth and development if they do not capitalize on this young and economically productive population, also referred to as the "demographic dividend," defined as the increase in economic growth that tends to follow increases in the ratio of the working-age population - essentially the labor force - to dependents. Nations undergoing this population transition have the opportunity to capitalize on the demographic dividend if the right social, economic, and human capital policies are in place. In particular, Sub-Saharan Africa, the Middle East, and North Africa are at risk of losing the demographic dividend. These regions face high youth unemployment, low primary school completion, and low secondary school enrollment. This results in an undereducated and unskilled segment of the population. The prohibitive costs of education prevent young people from finishing school, thereby entering the labor market unprepared. This article presents a case for youth-focused financial inclusion programs as one of the antidotes to the masses of poor, undereducated, and low-skilled young people swelling the labor markets of poor developing countries.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Optimizing+the+%22demographic+dividend%22+in+young+developing+countries%3A+The+role+of+contractual+savings+and+insurance+for+financing+education&amp;rft.au=Ssewamala%2C+Fred+M&amp;rft.aulast=Ssewamala&amp;rft.aufirst=Fred&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=248&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12131

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Optimizing+the+%22demographic+dividend%22+in+young+developing+countries%3A+The+role+of+contractual+savings+and+insurance+for+financing+education&amp;rft.au=Ssewamala%2C+Fred+M&amp;rft.aulast=Ssewamala&amp;rft.aufirst=Fred&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=248&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12131

Research Note-Program Evaluation: Enhancing Academic Quality and Program Integrity During Rapid Off-Campus Growth

Author: Pruitt, Doyle K.; Silverman, Ed

Publication info: Journal of Social Work Education ; Washington  Vol. 51, Iss. 3,  (Jul-Sep 2015): 595-603.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1696027897?accountid=14667

Abstract: By creating a program evaluation model that assesses multiple components from several perspectives, a social work division is able to determine the quality, effectiveness, and integrity of its offerings and support its mission to develop social work students for practice. This task is critical in supporting an off-campus program's ability to navigate change and uncertainty in higher education. This research note discusses how a small, bachelor of social work program with a dual-delivery system (traditional and community-site) used the Council on Social Work Education reaccreditation process to adapt its program evaluation to ensure academic quality and program integrity during a period of rapid growth.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.atitle=Research+Note-Program+Evaluation%3A+Enhancing+Academic+Quality+and+Program+Integrity+During+Rapid+Off-Campus+Growth&amp;rft.au=Pruitt%2C+Doyle+K.%3BSilverman%2C+Ed&amp;rft.aulast=Pruitt&amp;rft.aufirst=Doyle&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=51&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=595&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Education&amp;rft.issn=10437797&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F10437797.2015.1043206

'More time for what?' Exploring intersecting notions of gender, work, age and leisure time among people with cognitive disabilities

Author: Lovgren, Veronica1; Rosqvist, Hanna Bertilsdotter1 Department of Social Work, Umea University, Umea, Sweden.

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (July 2015): 263-272.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650583?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores intersecting notions of leisure among middle-aged people with intellectual disabilities in the setting of the Swedish welfare state. The participants are recipients of long-term disability services and have experienced the changing ideological frameworks of the welfare effort, which has recently focused on normalisation, inclusion and participation. Structured activities are arranged by disability services in order to normalise living conditions and provide recreation for disabled people. However, the range of activities is constrained by financial resources, by notions of gender and age and by an institutionalised emphasis on the work ethic - leading to constructions of leisure partly as 'time beside' where 'free time' activities should not interfere with the duties of the working week. The participants' limited resources and their lack of a strong voice limit their ability to demand their legal rights and leave many of them with 'too much time with too little to do'. Key Practitioner Message: A common idea of leisure is the relationship between social and physical activities, well-being and health; People with disabilities, regardless of age, engage in fewer leisure activities than the general population due to a lack of resources; Even with legal rights, the lack of a strong voice as well as institutional constraints limit their leisure opportunities. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=%27More+time+for+what%3F%27+Exploring+intersecting+notions+of+gender%2C+work%2C+age+and+leisure+time+among+people+with+cognitive+disabilities&amp;rft.au=Lovgren%2C+Veronica%3BRosqvist%2C+Hanna+Bertilsdotter&amp;rft.aulast=Lovgren&amp;rft.aufirst=Veronica&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=263&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12135

____________________________________________________________

Impact of enforcing a statutory minimum wage on work and quality of life of vulnerable groups in Hong Kong

Author: Wong, Hung1; Ye, Shengquan1 Department of Social Work, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, N.T, Hong Kong.

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (July 2015): 223-235.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650621?accountid=14667

Abstract: The statutory minimum wage (SMW) law was enforced in Hong Kong on 1 May 2011. To examine its impact, this longitudinal study measured the quality of life, job and pay satisfaction, monthly income, hourly rate and working hours of vulnerable groups (n = 253) before and after the legislation. The findings confirmed that the enforcement of the SMW induced a positive impact as intended. The introduction of the SMW induced a positive wage and employment effect on the vulnerable groups in Hong Kong without harming their employment rate. Job and pay satisfaction, as well as most domains of the quality of life (i.e., physical and psychological health, and environment), increased significantly. In general, the positive impact of the SMW was more prominent for employees who previously worked less than 18 hours a week and who had hourly rates less than 28 HKD. The implications of the findings are discussed in the social context of Hong Kong. Key Practitioner Message: Enforcing minimum wage induced a positive impact on quality of life, job and pay satisfaction, and a monthly income of vulnerable groups. The social relations (quality of life) decreased after implementing minimum wage for workers working longer than 18 hours a week. Longer working hours is a key factor for the increase of a monthly income among the vulnerable groups. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Impact+of+enforcing+a+statutory+minimum+wage+on+work+and+quality+of+life+of+vulnerable+groups+in+Hong+Kong&amp;rft.au=Wong%2C+Hung%3BYe%2C+Shengquan&amp;rft.aulast=Wong&amp;rft.aufirst=Hung&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=223&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12117

The impact of child benefits on single mother poverty: Exploring the role of targeting in 15 European countries

Author: Van Lancker, Wim1; Ghysels, Joris; Cantillon, Bea1 Research Foundation - Flanders (FWO), Brussels, Belgium.

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (July 2015): 210-222.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650717?accountid=14667

Abstract: Single mothers are vulnerable to living in poverty. The question of how to safeguard the economic status of single mothers in a context of increasing dual earnership is a crucial one. In the present study we addressed this issue by investigating the impact of child benefits on the poverty risk of single mothers in 15 European countries. We focused in particular on the design of child benefits and investigated whether targeting towards single mothers was associated with better poverty reduction. In doing so, we combined information on statutory child benefit entitlement with an empirical analysis of poverty reduction using survey data. We found that: (i) both spending effort and targeting are important to explain the effectiveness of child benefits in reducing single mother poverty; (ii) targeting is related to higher levels of poverty reduction independent of spending effort; yet (iii) it matters how targeting is done. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=The+impact+of+child+benefits+on+single+mother+poverty%3A+Exploring+the+role+of+targeting+in+15+European+countries&amp;rft.au=Van+Lancker%2C+Wim%3BGhysels%2C+Joris%3BCantillon%2C+Bea&amp;rft.aulast=Van+Lancker&amp;rft.aufirst=Wim&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=210&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12140

Poverty and quality of life of Chinese children: From the perspective of deprivation

Author: Wong, Yu-Cheung1; Wang, Ting-Yan; Xu, Yuebin1 The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China.

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (July 2015): 236-247.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650835?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using data from the Family and Children Survey of Beijing 2011, the authors constructed a child poverty measure - Child Deprivation Indicators (CDIs) - and explored the relationship between poverty and children's quality of life. The CDIs were found to be a more valid child poverty measure than the conventional measure which is based mainly on individuals' social assistance status. The findings show that deprived children are worse off in terms of living conditions. Furthermore, deprived boys and girls are disadvantaged differently; boys in self-efficacy and girls in physical development. The findings have four important implications: (i) policy makers should look beyond those on social assistance; (ii) more public funding should be invested in deprived children's informal education and social interaction; (iii) dealing with structural problems relating to parents' socioeconomic status (SES) would be helpful to alleviate child deprivation; (iv) different types of support should be provided to deprived boys and girls for their disadvantages are not identical. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Poverty+and+quality+of+life+of+Chinese+children%3A+From+the+perspective+of+deprivation&amp;rft.au=Wong%2C+Yu-Cheung%3BWang%2C+Ting-Yan%3BXu%2C+Yuebin&amp;rft.aulast=Wong&amp;rft.aufirst=Yu-Cheung&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=236&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12115

Coexisting principles and logics of elder care: Help to self-help and consumer-oriented service?

Author: Dahl, Hanne Marlene1; Eskelinen, Leena; Hansen, Eigil Boll1 Department of Society and Globalization, Roskilde University, Roskilde, Denmark.

Publication info: International Journal of Social Welfare  Vol. 24, Iss. 3,  (July 2015): 287-295.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1735650892?accountid=14667

Abstract: Healthy and active ageing has become an ideal in Western societies. In the Nordic countries, this ideal has been supported through a policy of help to self-help in elder care since the 1980s. However, reforms inspired by New Public Management (NPM) have introduced a new policy principle of consumer-oriented service that stresses the wishes and priorities of older people. We have studied how these two principles are applied by care workers in Denmark. Is one principle or logic replacing the other, or do they coexist? Do they create tensions between professional knowledge and the autonomy of older people? Using neo-institutional theory and feminist care theory, we analysed the articulation of the two policy principles in interviews and their logics in observations in four local authorities. We conclude that help to self-help is the dominant principle, that it is deeply entrenched in the identity of the professional care worker and that it coexists with consumer-oriented service and without major tensions in the logics identified in their practices. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Coexisting+principles+and+logics+of+elder+care%3A+Help+to+self-help+and+consumer-oriented+service%3F&amp;rft.au=Dahl%2C+Hanne+Marlene%3BEskelinen%2C+Leena%3BHansen%2C+Eigil+Boll&amp;rft.aulast=Dahl&amp;rft.aufirst=Hanne&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=287&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12141

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.atitle=Coexisting+principles+and+logics+of+elder+care%3A+Help+to+self-help+and+consumer-oriented+service%3F&amp;rft.au=Dahl%2C+Hanne+Marlene%3BEskelinen%2C+Leena%3BHansen%2C+Eigil+Boll&amp;rft.aulast=Dahl&amp;rft.aufirst=Hanne&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=287&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Journal+of+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.issn=13696866&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1111%2Fijsw.12141

Perceptions and Experiences of Cyberbullying at a Faith-Based University

Author: Slovak, Karen; Crabbs, Hannah; Stryffeler, Ben

Publication info: Social Work and Christianity ; Botsford  Vol. 42, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2015): 149-164.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1738841465?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although cyberbullying is a growing concern, there has been little research exploring the levels of this phenomenon at the college level. Furthermore, this growing field of research has not examined the role of spiritual faith as a mediating variable. This study examined both of these variables in relation to cyberbullying. Data from this study came from a survey of students (n=282) at a small Midwest faith based university. Results indicated that cyberbullying occurred on the campus with a little over 20% reporting experiencing cyberbullying at some level and about the same amount stating they had posted hurtful things online. Level of faith appeared to have a buffering effect on cyberbullying experiences and perceptions. Implications suggest that universities, including those of faith, are not immune to this phenomenon and that steps can be taken to address the issue from a social work systems perspective.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Perceptions+and+Experiences+of+Cyberbullying+at+a+Faith-Based+University&amp;rft.au=Slovak%2C+Karen%3BCrabbs%2C+Hannah%3BStryffeler%2C+Ben&amp;rft.aulast=Slovak&amp;rft.aufirst=Karen&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Role of African American Churches in Promoting Health Among Congregations

Author: Collins, Wanda Lott

Publication info: Social Work and Christianity ; Botsford  Vol. 42, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2015): 193-204.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1738841541?accountid=14667

Abstract: In nearly every key indicator of well-being, African Americans continue to fare worse than White Americans do as it relates to chronic illness and death. This article discusses health promotion strategies that social workers and faith-based practitioners can propose to African American pastors and congregants for successful community collaborations to reduce health disparities. Health promotion strategies such as speaking about health issues from the pulpit, adopting proactive practices to support kitchen committees, appointing a congregational health ministry, and building academic and church partnerships are discussed. The goal of this article is to describe practical health behavior strategies that can capitalize on the strengths, social networks, and institutional history of African American churches that can promote health and wellness among congregations.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=The+Role+of+African+American+Churches+in+Promoting+Health+Among+Congregations&amp;rft.au=Collins%2C+Wanda+Lott&amp;rft.aulast=Collins&amp;rft.aufirst=Wanda&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=193&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Conducting Measurement Invariance Tests with Ordinal Data: A Guide for Social Work Researchers

Author: Bowen, Natasha K; Masa, Rainier D

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2015): 229.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837558?accountid=14667

Abstract: The validity of measures across groups is a major concern for social work researchers and practitioners. Many social workers use scales, or sets of questionnaire items, with ordinal response options. This article synthesizes information from the literature and provides recommendations for appropriate measurement invariance procedures with ordinal data. The authors use data from the Cebu Longitudinal Health and Nutrition Survey to demonstrate applications of invariance testing with ordinal data. They describe 2 competing approaches: a 4-step approach, in which factor loadings and thresholds are tested and constrained separately; and a 3-step approach, in which loadings and thresholds are tested and constrained in tandem. Both approaches lead to the same conclusion that the 2 dimensions of the PSS are noninvariant across health status. Use of appropriate methods for invariance testing will reduce misuse of measures in practice and improve the rigor and quality of social work publications.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Conducting+Measurement+Invariance+Tests+with+Ordinal+Data%3A+A+Guide+for+Social+Work+Researchers&amp;rft.au=Bowen%2C+Natasha+K%3BMasa%2C+Rainier+D&amp;rft.aulast=Bowen&amp;rft.aufirst=Natasha&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=229&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Conducting+Measurement+Invariance+Tests+with+Ordinal+Data%3A+A+Guide+for+Social+Work+Researchers&amp;rft.au=Bowen%2C+Natasha+K%3BMasa%2C+Rainier+D&amp;rft.aulast=Bowen&amp;rft.aufirst=Natasha&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=229&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Food Insufficiency: Evidence from a Statewide Probability Sample

Author: Nam, Yunju; Huang, Jin; Heflin, Colleen; Sherraden, Michael

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2015): 201.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837917?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examines racial/ethnic disparities in the experience of food insufficiency among families with infants, focusing on the roles of socioeconomic characteristics. The authors examine the SEED for Oklahoma Kids experiment data collected from a probability sample of White, African American, American Indian, and Hispanic caregivers of infants randomly selected from Oklahoma&apos;s birth certificates (N= 2,652). Data are analyzed using Fairlie&apos;s extension of the Blinder-Oaxaca decomposition. Whites experience food insufficiency at a statistically significantly lower rate than do the 3 minority groups. Estimates suggest most of the racial/ethnic disparity in food insufficiency is explained by compositional differences in economic and noneconomic resources between Whites and minority groups. In particular, lower levels of asset ownership and access to credit among minority groups are estimated to contribute to higher levels of food insufficiency in comparison with Whites. Higher levels of food insufficiency among racial/ethnic minority families call for interventions for these families.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Racial+and+Ethnic+Disparities+in+Food+Insufficiency%3A+Evidence+from+a+Statewide+Probability+Sample&amp;rft.au=Nam%2C+Yunju%3BHuang%2C+Jin%3BHeflin%2C+Colleen%3BSherraden%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Nam&amp;rft.aufirst=Yunju&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=201&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Racial+and+Ethnic+Disparities+in+Food+Insufficiency%3A+Evidence+from+a+Statewide+Probability+Sample&amp;rft.au=Nam%2C+Yunju%3BHuang%2C+Jin%3BHeflin%2C+Colleen%3BSherraden%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Nam&amp;rft.aufirst=Yunju&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=201&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Confirmatory Factor Analysis of the Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children in an At-Risk Sample of Youth

Author: Butcher, Fredrick; Kretschmar, Jeff M; Singer, Mark I; Flannery, Daniel J

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2015): 251.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837984?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children (TSCC) is a widely used assessment tool in both community and clinical samples. Although the reliability and validity of the TSCC has been studied extensively, its factor structure has been understudied. Particularly, researchers have conceptualized the TSCC as a summative total scale score without evidence of its psychometric property. The current study examines the factor structure of the TSCC conceptualized as a total score using second-order confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) in a large sample of juvenile justice involved youth (N = 2,268). Results indicate that a total score does not fit the data. However, an alternative model that included 2 factors that grouped together (a) anxiety, dissociation, and posttraumatic stress with (b) anger and depression fit the data well. Although the findings do not support the use of the TSCC as a total score, a 2-factor solution provides a more parsimonious conceptualization of the TSCC.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Confirmatory+Factor+Analysis+of+the+Trauma+Symptom+Checklist+for+Children+in+an+At-Risk+Sample+of+Youth&amp;rft.au=Butcher%2C+Fredrick%3BKretschmar%2C+Jeff+M%3BSinger%2C+Mark+I%3BFlannery%2C+Daniel+J&amp;rft.aulast=Butcher&amp;rft.aufirst=Fredrick&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=251&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Confirmatory+Factor+Analysis+of+the+Trauma+Symptom+Checklist+for+Children+in+an+At-Risk+Sample+of+Youth&amp;rft.au=Butcher%2C+Fredrick%3BKretschmar%2C+Jeff+M%3BSinger%2C+Mark+I%3BFlannery%2C+Daniel+J&amp;rft.aulast=Butcher&amp;rft.aufirst=Fredrick&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=251&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

﻿Social Work Research: 2044﻿

Author: Howard, Matthew O; Garland, Eric L

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2015): 173.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794838030?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work research is currently in the midst of a pervasive and portentous identity conflict that could pose existential problems vis-a-vis its future viability. The Digital Revolution and the Information Age it wrought have contributed significantly to the growth of social work science between 1984 and 2014. A contemporaneous Era of Emulation arose in social work, involving the widespread importation of research and statistical methods of more advanced social and health sciences (along with the researchers themselves in these fields) into schools of social work. Digital Age developments and Emulation Era benefits led to substantially increased production of social work research as compared with the past scientific generation, in the absence of significant growth in the number of social work earned doctorates. Still, much could be done to improve the quality and increase the quantity of social work research. This article presents a host of proposals to improve social work doctoral education, publication practices, research funding and infrastructure, and performance appraisal that could do much to advance the research mission of the profession. Worrisome developments in science generally—the replication crisis, fraud, problematic peer review and predatory publishing—with implications for social work research are also discussed. Current efforts to resolve social work’s identity crisis by defining a science of social work and identifying a set of Grand Challenges for social work research are critiqued.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=%EF%BB%BFSocial+Work+Research%3A+2044%EF%BB%BF&amp;rft.au=Howard%2C+Matthew+O%3BGarland%2C+Eric+L&amp;rft.aulast=Howard&amp;rft.aufirst=Matthew&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=173&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=%EF%BB%BFSocial+Work+Research%3A+2044%EF%BB%BF&amp;rft.au=Howard%2C+Matthew+O%3BGarland%2C+Eric+L&amp;rft.aulast=Howard&amp;rft.aufirst=Matthew&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=173&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Racial Respect: Initial Testing and Validation of the Racial Respect Scale: For Adult African Americans

Author: Briggs, Harold; Kothari, Brianne; Briggs, Adam Christopher; Bank, Lew; DeGruy, Joy

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 2,  (Summer 2015): 269.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794838055?accountid=14667

Abstract: To investigate the utility of an adapted version of a racial respect scale originally developed for African American youth. The authors modified the scales for gender-specific use with adult African Americans, and added a subscale to assess racial respect related to romantic partnerships. The newly developed African American Respect Scale -- Women (AARS-W) and African American Respect Scale -- Men (AARS-M) are psychometrically tested with samples of adult African Americans (N = 278) recruited in 3 US cities: Portland, Oregon; St. Louis, MO; and Washington, DC, which were selected to represent the diversity in East Coast, Midwest, and West Coast populations. Findings from the current study provide evidence that racial respect predicts prosocial adaptive identity and is associated with participation in prosocial activities and positive health outcomes while the lack of it predicts maladaptive identity and poor mental health adjustment as well as the lack of access to the social determinants of health such as adequate education and employment opportunities.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Racial+Respect%3A+Initial+Testing+and+Validation+of+the+Racial+Respect+Scale%3A+For+Adult+African+Americans&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Harold%3BKothari%2C+Brianne%3BBriggs%2C+Adam+Christopher%3BBank%2C+Lew%3BDeGruy%2C+Joy&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Harold&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=269&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Interrogating the Child Marriage and the Age of Consent Conundrum

Author: Gupta, Pallavi

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2015): 425.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946394?accountid=14667

Abstract: The recent judgement that the legal system cannot be used to punish youngsters (minors) in love and are on the verge of attaining majority calls for revisiting the debate on the age of consent; especially since it is closely linked to the issue of child marriage. In an environment of heightened cultural policing against relationships/marriages of choice that break caste, class and religious barriers, this Judgement interrogates taboos surrounding sexuality and relationships.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Interrogating+the+Child+Marriage+and+the+Age+of+Consent+Conundrum&amp;rft.au=Gupta%2C+Pallavi&amp;rft.aulast=Gupta&amp;rft.aufirst=Pallavi&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=425&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Interrogating+the+Child+Marriage+and+the+Age+of+Consent+Conundrum&amp;rft.au=Gupta%2C+Pallavi&amp;rft.aulast=Gupta&amp;rft.aufirst=Pallavi&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=425&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Taboos; Sexuality; Children; Caste systems; Investigations (Law enforcement); Legal system

Title: Interrogating the Child Marriage and the Age of Consent Conundrum

Publication title: Indian Journal of Social Work; Bombay

Volume: 76

Issue: 3

First page: 425

Publication year: 2015

The Sibling Bond and Perceptions about Family interaction among Adolescent School-going Girls

Author: Bammidi, Smita

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2015): 401.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946495?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study sample comprises 84 school-going adolescent girls from higher income families of urban Bangalore, India. The focus of the study was on understanding the various dimensions of sibling relationships and to examine the respondents&apos; perceptions about family interactions, and whether they impinged on one another In a dynamic context. It was found that socio-demographic factors influenced both the variables. Higher empathy, similarity and lower levels of boundary maintenance, coercion among siblings were co-existent with the perceived higher intimacy and lesser conflict between parents, and a positive parenting style. Hence, therapeutic interventions in the sibling subsystem may bring positive changes in the family system and vice versa.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Sibling+Bond+and+Perceptions+about+Family+interaction+among+Adolescent+School-going+Girls&amp;rft.au=Bammidi%2C+Smita&amp;rft.aulast=Bammidi&amp;rft.aufirst=Smita&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=401&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Stress, Social Support and SWB of Older Adults in Mumbal

Author: Burnette, Denise; Soletti, Asha Banu; Sridhar, Rama

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2015): 351.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946726?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study extends the use of Stress Process Model (SPM) to older adults in a rapidly developing country, confirming the multidimensional nature of subjective well-being. Using the SPM, adopted hierarchical multiple regression to test four hypotheses: 1) life-stressors are negatively associated with depressive symptoms; 2) life-stressors are positively associated with global life satisfaction; 3) social support mediate the relationship between life-stressors and depressive symptoms; and 4) social support will mediate relationship between life stressors and global life satisfaction. Life-stressors were strongly associated with depressive symptoms and significantly but somewhat less strongly associated with global life-satisfaction. Social support partially mediated both relationships.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Stress%2C+Social+Support+and+SWB+of+Older+Adults+in+Mumbal&amp;rft.au=Burnette%2C+Denise%3BSoletti%2C+Asha+Banu%3BSridhar%2C+Rama&amp;rft.aulast=Burnette&amp;rft.aufirst=Denise&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=351&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Stress%2C+Social+Support+and+SWB+of+Older+Adults+in+Mumbal&amp;rft.au=Burnette%2C+Denise%3BSoletti%2C+Asha+Banu%3BSridhar%2C+Rama&amp;rft.aulast=Burnette&amp;rft.aufirst=Denise&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=351&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work in India: Do We Love being at Crossroads?

Author: Agnimitra, Neera; Jha, Manoj K; Shahid, Mohd

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2015): 331.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946731?accountid=14667

Abstract: Teaching as well as practice in India has been more favourably inclined towards engaging with issues and domains which remain within its comfort zones. The profession is still undergoing the existential crisis and that is why the tag of being &apos;at the crossroads&apos; is unrelentingly &apos;rear even now. Under the garb of the popularly held belief that &apos;social work has to be apolitical&apos;, schools of social work and practitioners have opted to carve out a convenient functional niche that singularly avoids any encounter with a discomforting agenda, and prevents its constituents from taking a counter-hegemonic posture. Keeping in view the endemic nature of oppression, and its frequent manifestation in violence based on gender, caste, and religion, the schools of social work in India, need to review their thrust/objectives, courses and praxis. A Gramscian framework is used to make sense of the popular professional perceptions (common sense) on social work teaching and practice. Examining the value bases and world views which inform the teaching and practice of social work, this article argues for integrating the values of human rights and social justice. The article cautions the social workers from becoming what Gramsci calls the dominant group "duputies" exercising the subaltern functions of social hegemony.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+in+India%3A+Do+We+Love+being+at+Crossroads%3F&amp;rft.au=Agnimitra%2C+Neera%3BJha%2C+Manoj+K%3BShahid%2C+Mohd&amp;rft.aulast=Agnimitra&amp;rft.aufirst=Neera&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=331&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Interventions for Runaway and Homeless Youth: Stepping Back and Critically Summarising the Social Responses

Author: Saldanha, Kennedy

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 3,  (Jul 2015): 373.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946914?accountid=14667

Abstract: Visible attention to youth homelessness is not recent. Literature demonstrates the issue has always raised concerns and invited responses. However, different conceptualisations of looking at youth homelessness such as delinquency, psychopathology, or the result of family abuse, have resulted in a variability of responses. Interventions are offered through child protection, HIV/AIDS treatment, substance abuse interventions or establishing of drop-ins and emergency shelters. But there is a need for multicausal comprehensive interventions, evaluation of their outcomes and learning from all stakeholders globally. It is time for areas like South Asia to rigorously evaluate and share some of their unique interventions and best practices for homeless youth and street children.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Interventions+for+Runaway+and+Homeless+Youth%3A+Stepping+Back+and+Critically+Summarising+the+Social+Responses&amp;rft.au=Saldanha%2C+Kennedy&amp;rft.aulast=Saldanha&amp;rft.aufirst=Kennedy&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=373&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

FIELDWORK SUPERVISION: MEETING REQUIREMENTS OF SOCIAL WORK EDUCATION THROUGH CRITICAL THINKING

Author: Sharma, Seema

Publication info: Hong Kong Journal of Social Work = Xiang Gang She Hui Gong Zuo Xue Bao ; Singapore  Vol. 49, Iss. 1/2,  (Summer 2015): 3.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1823980487?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper highlights the process of supervision that aims to developing critical thinking amongst social work students by consciously creating spaces for them, so as to enable them to reflect upon their own position and the social context within which the individuals, groups and societies exist. It is hoped that the paper will generate debate as well as a critical and constructive evaluation of the role of supervision in the context of third world countries, which face the problem of structural inequality in their societies. The paper is also expected to provide insights for fieldwork supervisors who may wish to challenge their students to question the existing status quo in the society. The paper is based entirely on the author's experiences as a field work supervisor, her observations and discussions with students during individual conferences, group meetings, community field visits and through fieldwork reports of the students.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work+%3D+Xiang+Gang+She+Hui+Gong+Zuo+Xue+Bao&amp;rft.atitle=FIELDWORK+SUPERVISION%3A+MEETING+REQUIREMENTS+OF+SOCIAL+WORK+EDUCATION+THROUGH+CRITICAL+THINKING&amp;rft.au=Sharma%2C+Seema&amp;rft.aulast=Sharma&amp;rft.aufirst=Seema&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=49&amp;rft.issue=1%2F2&amp;rft.spage=3&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work+%3D+Xiang+Gang+She+Hui+Gong+Zuo+Xue+Bao&amp;rft.issn=02192462&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

ENHANCING STUDENTS' LEARNING IN SOCIAL WORK FIELD PRACTICUM

Author: Cheung, Sandra Oi-ngor

Publication info: Hong Kong Journal of Social Work = Xiang Gang She Hui Gong Zuo Xue Bao ; Singapore  Vol. 49, Iss. 1/2,  (Summer 2015): 15.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1823980491?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work education comprises an indispensable part ? the field practicum, as revealed in the curricula of social work degree programmes all over the world. Here the question is about the positivist curriculum design and fieldwork assessment, which reduces human understanding to matters of technicality. There is a growing discussion about the reflective paradigm - practice wisdom - in human professions, which may be deemed to be more desirable for accommodating the nature of social work practice. A four-dimension framework is developed for the epistemological understanding of practice wisdom, in order to guide research on unravelling how practice teachers exercise pedagogical practice wisdom in advancing students' learning. The findings reveal student factor that might hinder or facilitate practice teachers in bringing pedagogical practice wisdom to their teaching. Implications for those concerned with the enhancement of students' learning in social work field practicum, particularly social work educators, are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work+%3D+Xiang+Gang+She+Hui+Gong+Zuo+Xue+Bao&amp;rft.atitle=ENHANCING+STUDENTS%27+LEARNING+IN+SOCIAL+WORK+FIELD+PRACTICUM&amp;rft.au=Cheung%2C+Sandra+Oi-ngor&amp;rft.aulast=Cheung&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=49&amp;rft.issue=1%2F2&amp;rft.spage=15&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work+%3D+Xiang+Gang+She+Hui+Gong+Zuo+Xue+Bao&amp;rft.issn=02192462&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

DO MALE VICTIMS OF INTIMATE PARTNER VIOLENCE (IPV) DESERVE HELP? SOME REFLECTIONS BASED ON A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW

Author: Tsang, Wallace Wai-Hung

Publication info: Hong Kong Journal of Social Work = Xiang Gang She Hui Gong Zuo Xue Bao ; Singapore  Vol. 49, Iss. 1/2,  (Summer 2015): 51.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1823980498?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on a systematic review of 32 articles on help-seeking by male victims of intimate partner violence (IPV), this study attempts to understand why men tend not to seek help in IPV. The review of the selected literature establishes that male victimization in IPV is a real problem. However, men tend not to seek help for a variety of reasons, most of which are attributable to either psychological factors or external service barriers. Based on the findings of this study, the implications of the failure to deliver social services to men suffering various forms of domestic violence are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work+%3D+Xiang+Gang+She+Hui+Gong+Zuo+Xue+Bao&amp;rft.atitle=DO+MALE+VICTIMS+OF+INTIMATE+PARTNER+VIOLENCE+%28IPV%29+DESERVE+HELP%3F+SOME+REFLECTIONS+BASED+ON+A+SYSTEMATIC+REVIEW&amp;rft.au=Tsang%2C+Wallace+Wai-Hung&amp;rft.aulast=Tsang&amp;rft.aufirst=Wallace&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=49&amp;rft.issue=1%2F2&amp;rft.spage=51&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Hong+Kong+Journal+of+Social+Work+%3D+Xiang+Gang+She+Hui+Gong+Zuo+Xue+Bao&amp;rft.issn=02192462&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

LEADERSHIP SUPPORT OF SUPERVISION IN SOCIAL WORK PRACTICE: Challenges and Enablers to Achieving Success

Author: Vito, Rosemary

Publication info: Canadian Social Work Review = Review Canadienne de Services Social ; Ottawa  Vol. 32, Iss. 2,  (2015): 151-165.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825962876?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses research findings that highlight the importance of leadership support of supervision for social workers in human service organizations. While supervision is considered a cornerstone of social work practice, whether and how such supervision is supported by human service leaders is not adequately analyzed. Using qualitative research data from interviews with supervisors and managers in southern Ontario, this article presents the vital role social work leaders play in supporting supervision by modelling values, and creating a safe organizational culture. The challenges of providing this support are also discussed in the current context of new public management. The article concludes with a series of recommendations, including: prioritizing supervision to promote organizational learning, organizational restructuring to reduce power differentials, modelling social work values to create a safe learning culture, and supporting supervisory and leadership training for social workers. Findings may be of interest to social workers who are leading, supervising, teaching or practicing in human service organizations.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.atitle=LEADERSHIP+SUPPORT+OF+SUPERVISION+IN+SOCIAL+WORK+PRACTICE%3A+Challenges+and+Enablers+to+Achieving+Success&amp;rft.au=Vito%2C+Rosemary&amp;rft.aulast=Vito&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosemary&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=151&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.issn=0820909X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

REPRÉSENTATIONS SOCIALES DU VIH/SIDA CHEZ LES ÉTUDIANTS DE NIVEAU UNIVERSITAIRE D'UNE RÉGION ÉLOIGNÉE DU QUÉBEC / SOCIAL REPRESENTATIONS OF HIV / AIDS IN STUDENTS AT A UNIVERSITY LEVEL IN A REMOTE REGION OF QUEBEC

Author: Labra, Oscar; Lacasse, Anaïs

Publication info: Canadian Social Work Review = Review Canadienne de Services Social ; Ottawa  Vol. 32, Iss. 2,  (2015): 167-186.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825963120?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the social representations of HIV/AIDS held by 11 students (six women and five men) attending the Université du Québec en Abitibi-Témiscamingue who participated in two gender-specific discussion groups. The study had two objectives: 1) To describe the social representations of HIV/AIDS held by the students, and 2) To describe the impact of those representations on how the students understand and react toward HIV/AIDS. The participants' discourse reveals a positive attitude and openness toward people living with HIV/AIDS (PLHIV/AIDS), who are perceived as resilient. This capacity for resilience confirms the hypothesis that, rather than dying from the illness as was the case 30 years ago, PLHIV/AIDS can now expect to enjoy fairly stable health. It further demonstrates the dynamic nature of the social representations of HIV/AIDS over time. Our results also show marked differences in prevention mechanisms between genders, with men citing condom use as the most important element and women emphasizing confidence in their sexual partners. The study concludes that social representations of HIV/AIDS constitute an integral part of everyday reality, with these representations being culturally constructed and shared. The study demonstrates the need to develop more robust prevention campaigns for youth, with messages that are differentiated by gender and better able to factor in the cultural dimension of this phenomenon.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.atitle=REPR%C3%89SENTATIONS+SOCIALES+DU+VIH%2FSIDA+CHEZ+LES+%C3%89TUDIANTS+DE+NIVEAU+UNIVERSITAIRE+D%27UNE+R%C3%89GION+%C3%89LOIGN%C3%89E+DU+QU%C3%89BEC+%2F+SOCIAL+REPRESENTATIONS+OF+HIV+%2F+AIDS+IN+STUDENTS+AT+A+UNIVERSITY+LEVEL+IN+A+REMOTE+REGION+OF+QUEBEC&amp;rft.au=Labra%2C+Oscar%3BLacasse%2C+Ana%C3%AFs&amp;rft.aulast=Labra&amp;rft.aufirst=Oscar&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=167&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.issn=0820909X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.atitle=REPR%C3%89SENTATIONS+SOCIALES+DU+VIH%2FSIDA+CHEZ+LES+%C3%89TUDIANTS+DE+NIVEAU+UNIVERSITAIRE+D%27UNE+R%C3%89GION+%C3%89LOIGN%C3%89E+DU+QU%C3%89BEC+%2F+SOCIAL+REPRESENTATIONS+OF+HIV+%2F+AIDS+IN+STUDENTS+AT+A+UNIVERSITY+LEVEL+IN+A+REMOTE+REGION+OF+QUEBEC&amp;rft.au=Labra%2C+Oscar%3BLacasse%2C+Ana%C3%AFs&amp;rft.aulast=Labra&amp;rft.aufirst=Oscar&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=167&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.issn=0820909X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

THE EMOTIONAL CONSEQUENCES OF ORGANIZATIONAL CHANGE

Author: Grenier, Amanda M; Bidgoli, Elham

Publication info: Canadian Social Work Review = Review Canadienne de Services Social ; Ottawa  Vol. 32, Iss. 2,  (2015): 187-205.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825963173?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores the emotional experiences of professionals in a health and social care setting during a process of reform in the Canadian province of Quebec. Characterized as "new public management" or "new managerialism," public health and social care services in a number of countries have undergone reforms since the early 1980s that focus on efficiency and cost reduction (Nadeau, 1996; Hornblow, 1997; Gross, Rosen, & Chinitz, 1998, Anell, 2005; Levine, 2007; Wimbush, Young, & Robertson, 2007). Although differences exist between the cultural and political contexts within which reforms are implemented, reforms regularly involve changing institutional and organizational structures, the implementation of standard procedures, and the generation of outcome measures for service. The process of reform, and the body of knowledge on organizational change however, tend to overlook the flux of emotions that take place in the everyday lives of professionals. This paper reflects on data from 25 individual interviews collected from a critical ethnography of one health and social care setting during a period of provincial health-care reform in Quebec, Canada (2004-2012). The paper provides an in-depth focus on the emotional consequences of reform as an attempt to understand and expose the human costs of change. Three patterns that professionals used to adapt to change and conflict are discussed: internalization of the reform mandate; rationalization; and creating distance between the reform and their professional or personal selves. Important in their own right, the emotions produced in a period of change provide lessons on the general stressors that surround reform, and demonstrate how health and social care professionals are often caught between policy intentions, professional values, and their personal ambitions.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.atitle=THE+EMOTIONAL+CONSEQUENCES+OF+ORGANIZATIONAL+CHANGE&amp;rft.au=Grenier%2C+Amanda+M%3BBidgoli%2C+Elham&amp;rft.aulast=Grenier&amp;rft.aufirst=Amanda&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=187&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.issn=0820909X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.atitle=THE+EMOTIONAL+CONSEQUENCES+OF+ORGANIZATIONAL+CHANGE&amp;rft.au=Grenier%2C+Amanda+M%3BBidgoli%2C+Elham&amp;rft.aulast=Grenier&amp;rft.aufirst=Amanda&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=187&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.issn=0820909X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

ONTARIO'S FAMILY HEALTH TEAMS: Politics Within the Model

Author: Ashcroft, Rachelle

Publication info: Canadian Social Work Review = Review Canadienne de Services Social ; Ottawa  Vol. 32, Iss. 2,  (2015): 117-132.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1825963323?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article provides an overview of political decisions that led up to the implementation of the Ontario Family Health Team (FHT) model. FHTs have broadened primary health care in Ontario by bringing together family physicians with various interdisciplinary professionals. Political decisions have long influenced the shape and need for the FHT model. Knowledge of historically imbedded elements in the FHT model helps to strengthen current and future policy and decision-making. This article is informed by qualitative data collected from interviews with seven policy informants and 29 FHT leaders.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.atitle=ONTARIO%27S+FAMILY+HEALTH+TEAMS%3A+Politics+Within+the+Model&amp;rft.au=Ashcroft%2C+Rachelle&amp;rft.aulast=Ashcroft&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachelle&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=117&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.issn=0820909X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.atitle=ONTARIO%27S+FAMILY+HEALTH+TEAMS%3A+Politics+Within+the+Model&amp;rft.au=Ashcroft%2C+Rachelle&amp;rft.aulast=Ashcroft&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachelle&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=117&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Canadian+Social+Work+Review+%3D+Review+Canadienne+de+Services+Social&amp;rft.issn=0820909X&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Aging in Place vs. Relocation for Older Adults with Neurocognitive Disorder: Applications of Wiseman's Behavioral Model

Author: Kaplan, Daniel B1; Andersen, Troy Christian2; Lehning, Amanda J3; Perry, Tam E41 School of Social Work, Adelphi University, Garden City, New York, USA2 College of Social Work, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah, USA3 School of Social Work, University of Maryland, Baltimore, Maryland, USA4 School of Social Work, Wayne State University, Detroit, Michigan, USA

Publication info: Journal of Gerontological Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2015): 521-538.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1900185755?accountid=14667

Abstract: Some older adults are more vulnerable to housing concerns due to physical and cognitive challenges, including those with a neurocognitive disorder who need extensive support. Environmental gerontology frameworks, including Wiseman's 1980 Behavioral Model of Elderly Migration, have informed scholarship on aging in place and relocation. Understanding Wiseman's model, including considerations for working with families confronting a neurocognitive disorder, can help practitioners ensure that older clients live in settings that best meet their wants and needs.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Aging+in+Place+vs.+Relocation+for+Older+Adults+with+Neurocognitive+Disorder%3A+Applications+of+Wiseman%27s+Behavioral+Model&amp;rft.au=Kaplan%2C+Daniel+B%3BAndersen%2C+Troy+Christian%3BLehning%2C+Amanda+J%3BPerry%2C+Tam+E&amp;rft.aulast=Kaplan&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=521&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2015.1052175

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Aging+in+Place+vs.+Relocation+for+Older+Adults+with+Neurocognitive+Disorder%3A+Applications+of+Wiseman%27s+Behavioral+Model&amp;rft.au=Kaplan%2C+Daniel+B%3BAndersen%2C+Troy+Christian%3BLehning%2C+Amanda+J%3BPerry%2C+Tam+E&amp;rft.aulast=Kaplan&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=521&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2015.1052175

Characterizing Older Adults' Involvement in Naturally Occurring Retirement Community (NORC) Supportive Service Programs

Author: Greenfield, Emily A1; Fedor, James P11 School of Social Work, Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey, New Brunswick, New Jersey, USA

Publication info: Journal of Gerontological Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2015): 449-468.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1900185916?accountid=14667

Abstract: Naturally Occurring Retirement Community (NORC) Supportive Service Programs constitute one of the longest-standing models for age-friendly community initiatives. As a support-focused model, NORC programs typically offer a range of benefits-including direct services, group activities, and broader community development activities-that are intended to engage older adults with diverse needs, preferences, and interests. Moreover, NORC programs are designed to be used according to the needs of the particular participant engaging with them at a particular point in time. This range and flexibility of benefits indicate the importance of more systematically characterizing the ways in which older adults are involved with NORC programs. For this purpose, we used data from in-depth interviews with 35 residents across 6 NORC programs in New York City. Qualitative analysis revealed 6 ordered categories of involvement: (a) consciously no involvement; (b) involved, but not consciously; (c) relationship with staff only; (d) selectively involved with a strong sense of security; (e) NORC program leaders; and (f) dependence on the NORC program. Overall, results indicate how older adults' involvement in NORC programs can be characterized beyond their utilization of specific types of services and by their relationship with the program as a whole. Findings suggest the importance for outcomes research on NORC programs and related models to consider subgroup differences by involvement. Results also provide directions for theory development on engagement in voluntary programs, as well as for practice to enhance older adults' involvement in supportive service programs.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Characterizing+Older+Adults%27+Involvement+in+Naturally+Occurring+Retirement+Community+%28NORC%29+Supportive+Service+Programs&amp;rft.au=Greenfield%2C+Emily+A%3BFedor%2C+James+P&amp;rft.aulast=Greenfield&amp;rft.aufirst=Emily&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=449&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2015.1008168

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Characterizing+Older+Adults%27+Involvement+in+Naturally+Occurring+Retirement+Community+%28NORC%29+Supportive+Service+Programs&amp;rft.au=Greenfield%2C+Emily+A%3BFedor%2C+James+P&amp;rft.aulast=Greenfield&amp;rft.aufirst=Emily&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=449&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2015.1008168

Toward the Development of a More Integrated Aged Care Assessment Process for Rural Older Australians: Practitioners' Perspectives

Author: Warburton, Jeni1; Cowan, Suzanne1; Savy, Pauline1; MacPhee, Fiona21 John Richards Initiative, La Trobe Rural Health School (Albury/Wodonga Campus), College of Science, Health and Engineering, La Trobe University, Wodonga, Victoria, Australia2 Integrated Aged Care Assessment Service, Ovens and King Community Health Service, Wangaratta, Australia

Publication info: Journal of Gerontological Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2015): 503-520.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1900185988?accountid=14667

Abstract: There is an identified need for more effective assessment processes in rural Australia, with prior research revealing little knowledge sharing and even duplication across existing services. This article aims to explore the challenges to more closely integrated assessment processes, drawing on interview data with practitioners from three agencies located in the same rural region. Findings highlight the challenges of rural assessment, both demand-driven (more older people with complex needs, geographic isolation) and supply issues (time and distance, funding formulae, workforce shortages). The need for closer collaboration is recognized but significant systemic issues require addressing if it is to be achieved.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Toward+the+Development+of+a+More+Integrated+Aged+Care+Assessment+Process+for+Rural+Older+Australians%3A+Practitioners%27+Perspectives&amp;rft.au=Warburton%2C+Jeni%3BCowan%2C+Suzanne%3BSavy%2C+Pauline%3BMacPhee%2C+Fiona&amp;rft.aulast=Warburton&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeni&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=503&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2015.1041667

Auto Therapy: Using Automobiles as Vehicles for Reminiscence With Older Adults

Author: Anderson, Keith A1; Weber, Katherine V21 School of Social Work, University of Montana, Missoula, Montana, USA2 College of Social Work, The Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio, USA

Publication info: Journal of Gerontological Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 5,  (Jul 2015): 469-483.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1900193647?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reminiscence can be beneficial for older adults and contribute to well-being and ego integrity. In this exploratory pilot study, researchers assessed the feasibility and tolerability of a novel reminiscence intervention using automobiles as the focal point. Nineteen older adults (N = 19) were asked to reminisce using photographs of automobiles from across their lifespan. The RE-AIM framework was used to assess the intervention in terms of reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation, and maintenance. The intervention was well-received, quickly established rapport, and effectively fostered reminiscence. Social workers may find this intervention useful in helping older adults to explore their lives.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Auto+Therapy%3A+Using+Automobiles+as+Vehicles+for+Reminiscence+With+Older+Adults&amp;rft.au=Anderson%2C+Keith+A%3BWeber%2C+Katherine+V&amp;rft.aulast=Anderson&amp;rft.aufirst=Keith&amp;rft.date=2015-07-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.spage=469&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Gerontological+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=01634372&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F01634372.2015.1008169
