Decision Making in Social Work with Families and Children: Developing Decision-Aids Compatible with Cognition

Author: De Bortoli, Lillian; Dolan, Mairead

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 45, Iss. 7,  (Oct 2015): 2142.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732543456?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social work practice occurs under difficult circumstances and often involves using incomplete, conflicting and inaccurate information to carry out complex assessments. Personal and organisational factors impact upon practitioner perceptions and work practices may contribute to errors associated with biased judgement. In the field of social work with families and children, poor decisions have been associated with child injuries and deaths. To assist with decision making, most practitioners adopt either consensus decision-aids, which focus upon the practitioner's intuitive cognitive mode, or actuarial decision-aids, which focus upon the analytical cognitive mode. Modern cognitive theory suggests that these cognitive modes function in tandem -- a finding that has led to the development of a third aid, Structured Professional Judgement (SPJ). We discuss the advantages associated with SPJ such as the increased transparency of decision making, the ability of practitioners to identify and manage uncertainty and use emotions in clinical judgement. Given the success of SPJ in forensic psychology, we believe SPJ is more likely to optimise decision making in social work practice with families and children and produce superior outcomes. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/45/7/2142.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Decision+Making+in+Social+Work+with+Families+and+Children%3A+Developing+Decision-Aids+Compatible+with+Cognition&amp;rft.au=De+Bortoli%2C+Lillian%3BDolan%2C+Mairead&amp;rft.aulast=De+Bortoli&amp;rft.aufirst=Lillian&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=2142&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Decision+Making+in+Social+Work+with+Families+and+Children%3A+Developing+Decision-Aids+Compatible+with+Cognition&amp;rft.au=De+Bortoli%2C+Lillian%3BDolan%2C+Mairead&amp;rft.aulast=De+Bortoli&amp;rft.aufirst=Lillian&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=2142&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Psychometric Properties of the Brief Symptom Inventory in Men under Criminal Justice Involvement: Implications for Forensic Social Workers in Practice Settings

Author: Valera, Pamela; Fullilove, Robert; Cali, Shae; Nunes, Edward; Chiongbian, Victoria; Clark, Wayne; Covey, Lirio

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 45, Iss. 7,  (Oct 2015): 2210.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732543469?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to assess the factor structure and psychometric properties of the original and a revised modification of the Brief Symptom Inventory (BSI) in 259 black and Latino males, aged thirty-five to sixty-seven, who had been released from a New York state prison or a New York City jail. The data were analysed using exploratory factor analysis, principal axis factoring and confirmatory factor analysis. Standardised factor loadings were evaluated at 0.05, model fit was evaluated using the chi-square statistic, and fit indices were examined. Items whose communalities fell below 0.30 were eliminated from the procedure. The findings did not yield the same number of factors as the original BSI, but the revised BSI model fitted the current data better. This modified factor structure reduced the BSI to the nineteen most appropriate items to assess five key common psychiatric symptoms affecting men under community supervision. The results of the current factor structure suggest that the psychiatric disorders experienced by men under community supervision may differ from the populations studied by the original BSI factor structure. Forensic social work ought to examine the psychometric properties of standardised measures for different populations such that appropriate instruments may be specifically targeted and maximised. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/45/7/2210.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Psychometric+Properties+of+the+Brief+Symptom+Inventory+in+Men+under+Criminal+Justice+Involvement%3A+Implications+for+Forensic+Social+Workers+in+Practice+Settings&amp;rft.au=Valera%2C+Pamela%3BFullilove%2C+Robert%3BCali%2C+Shae%3BNunes%2C+Edward%3BChiongbian%2C+Victoria%3BClark%2C+Wayne%3BCovey%2C+Lirio&amp;rft.aulast=Valera&amp;rft.aufirst=Pamela&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=2210&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Psychometric+Properties+of+the+Brief+Symptom+Inventory+in+Men+under+Criminal+Justice+Involvement%3A+Implications+for+Forensic+Social+Workers+in+Practice+Settings&amp;rft.au=Valera%2C+Pamela%3BFullilove%2C+Robert%3BCali%2C+Shae%3BNunes%2C+Edward%3BChiongbian%2C+Victoria%3BClark%2C+Wayne%3BCovey%2C+Lirio&amp;rft.aulast=Valera&amp;rft.aufirst=Pamela&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=2210&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Risk Factors for Depressed Mood in a Taiwanese School-Based Sample of Adolescents: Does Spirituality Have Protective Effects?

Author: Huang, Yu-Te; Chen, Yu-Wen

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 45, Iss. 7,  (Oct 2015): 2020.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732543541?accountid=14667

Abstract: A variety of risk factors have been identified as able to engender adolescent vulnerability to depressed mood. Recently, the social work profession has started to validate spirituality as integral to individual well-being, and as a protective factor of one's poor adjustment outcome. The present study aims to investigate spirituality as a protective factor for depressed mood among Taiwanese adolescents. Risk factors examined include family economic strains, parent-adolescent conflict, negative peer relationships and academic expectation stress. Using a cross-sectional quantitative research design, we utilised the multi-stage, random cluster sampling method to select respondents. A total of 1,325 Taiwanese students from grades 10 to 12 were recruited to complete the self-reported questionnaires. Results of multiple linear regression analyses indicated that controlling for gender and age, family economic strains, parent-adolescent conflict, negative peer relationships and academic expectation stress were positively associated with depressed mood. Spirituality was found to be negatively associated with depressed mood, and to partially moderate the association between negative peer relationships and depressed mood. Findings suggest that the culturally specific concern of spirituality should be incorporated into helping depressed adolescents. Spirituality should be examined cross-culturally in social work research, education and practice. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/45/7/2020.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Risk+Factors+for+Depressed+Mood+in+a+Taiwanese+School-Based+Sample+of+Adolescents%3A+Does+Spirituality+Have+Protective+Effects%3F&amp;rft.au=Huang%2C+Yu-Te%3BChen%2C+Yu-Wen&amp;rft.aulast=Huang&amp;rft.aufirst=Yu-Te&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=2020&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Job Stress among Social Workers: Determinants and Attitude Effects in the Nordic Countries

Author: Blomberg, Helena; Kallio, Johanna; Kroll, Christian; Saarinen, Arttu

Publication info: British Journal of Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 45, Iss. 7,  (Oct 2015): 2089.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732543581?accountid=14667

Abstract: Little is known about social workers' job stress in a comparative sense, and whether job stress might negatively affect their views of clients within the welfare system. We examine these issues on the basis of cross-sectional survey data collected from professional social workers in four Nordic countries that have similar welfare systems and where workers engage in similar tasks. Job stress is measured using two indicators: workload and role conflicts. The results indicate frequent problems with job stress in all four countries, although they are especially pronounced in Finland. Social workers with limited work experience, as well as those working within the public sector, suffered the most both from an extensive workload and from role conflicts. The findings also indicate that social workers' attitudes towards clients within the welfare system are to some extent related to their level of job stress. [web URL: http://bjsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/45/7/2089.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Job+Stress+among+Social+Workers%3A+Determinants+and+Attitude+Effects+in+the+Nordic+Countries&amp;rft.au=Blomberg%2C+Helena%3BKallio%2C+Johanna%3BKroll%2C+Christian%3BSaarinen%2C+Arttu&amp;rft.aulast=Blomberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Helena&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=45&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.spage=2089&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=British+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00453102&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Correlates of Self-Rated Health Among Muslims in the United States

Author: Hodge, David R; Zidan, Tarek; Husain, Altaf; Hong, Philip Young P

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 96, Iss. 4,  (2015): 284.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753390969?accountid=14667

Abstract: Despite the large and growing population of Muslims in the United States, a paucity of research exists on the variables that may impact health status among members of this distinct cultural group. We address the lack of research by identifying correlates of self-rated health among a community sample of Muslims in the United States (N = 269). We examine the effects of demographic characteristics, health behaviors, psychological health, and contextual factors in the form of discrimination and spirituality. The results of our sequential logistic regression indicate that Muslims who were younger, married, had a graduate degree, and prayed more frequently were more likely to report higher levels of self-rated health. Conversely, respondents who reported clinically significant levels of depressive symptoms and those who reported being singled out by law enforcement as a result of being a Muslim were more likely to report poorer self-rated health. We conclude by discussing the implications of the results for social work practice with Muslims.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Correlates+of+Self-Rated+Health+Among+Muslims+in+the+United+States&amp;rft.au=Hodge%2C+David+R%3BZidan%2C+Tarek%3BHusain%2C+Altaf%3BHong%2C+Philip+Young+P&amp;rft.aulast=Hodge&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=284&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

&quot;My Worker Was There When It Really Mattered&quot;: Foster Care Youths&apos; Perceptions and Experiences of Their Relationships With Child Welfare Workers

Author: Augsberger, Astraea; Swenson, Emilie

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 96, Iss. 4,  (2015): 234.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753390974?accountid=14667

Abstract: The study examines foster care youths&apos; perceptions of their relationships with child welfare caseworkers, including the characteristics youth value and the supports they seek surrounding decision making while in foster care. Interviews were conducted with 18 foster care youth. Qualitative analysis identified perceived trust as an overarching theme connecting three subthemes: worker continuity, worker nonjudgmental listening, and worker ability/willingness to transcend the confines of the role. Workers should receive specialized training so they can better understand the developmental stages of adolescence and emerging adulthood, view these youth in the context of the youths&apos; life experiences, and refine their interpersonal skills to better respond to the needs of this age group. Policy and program efforts should focus on reducing workforce turnover.

____________________________________________________________

Foster Youth Perceptions on Educational Well-Being

Author: Schroeter, Mary Kate; Strolin-Goltzman, Jessica; Suter, Jesse; Werrbach, Matthew; Hayden-West, Kristen; Wilkins, Zachary; Gagnon, Mark; Rock, Joan

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 96, Iss. 4,  (2015): 227.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753390992?accountid=14667

Abstract: Educational outcomes for youth in foster care are concerning. The achievement gap is close to 1 school year between youth in foster care and the general population (Smithgall, Gladden, Howard, Goerge, & Courtney, 2004). Although there has been research on the educational disparities between youth in foster care and the general population, the field has not yet heard the voices of youth within the system about their educational experiences while in custody. The purposes of this manuscript are to (a) describe a study which engaged youth in foster care in sharing experiences and opinions about their educational successes in a participatory manner, (b) explore the relationship between perceived student engagement and educational outcomes, and (c) harness the suggestions of these youth in policy and practice improvements supporting their educational well-being.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Foster+Youth+Perceptions+on+Educational+Well-Being&amp;rft.au=Schroeter%2C+Mary+Kate%3BStrolin-Goltzman%2C+Jessica%3BSuter%2C+Jesse%3BWerrbach%2C+Matthew%3BHayden-West%2C+Kristen%3BWilkins%2C+Zachary%3BGagnon%2C+Mark%3BRock%2C+Joan&amp;rft.aulast=Schroeter&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=227&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Foster+Youth+Perceptions+on+Educational+Well-Being&amp;rft.au=Schroeter%2C+Mary+Kate%3BStrolin-Goltzman%2C+Jessica%3BSuter%2C+Jesse%3BWerrbach%2C+Matthew%3BHayden-West%2C+Kristen%3BWilkins%2C+Zachary%3BGagnon%2C+Mark%3BRock%2C+Joan&amp;rft.aulast=Schroeter&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=227&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Impact of In-Home Services From Child Protective Services on Child Maltreatment Recurrence: A Process Model

Author: Kang, Jiyoung

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 96, Iss. 4,  (2015): 241.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753391047?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the impact of child protective services (CPS) in-home services on child maltreatment recurrence, mediated by perceived match between services and needs and by stress. The process model was tested using structural equation modeling, with 373 caregivers who were reported to Illinois CPS. The findings indicate that among CPS in-home service components (concrete services, clinical services, and emotional support), only emotional support had indirect effects on child maltreatment recurrence; emotional support from a caseworker increased the perceived match between services and needs; the perceived match decreased perceived stress; and decreased stress reduced child maltreatment recurrence. The importance of family-centered practice in child welfare and the need for trainings are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=The+Impact+of+In-Home+Services+From+Child+Protective+Services+on+Child+Maltreatment+Recurrence%3A+A+Process+Model&amp;rft.au=Kang%2C+Jiyoung&amp;rft.aulast=Kang&amp;rft.aufirst=Jiyoung&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=241&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=The+Impact+of+In-Home+Services+From+Child+Protective+Services+on+Child+Maltreatment+Recurrence%3A+A+Process+Model&amp;rft.au=Kang%2C+Jiyoung&amp;rft.aulast=Kang&amp;rft.aufirst=Jiyoung&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=241&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Collaborative Research Challenges and Recommendations: A Case Study of Parent Engagement in Youth Mentoring (Research Note)

Author: Kaye, Lara; Cabrera, Patricia; Smith, Carolyn; Houser, Sabrina; Krolikowski, Alex

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 96, Iss. 4,  (2015): 250.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753391183?accountid=14667

Abstract: Collaboration between community-based agencies and research institutions are crucial to the growth of knowledge about community services and outcomes, as well as innovative approaches in the field. Yet, these complicated partnerships come with a number of challenges. This case study arises from a collaboration between an academic research center and a community agency designed to evaluate the impact of a parent engagement intervention on youth mentoring outcomes. We describe the study process, explain challenges from the research and agency perspectives, and conclude with concrete recommendations for future collaborations that highlight the role of clear and ongoing communication, and the potential benefits of an initial evaluability assessment phase.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Collaborative+Research+Challenges+and+Recommendations%3A+A+Case+Study+of+Parent+Engagement+in+Youth+Mentoring+%28Research+Note%29&amp;rft.au=Kaye%2C+Lara%3BCabrera%2C+Patricia%3BSmith%2C+Carolyn%3BHouser%2C+Sabrina%3BKrolikowski%2C+Alex&amp;rft.aulast=Kaye&amp;rft.aufirst=Lara&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=250&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Predictors of Stable Housing for Homeless Women Leaving a Sex Work-Exiting Program

Author: Bowen, Elizabeth A; Canfield, James P; Trostle, Amy; Harley, Dana

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 96, Iss. 4,  (2015): 268.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753391248?accountid=14667

Abstract: Women who have experienced homelessness while engaging in sex work have complex service needs. A variety of social service programs have been developed to assist women in exiting sex work, but there is little research documenting the outcomes of such programs, particularly with regard to housing. This study examined participant characteristics associated with obtaining stable housing for homeless women leaving a residential sex work-exiting program in Cincinnati, Ohio. Though a number of demographic, sex work-related, and participant need characteristics were linked to the likelihood of obtaining housing in the bivariate analyses, only participants&apos; length of stay in the program remained significant in the multivariate model. Implications for research, practice, and policy with this vulnerable population are explored.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Predictors+of+Stable+Housing+for+Homeless+Women+Leaving+a+Sex+Work-Exiting+Program&amp;rft.au=Bowen%2C+Elizabeth+A%3BCanfield%2C+James+P%3BTrostle%2C+Amy%3BHarley%2C+Dana&amp;rft.aulast=Bowen&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=268&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Predictors+of+Stable+Housing+for+Homeless+Women+Leaving+a+Sex+Work-Exiting+Program&amp;rft.au=Bowen%2C+Elizabeth+A%3BCanfield%2C+James+P%3BTrostle%2C+Amy%3BHarley%2C+Dana&amp;rft.aulast=Bowen&amp;rft.aufirst=Elizabeth&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=268&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Adolescent Eating Behavior: The Role of Indulgent Parenting

Author: Darling, Carol A; Rehm, Marsha; Coccia, Catherine; Cui, Ming

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 96, Iss. 4,  (2015): 257.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753391316?accountid=14667

Abstract: This qualitative study was set in the context of two evolving concomitant social issues: concerns with adolescent eating and health behaviors and parental indulgence. The research purpose was to gain a deeper and more insightful understanding of the family food ecosystem, parental modeling, and parental indulgence and their potential relationship to adolescent health and well-being. In all, 29 parents of 25 high school students were interviewed, and the resulting narrative data were analyzed for themes. Results showed parental concerns about weight and health, modeling of unhealthy eating habits, and soft structure as a prevalent form of parental indulgence. This research has implications for social workers, family service providers, and health providers who work with communities in developing nutrition and health education programs and policies that enhance parental knowledge, limit the effects of parental indulgence, and address adolescent decision-making skills related to their own health. Recommendations are provided to improve services for families.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Adolescent+Eating+Behavior%3A+The+Role+of+Indulgent+Parenting&amp;rft.au=Darling%2C+Carol+A%3BRehm%2C+Marsha%3BCoccia%2C+Catherine%3BCui%2C+Ming&amp;rft.aulast=Darling&amp;rft.aufirst=Carol&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=257&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Results From a Music, Imagery, and Movement Treatment Intervention in a Long-Term Care Facility

Author: Matto, Holly C; Tompkins, Catherine J; Ihara, Emily S; Inoue, Megumi; Byrd, Ayla

Publication info: Families in Society ; Milwaukee  Vol. 96, Iss. 4,  (2015): 277.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753391519?accountid=14667

Abstract: Results are presented from the first cohort of a music, imagery, and movement (MiM) treatment intervention study conducted with residents in a long-term care facility. The pre-post two-group treatment design randomly assigned participants to the 10- week MiM intervention or 10-week conversational social control group (N = 20). Cognitive functioning and depression were assessed for all study participants at baseline and the end of treatment. Quantitative data showed an impact of MiM on depression score reduction, and qualitative data suggested that participants engaged in meaningful interpersonal experiences within the MiM group. Together, the data suggest that creative arts participation enhances positive social engagement, which may be a key therapeutic mechanism of change acting on depression scores differentially across the MiM group versus the social control conversation group.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.atitle=Results+From+a+Music%2C+Imagery%2C+and+Movement+Treatment+Intervention+in+a+Long-Term+Care+Facility&amp;rft.au=Matto%2C+Holly+C%3BTompkins%2C+Catherine+J%3BIhara%2C+Emily+S%3BInoue%2C+Megumi%3BByrd%2C+Ayla&amp;rft.aulast=Matto&amp;rft.aufirst=Holly&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=96&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=277&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Families+in+Society&amp;rft.issn=10443894&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Sociodemographic Characteristics and Health Status of Asian, Hispanic, and Non-Hispanic White Family Caregivers of Older Adults Across Generations

Author: Miyawaki, Christina E

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (2015): 257.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753396389?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using the 2009 California Health Interview Survey, this study examines and compares the sociodemographic characteristics and health conditions of Asian (N = 591), Hispanic (N = 989), and White (N = 6,537) American caregivers of older adults by race/ethnicity and three successive immigrant generations. Second-generation Asian and Hispanic caregivers were the youngest while White counterparts were the oldest. The later the Asian and Hispanic generation, the better their educational attainment, but the poorer their health status. Findings suggest the importance of awareness of generational differences so that social workers can provide culturally and generationally appropriate services to racially/ethnically diverse caregiver populations more effectively.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Sociodemographic+Characteristics+and+Health+Status+of+Asian%2C+Hispanic%2C+and+Non-Hispanic+White+Family+Caregivers+of+Older+Adults+Across+Generations&amp;rft.au=Miyawaki%2C+Christina+E&amp;rft.aulast=Miyawaki&amp;rft.aufirst=Christina&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=257&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Beyond Bilingual and Bicultural: Serving Latinos in a New-Growth Community

Author: Lanesskog, Deirdre; Piedra, Lissette M; Maldonado, Stephanie

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (2015): 300.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753396436?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study explores how human services providers in "new-growth" communities -- those with rapidly growing Latino immigrant populations and limited Spanish-speaking professionals -- work with newcomers who tend to be Spanish-speaking and poor. We interviewed 25 human service professionals working with Latino immigrants in one new-growth community and found that service delivery to Latinos requires not just language ability and cultural knowledge, but the convergence of four distinct skill sets: (a) language skills; (b) cultural competence; (c) empathy; and (d) the provider&apos;s will to act. We use these findings to illuminate institutional roadblocks and strategies to create a more effective service environment for providers and the Latino newcomers they serve.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Beyond+Bilingual+and+Bicultural%3A+Serving+Latinos+in+a+New-Growth+Community&amp;rft.au=Lanesskog%2C+Deirdre%3BPiedra%2C+Lissette+M%3BMaldonado%2C+Stephanie&amp;rft.aulast=Lanesskog&amp;rft.aufirst=Deirdre&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=300&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Beyond+Bilingual+and+Bicultural%3A+Serving+Latinos+in+a+New-Growth+Community&amp;rft.au=Lanesskog%2C+Deirdre%3BPiedra%2C+Lissette+M%3BMaldonado%2C+Stephanie&amp;rft.aulast=Lanesskog&amp;rft.aufirst=Deirdre&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=300&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Reconceptualizing Hope Among Urban African-American Adolescents Through the Lens of Photovoice

Author: Harley, Dana

Publication info: Journal of Ethnic & Cultural Diversity in Social Work ; Abingdon  Vol. 24, Iss. 4,  (2015): 280.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753397719?accountid=14667

Abstract: Few studies have contextually examined the construct of hope among low-income African-American adolescents. Furthermore, little is known about how such youths assign meaning to, perceive, and experience feelings of hope. The present study utilized photovoice and in-depth interviews to better understand the perspectives of hope among low-come African-American adolescents. Sixteen (N = 16) African-American adolescents ages 13 to 17 participated in this study. Results of the study broaden the construct of hope to include caring connections, education, spirituality, "the basics," and "gonna-make-it" mentality. Implications are made for social workers and other professionals working with African-American adolescents.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Reconceptualizing+Hope+Among+Urban+African-American+Adolescents+Through+the+Lens+of+Photovoice&amp;rft.au=Harley%2C+Dana&amp;rft.aulast=Harley&amp;rft.aufirst=Dana&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=280&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Reconceptualizing+Hope+Among+Urban+African-American+Adolescents+Through+the+Lens+of+Photovoice&amp;rft.au=Harley%2C+Dana&amp;rft.aulast=Harley&amp;rft.aufirst=Dana&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=24&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=280&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Ethnic+%26+Cultural+Diversity+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=15313204&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Lessons Learned: Conducting Culturally Competent Research and Providing Interventions with Black Churches

Author: Stennis, Kesslyn Brade; Purnell, Kathy; Perkins, Emory; Fischle, Helen

Publication info: Social Work and Christianity ; Botsford  Vol. 42, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 332-349.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1759851217?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers have been challenged to understand, practice, and research from a perspective that demonstrates an appropriate level of cultural competence. This conceptual article provides guidance for those seeking to conduct culturally competent research in Black Churches. The content shared in this article is based on the authors&apos; collective 15 years of experience conducting research and trainings in Black Churches on interpersonal violence, women&apos;s empowerment, effective practices surrounding gentrification, use of narratives, and the impact of HIV/AIDS-related knowledge on risk-taking behaviors. This conceptual article discusses cultural competence in social work, the history of research in Black Churches, challenges that the authors experienced while conducting research in the Black Church, and the lessons learned regarding how to conduct effective culturally competent research in the Black Church. It is believed that this information will promote efforts to conduct culturally competent research in Black congregations and subsequently lead to providing effective interventions and social reforms that positively impact diverse populations.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Lessons+Learned%3A+Conducting+Culturally+Competent+Research+and+Providing+Interventions+with+Black+Churches&amp;rft.au=Stennis%2C+Kesslyn+Brade%3BPurnell%2C+Kathy%3BPerkins%2C+Emory%3BFischle%2C+Helen&amp;rft.aulast=Stennis&amp;rft.aufirst=Kesslyn&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=332&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Capturing the Spirit: Validation of the Attitudes toward Religious Help-Seeking Scale (ATRHSS) among African-American Christians

Author: Hardy, Kimberly

Publication info: Social Work and Christianity ; Botsford  Vol. 42, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 385-395.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1759851232?accountid=14667

Abstract: While some instruments may be developed for a discrete research study others could have significant utility as a tool for researchers and practitioners if they are found to be both culturally and psychometrically reliable measures. The persistence of religion as a central component of daily life for many African-Americans provides a rich opportunity for researchers to develop tools that can be used broadly by clinicians and clergy. Research expediency and cultural neutrality cannot be the hallmarks of measurement instrument design. If the goal of research is to gain awareness of existing viewpoints and desired outcomes among a particular population, it is important to tailor that tool to collect the views and outcomes to the population under study. The results of this study show that the ATRHSS is a reliable measure that can accomplish this goal.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Capturing+the+Spirit%3A+Validation+of+the+Attitudes+toward+Religious+Help-Seeking+Scale+%28ATRHSS%29+among+African-American+Christians&amp;rft.au=Hardy%2C+Kimberly&amp;rft.aulast=Hardy&amp;rft.aufirst=Kimberly&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=385&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Capturing+the+Spirit%3A+Validation+of+the+Attitudes+toward+Religious+Help-Seeking+Scale+%28ATRHSS%29+among+African-American+Christians&amp;rft.au=Hardy%2C+Kimberly&amp;rft.aulast=Hardy&amp;rft.aufirst=Kimberly&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=385&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Troubled Waters: The Black Church in Mississippi, A Single Subject Case Study

Author: Watson, Jerry; Stepteau-Watson, Desiree

Publication info: Social Work and Christianity ; Botsford  Vol. 42, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 369-384.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1759851248?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using rapid ethnographic methodology, the study focused on the history and current responses of a Black Missionary Baptist church in northwest Mississippi to the myriad of social problems facing the African American community in both rural and urban settings. The aim of the study was to uncover and document the history and the role of the church in the implementation of social services and outreach ministries that promote the overall improvement of quality of life and wellness of it&apos;s members and the community. The results of this study suggest that the church&apos;s social service/outreach ministries are designed, developed, and implemented in ways that purposefully and positively improve and enhance the quality of life church members and residents of North Mississippi and the surrounding areas.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Troubled+Waters%3A+The+Black+Church+in+Mississippi%2C+A+Single+Subject+Case+Study&amp;rft.au=Watson%2C+Jerry%3BStepteau-Watson%2C+Desiree&amp;rft.aulast=Watson&amp;rft.aufirst=Jerry&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=369&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+and+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Role of Men of Faith in Responding to Domestic Violence: Focus Group Themes

Author: Bent-Goodley, Tricia; Henderson, Zuleka; Youmans, Lavar; St Vil, Christopher

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 42, Iss. 3,  (October 2015): 280-295.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682834?accountid=14667

Abstract: Men of faith have a unique role to play in responding to domestic violence. Yet, there is limited information available as to how men of faith view domestic violence and their role in responding to domestic violence. This manuscript reports on focus groups conducted with men of faith to ascertain their perceptions of domestic violence and how they felt men and boys could be engaged to address this issue. Fifty-four men participated in six focus groups and seven themes emerged from their participation. These themes included a focus on individual, faith-based, and community level responses that could be utilized to engage men in the prevention of domestic violence. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=The+Role+of+Men+of+Faith+in+Responding+to+Domestic+Violence%3A+Focus+Group+Themes&amp;rft.au=Bent-Goodley%2C+Tricia%3BHenderson%2C+Zuleka%3BYoumans%2C+Lavar%3BSt+Vil%2C+Christopher&amp;rft.aulast=Bent-Goodley&amp;rft.aufirst=Tricia&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=280&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=The+Role+of+Men+of+Faith+in+Responding+to+Domestic+Violence%3A+Focus+Group+Themes&amp;rft.au=Bent-Goodley%2C+Tricia%3BHenderson%2C+Zuleka%3BYoumans%2C+Lavar%3BSt+Vil%2C+Christopher&amp;rft.aulast=Bent-Goodley&amp;rft.aufirst=Tricia&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=280&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Males; Family Violence; Charities; Religious Beliefs; Participation; Social Response; Prevention

Classification: 6143: child & family welfare

Identifier / keyword: domestic violence faith religion spirituality men

Title: The Role of Men of Faith in Responding to Domestic Violence: Focus Group Themes

Correspondence author: Bent-Goodley, Tricia  

Publication title: Social Work & Christianity

The Black Church: Responding to the Drug-Related Mass Incarceration of Young Black Males: 'If you had been here my Brother would not have died!'

Author: Moore, Sharon E; Adedoyin, A Christson; Robinson, Michael A; Boamah, Daniel A

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 42, Iss. 3,  (October 2015): 313-331.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682841?accountid=14667

Abstract: The mass incarceration of young Black males for drug-related offences is a social issue that has broad implications. Some scholars have described this as a new form of racism that needs to be addressed through the concerted effort of various institutions, including the Black Church. In this paper the authors will elucidate the past and current roles of the Black Church, discuss the utilization of the social work Theory of Empowerment and Black Church theology to address the disproportionality of drug-related mass incarceration of young Black males, focus on initiatives undertaken by the Black Church to address this issue and further, discuss the role of the Black Church in ex-drug offender reentry and reintegration. This paper will conclude with implications for the Black Church and incarcerated young Black males. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=The+Black+Church%3A+Responding+to+the+Drug-Related+Mass+Incarceration+of+Young+Black+Males%3A+%27If+you+had+been+here+my+Brother+would+not+have+died%21%27&amp;rft.au=Moore%2C+Sharon+E%3BAdedoyin%2C+A+Christson%3BRobinson%2C+Michael+A%3BBoamah%2C+Daniel+A&amp;rft.aulast=Moore&amp;rft.aufirst=Sharon&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=313&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=The+Black+Church%3A+Responding+to+the+Drug-Related+Mass+Incarceration+of+Young+Black+Males%3A+%27If+you+had+been+here+my+Brother+would+not+have+died%21%27&amp;rft.au=Moore%2C+Sharon+E%3BAdedoyin%2C+A+Christson%3BRobinson%2C+Michael+A%3BBoamah%2C+Daniel+A&amp;rft.aulast=Moore&amp;rft.aufirst=Sharon&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=313&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Black Churches' Capacity to Respond to the Mental Health Needs of African Americans

Author: Hays, Krystal

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 42, Iss. 3,  (October 2015): 296-312.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761682919?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although African Americans have a lower incidence of many mental health disorders, they continue to have poorer mental health prognoses and worse treatment outcomes than non-Hispanic Whites. Many African Americans prefer informal church support and rely on religious coping instead of visiting specialty mental health clinics for mental and emotional problems. As a result, Black churches may continue to be a preferred resource for mental health services among African Americans. However, the ability of Black churches to meet their community's mental health needs is unclear. This article argues for the need to explore the organizational capacity of Black churches to promote mental health and provides a brief review of the literature and theory regarding mental health promotion, existing church-based programs, and models of capacity building in an attempt to answer these questions. A guide for assessing the organizational capacity of Black churches is provided and the concept of capacity building is introduced. This work will inform the development and implementation of church-based mental health efforts. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Black+Churches%27+Capacity+to+Respond+to+the+Mental+Health+Needs+of+African+Americans&amp;rft.au=Hays%2C+Krystal&amp;rft.aulast=Hays&amp;rft.aufirst=Krystal&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=296&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Black+Churches%27+Capacity+to+Respond+to+the+Mental+Health+Needs+of+African+Americans&amp;rft.au=Hays%2C+Krystal&amp;rft.aulast=Hays&amp;rft.aufirst=Krystal&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=296&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Lessons Learned: Conducting Culturally Competent Research and Providing Interventions with Black Churches

Author: Stennis, Kesslyn Brade; Purnell, Kathy; Perkins, Emory; Fischle, Helen

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 42, Iss. 3,  (October 2015): 332-349.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761683110?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers have been challenged to understand, practice, and research from a perspective that demonstrates an appropriate level of cultural competence. This conceptual article provides guidance for those seeking to conduct culturally competent research in Black Churches. The content shared in this article is based on the authors' collective 15 years of experience conducting research and trainings in Black Churches on interpersonal violence, women's empowerment, effective practices surrounding gentrification, use of narratives, and the impact of HIV/AIDS-related knowledge on risk-taking behaviors. This conceptual article discusses cultural competence in social work, the history of research in Black Churches, challenges that the authors experienced while conducting research in the Black Church, and the lessons learned regarding how to conduct effective culturally competent research in the Black Church. It is believed that this information will promote efforts to conduct culturally competent research in Black congregations and subsequently lead to providing effective interventions and social reforms that positively impact diverse populations. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Lessons+Learned%3A+Conducting+Culturally+Competent+Research+and+Providing+Interventions+with+Black+Churches&amp;rft.au=Stennis%2C+Kesslyn+Brade%3BPurnell%2C+Kathy%3BPerkins%2C+Emory%3BFischle%2C+Helen&amp;rft.aulast=Stennis&amp;rft.aufirst=Kesslyn&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=332&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Introduction: Special Issue on the Black Church and Social Reform

Author: Brice, Tanya; Hardy, Kimberly

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 42, Iss. 3,  (October 2015): 273-279.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761683164?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Negro Church is the only social institution of the Negroes which started in the African forest and survived slavery; under the leadership of priests or medicine men, afterward of the Christian pastor, the Church preserved in itself the remnants of African tribal life and became after emancipation the center of Negro social life. As a result, today the Negro population of the United States is virtually divided into church congregations which are the real units of race life. It is natural, therefore, that charitable and rescue work among Negroes should first be found in the churches and reach there its greatest development (DuBois, 1898). Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Introduction%3A+Special+Issue+on+the+Black+Church+and+Social+Reform&amp;rft.au=Brice%2C+Tanya%3BHardy%2C+Kimberly&amp;rft.aulast=Brice&amp;rft.aufirst=Tanya&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=273&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Black Church Members' Perspectives on the Role of the Black Church in the Rehabilitative Process of Juvenile Sex Offenders

Author: Venable, Victoria M

Publication info: Social Work & Christianity  Vol. 42, Iss. 3,  (October 2015): 350-368.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1761684931?accountid=14667

Abstract: A developing area of research involves understanding the influence of ecological and cultural factors that support the rehabilitation of juvenile sexual offenders. The Black church provides an ideal starting point in this line of research because of the historical position the church has within the African American community. In this exploratory study, content analysis was used to review the written responses of a purposive sample of 167 Black church members from one congregation to identify what role the Black church should play in helping juvenile sex offenders and their families. The results indicate that, overall, church members believe the Black church should provide support. In addition, participants indicated that there is a strong need in the church for further education, training and collaboration with professionals and other authority figures. Church members also held parents and the home environment responsible for the offending behaviors. Considerations for church policy development and implications for social work practice are discussed. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.atitle=Black+Church+Members%27+Perspectives+on+the+Role+of+the+Black+Church+in+the+Rehabilitative+Process+of+Juvenile+Sex+Offenders&amp;rft.au=Venable%2C+Victoria+M&amp;rft.aulast=Venable&amp;rft.aufirst=Victoria&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=42&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=350&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Social+Work+%26+Christianity&amp;rft.issn=07375778&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Socialization of Culture and Coping with Discrimination Among American Indian Families: Examining Cultural Correlates of Youth Outcomes

Author: Yasui, Miwa; Dishion, Thomas J; Stormshak, Elizabeth; Ball, Alison

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 317.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837543?accountid=14667

Abstract: The current study examines the interrelations between observed parental cultural socialization and socialization of coping with discrimination, and youth outcomes among a sample of 92 American Indian adolescents and their parents in a rural reservation. Path analysis is used to examine the relationships among observed parental socialization (cultural socialization and socialization of coping with discrimination), and youth-reported perceived discrimination, ethnic identity and depression. Findings reveal that higher levels of observed parental cultural socialization and socialization of coping with discrimination predict lower levels of depression as reported by youth 1 year later. Path analyses also show that observed parental cultural socialization and socialization of coping with discrimination are positively associated with youth ethnic identity. These findings point to the importance of integrating familial socialization of culture and coping with discrimination in fostering resilience among American Indian youth.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Socialization+of+Culture+and+Coping+with+Discrimination+Among+American+Indian+Families%3A+Examining+Cultural+Correlates+of+Youth+Outcomes&amp;rft.au=Yasui%2C+Miwa%3BDishion%2C+Thomas+J%3BStormshak%2C+Elizabeth%3BBall%2C+Alison&amp;rft.aulast=Yasui&amp;rft.aufirst=Miwa&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=317&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Relationships of Dually Diagnosed Homeless Adults Following Enrollment in Housing First or Traditional Treatment Services

Author: Henwood, Benjamin F; Stefancic, Ana; Petering, Robin; Schreiber, Sarah; Abrams, Courtney; Padgett, Deborah K

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 385.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837550?accountid=14667

Abstract: Strong and effective social support is a critical element of mental health recovery, yet social support is often lacking for adults experiencing homelessness. This study examines differences in the social networks of participants newly enrolled in programs that use either a Housing First (HF) approach (i.e., provides immediate access to permanent housing with ongoing consumer-driven support services) or a treatment first (TF) approach (ie, traditional clinician-driven staircase model that requires temporary or transitional housing and treatment placements before accessing permanent housing). As compared with participants who remain in a program, those who disengage from programs have a greater proportion of mixed relationships and relationships that grow distant. Qualitative analyses suggest that HF participants regard housing as providing a stable foundation from which to reconnect or restore broken relationships. However, HF participants are guarded about close relationships for fear of being exploited due to their newly acquired apartments.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Relationships+of+Dually+Diagnosed+Homeless+Adults+Following+Enrollment+in+Housing+First+or+Traditional+Treatment+Services&amp;rft.au=Henwood%2C+Benjamin+F%3BStefancic%2C+Ana%3BPetering%2C+Robin%3BSchreiber%2C+Sarah%3BAbrams%2C+Courtney%3BPadgett%2C+Deborah+K&amp;rft.aulast=Henwood&amp;rft.aufirst=Benjamin&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=385&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Factors Associated with Staff Perceptions of the Effectiveness of Family Group Conferences

Author: Williams, Jason R; Merkel-Holguin, Lisa; Allan, Heather; Maher, Erin J; Fluke, John; Hollinshead, Dana

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 343.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837779?accountid=14667

Abstract: Family Group Conferencing (FGC) challenges the entrenched practice of child welfare service providers making decisions for children and families. Prior research shows social work staff differ in their opinions of FGC, but little research connects these attitudes to staff and agency characteristics and, ultimately, referrals and outcomes. The authors explore the influence of staff, agency, and service availability factors on staff perceptions of effectiveness of FGC using Bayesian model averaging with 252 staff surveys. The results imply that worker attitudes about FGC effectiveness are a product of attitudes towards families, type of work responsibility, and the perception of resources or services in the external environment. Among those who do not carry a caseload, endorsement of families&apos; abilities to make plans to address their issues predicts endorsement of the effectiveness of FGC. Future research should account for caseload status, service mix, and staff beliefs about family capacity when staff have discretion over implementation of family meeting interventions.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Associated+with+Staff+Perceptions+of+the+Effectiveness+of+Family+Group+Conferences&amp;rft.au=Williams%2C+Jason+R%3BMerkel-Holguin%2C+Lisa%3BAllan%2C+Heather%3BMaher%2C+Erin+J%3BFluke%2C+John%3BHollinshead%2C+Dana&amp;rft.aulast=Williams&amp;rft.aufirst=Jason&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=343&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Associated+with+Staff+Perceptions+of+the+Effectiveness+of+Family+Group+Conferences&amp;rft.au=Williams%2C+Jason+R%3BMerkel-Holguin%2C+Lisa%3BAllan%2C+Heather%3BMaher%2C+Erin+J%3BFluke%2C+John%3BHollinshead%2C+Dana&amp;rft.aulast=Williams&amp;rft.aufirst=Jason&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=343&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Network Analysis as a Toolkit for the Science of Social Work

Author: Rice, Eric; Yoshioka-Maxwell, Amanda

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 369.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837877?accountid=14667

Abstract: The science of social work can be augmented by active engagement in social network analysis. We provide an overview of both egocentric analysis (also referred to as personal network analysis) and sociometric analysis (or whole network analysis), and discuss ways of incorporating these tools into social work research. Social network analysis is particularly useful in identifying mechanisms of social change; however, the science of social work is incomplete unless understanding is linked to the processes that promote positive change. We draw on 4 articles published in conjunction with this article to demonstrate how mechanisms for social change can be modeled, and to illustrate the ease with which implications for social work practice and directions for future intervention efforts emerge from such analyses.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Network+Analysis+as+a+Toolkit+for+the+Science+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Rice%2C+Eric%3BYoshioka-Maxwell%2C+Amanda&amp;rft.aulast=Rice&amp;rft.aufirst=Eric&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=369&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Network+Analysis+as+a+Toolkit+for+the+Science+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Rice%2C+Eric%3BYoshioka-Maxwell%2C+Amanda&amp;rft.aulast=Rice&amp;rft.aufirst=Eric&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=369&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

A Validation Study of the Posttraumatic Growth Inventory Among Survivors of Clergy-Perpetrated Child Sexual Abuse

Author: Saltzman, Leia Y; Easton, Scott D; Salas-Wright, Christopher P

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 305.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837942?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study is to assess the structure of the Posttraumatic Growth Inventory (PTGI), a widely used measure, in a previously untested population; namely a sample of adult males who reported experiencing clergy-perpetrated childhood sexual abuse (N= 273). Using confirmatory factor analysis, 4 models are selected to test the underlying structure of posttraumatic growth in this sample: a single latent factor measuring general posttraumatic growth; a 3-factor model, which organizes the 21-item scale into 3 latent structures (ie, perception of self, interpersonal relationships, and philosophy of life); the original 5-factor structure of the PTGI (ie, relating to others, new possibilities, personal strength, spiritual growth, and appreciation of life); and the same 5-factor model with a second order factor measuring overall posttraumatic growth. Findings suggest both the original 5-factor model and a 5-factor model with a second order factor using the 21 items of the PTGI offer acceptable fit.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=A+Validation+Study+of+the+Posttraumatic+Growth+Inventory+Among+Survivors+of+Clergy-Perpetrated+Child+Sexual+Abuse&amp;rft.au=Saltzman%2C+Leia+Y%3BEaston%2C+Scott+D%3BSalas-Wright%2C+Christopher+P&amp;rft.aulast=Saltzman&amp;rft.aufirst=Leia&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=305&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Network Correlates of Methamphetamine, Heroin, and Cocaine Use in a Sociometric Network of Homeless Youth

Author: Barman-Adhikari, Anamika; Rice, Eric; Winetrobe, Hailey; Petering, Robin

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 433.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794837982?accountid=14667

Abstract: Peer influence is one the most consistent correlates of drug use among youth. However, beyond the dyadic level, there is the possibility that peer influence also functions at a more macro or group level, which calls for a better understanding of how positioning within larger social networks affects youth behaviors. Yet, whereas extant research among homeless youth indicates that having substance-using peers is associated with youth&apos;s own substance use, the issue of how peer influence operates in conjunction with network structure and position especially with regards to substance use is relatively unexplored. Using Freeman&apos;s Event Based Approach, a sociometric network of 136 homeless youth (39.6% female; 38.1% African American; mean age 20.81 years) were recruited in 2008 at 1 drop-in agency in Los Angeles. Self-administered questionnaires and interviewer-administered social network interviews captured individual and network alters&apos; risk behaviors. Network structure and position was assessed with UCINET and visualized with NetDraw.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Network+Correlates+of+Methamphetamine%2C+Heroin%2C+and+Cocaine+Use+in+a+Sociometric+Network+of+Homeless+Youth&amp;rft.au=Barman-Adhikari%2C+Anamika%3BRice%2C+Eric%3BWinetrobe%2C+Hailey%3BPetering%2C+Robin&amp;rft.aulast=Barman-Adhikari&amp;rft.aufirst=Anamika&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=433&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Network+Correlates+of+Methamphetamine%2C+Heroin%2C+and+Cocaine+Use+in+a+Sociometric+Network+of+Homeless+Youth&amp;rft.au=Barman-Adhikari%2C+Anamika%3BRice%2C+Eric%3BWinetrobe%2C+Hailey%3BPetering%2C+Robin&amp;rft.aulast=Barman-Adhikari&amp;rft.aufirst=Anamika&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=433&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Personal Networks: A Hypothesized Mediator in the Association Between Incarceration and HIV Risk Behaviors Among Women With Histories of Homelessness

Author: Kriegel, Liat S; Hsu, Hsun-Ta; Wenzel, Suzanne L

Publication info: Journal of the Society for Social Work and Research ; Chicago  Vol. 6, Iss. 3,  (Fall 2015): 407.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1794838049?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research on women with histories of homelessness shows both higher rates of incarceration and higher rates of HIV-risk behaviors. However, understanding homeless women&apos;s experiences with the criminal justice system is hampered by the dearth of social network research with this population. This study uses a sample of 445 women with histories of homelessness. Women self-reported lifetime experience of incarceration and recent 6-month participation in 3 risk behaviors: multiple sex partnership, sex trade, and crack/cocaine use. Path analysis is used to answer whether incarceration is associated with the 3 risk behaviors and if risky personal networks mediate those relationships. Findings indicate that incarceration is directly and indirectly (through personal networks) associated with all 3 risk behaviors. This study validates a need to intervene earlier in the criminal justice process and to incorporate personal network composition into interventions for women with histories of homelessness and incarceration.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Personal+Networks%3A+A+Hypothesized+Mediator+in+the+Association+Between+Incarceration+and+HIV+Risk+Behaviors+Among+Women+With+Histories+of+Homelessness&amp;rft.au=Kriegel%2C+Liat+S%3BHsu%2C+Hsun-Ta%3BWenzel%2C+Suzanne+L&amp;rft.aulast=Kriegel&amp;rft.aufirst=Liat&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=407&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+the+Society+for+Social+Work+and+Research&amp;rft.issn=23342315&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Perception of Family Functioning among Addicts and their Codependents

Author: Iyer, Krishna; Mehta, Snehal; Lobo, Aninha

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2015): 591.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946443?accountid=14667

Abstract: Addiction affects family functioning; patient and family often differ on perceptions of familial dynamics and dysfunctions. Thirty Indian male patients undergoing a rehabilitation programme for Substance Use Disorders (SUD) in Kripa Foundation, Mumbai and their significant others (SO) family member were administered the Family Assessment Device. The difference in perception between patient and family member on the Roles&apos; subscale was statistically significant and the difference on General Family Functioning&apos; subscale approached significance. The mean scores on the subscales (except for `Problem Solving&apos; and `Affective Involvement&apos;) were indicative of problems that need to be addressed in patient recovery and reintegration into families.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+Perception+of+Family+Functioning+among+Addicts+and+their+Codependents&amp;rft.au=Iyer%2C+Krishna%3BMehta%2C+Snehal%3BLobo%2C+Aninha&amp;rft.aulast=Iyer&amp;rft.aufirst=Krishna&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=591&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Factors Influencing Employee Engagement: An Exploratory Study

Author: Sharma, Baldev R; Agrawal, Soni

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2015): 485.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946500?accountid=14667

Abstract: Employee engagement as an emerging concept predicts employee performance, organisational commitment as well as the organisation&apos;s financial performance (Bates, 2004). Hailer and others (2002) reported that employee engagement is positively related to customer satisfaction, loyalty, profitability, and productivity. Although the term employee engagement is becoming popular, it has its basis in practice rather than in theory and empirical research (Robinson and others, 2004). There is apparently a dearth of academic literature on employee engagement. This study is a modest attempt towards filling the said gap.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Factors+Influencing+Employee+Engagement%3A+An+Exploratory+Study&amp;rft.au=Sharma%2C+Baldev+R%3BAgrawal%2C+Soni&amp;rft.aulast=Sharma&amp;rft.aufirst=Baldev&amp;rft.date=2015-10-01&amp;rft.volume=76&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=485&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Indian+Journal+of+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00195634&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Mixed-Methods Approach in Research on Community Based Organisations

Author: Singh, Anita Ranjan; Babu, T

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2015): 537.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946528?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using mixed methods is often proposed as desirable, but not an often used research design. By using a mixed methods design in exploratory and survey phases, this study shows how qualitative and quantitative methods can help to gain a better understanding of the community based organisation&apos;s (CBO) structure, social capital, and community capacity building. It also studies how the Appreciative Inquiry training provided to the CBOs in Karnataka, impacts sustainable community development. Finally, this paper proposes a research design for studying complex phenomenon and developing theory through a combination of cases and analysis of other qualitative data, variance and path analysis.

Cognitive Interviews as a Method for Effective Cross-Cultural Research: A Study of Organisational Leaders in Sweden and India

Author: Biswas, Urmi Nanda; Allard, Karin; Harenstam, Annika; Poussette, Anders

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2015): 521.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946701?accountid=14667

Abstract: The research attempts to demonstrate the effectiveness of cognitive interview (CI) techniques used while finalising the survey instrument for establishing the conceptual equivalence of ethical values practiced by the managers of the selected organisations from Sweden and India. The results provided substantive insight into the cultural differences that influence ethical values in the organisations. The paper highlights the types and applications of CI in the study of the different fields of human behaviour.

Lifeworlds of Children of Sex Workers in Budhwar Peth

Author: Rawat, Ayushi; Kumar, Shewli

Publication info: Indian Journal of Social Work ; Bombay  Vol. 76, Iss. 4,  (Oct 2015): 573.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1819946764?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article is based on primary research done with children of sex workers in Pune&apos;s Budhwar Peth. It attempts to locate the `lifeworlds&apos; of the children of sex workers. The research utilised qualitative and participatory techniques to elicit information from the children. It locates specific situations within which the children live in and their experiences of growing up. Through the narratives of the children, the article tries to give a thick description of their perceptions of their everyday and poses questions to the existing interventions.
