A Review of Sexual Assault Information on College Web Sites

Author: Schwartz, Rachel; McMahon, Sarah; Broadnax, Jesica

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 275.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732569058?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents a comprehensive review of information available on campus Web sites at all four-year colleges and universities in New Jersey. This study used a descriptive, content analysis methodology with a sample that consisted of 28 college and university Web pages. To evaluate the Web sites, ecological approaches were rated with a checklist created to document the presence and extent of information about sexual assault, including five key areas: (1) general information about sexual assault, (2) the availability of services for students, (3) information about how to report an incident of sexual assault, (4) whether there was a department exclusively dedicated to the school&apos;s response to sexual assault, and (5) information about the existence of a policy prohibiting sexual assault on campus. Almost all of the schools provided policies and information about services for students. However, the comprehensiveness of the information and the ease of finding it varied greatly by campus. The article concludes with a discussion of the implications for social workers and those responding to survivors of sexual assault on a college campus. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/275.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Review+of+Sexual+Assault+Information+on+College+Web+Sites&amp;rft.au=Schwartz%2C+Rachel%3BMcMahon%2C+Sarah%3BBroadnax%2C+Jesica&amp;rft.aulast=Schwartz&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachel&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=275&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=A+Review+of+Sexual+Assault+Information+on+College+Web+Sites&amp;rft.au=Schwartz%2C+Rachel%3BMcMahon%2C+Sarah%3BBroadnax%2C+Jesica&amp;rft.aulast=Schwartz&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachel&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=275&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

"A Curious Inconsistency": The Discourse of Social Work on the 1922 Married Women's Independent Nationality Act and the Intersecting Dynamics of Race and Gender in the Laws of Immigration and Citizenship

Author: Park, Yoosun

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 560.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732569366?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Cable Act of 1922 provided for the first time in U.S. history, independent citizenship for married women. Henceforth, a woman&apos;s citizenship was a status separate from her husband&apos;s. A victory for activists, including many prominent social workers who had long-pursued equal political status for women, the Cable Act benefited many but not all women. Using primary archival data and published social work writings from the era, this study analyzes how prominent immigrant-serving social workers responded to the Cable Act, and the bifurcated sets of raced and gendered biases that shaped this and other policies and practices of immigration and citizenship.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%22A+Curious+Inconsistency%22%3A+The+Discourse+of+Social+Work+on+the+1922+Married+Women%27s+Independent+Nationality+Act+and+the+Intersecting+Dynamics+of+Race+and+Gender+in+the+Laws+of+Immigration+and+Citizenship&amp;rft.au=Park%2C+Yoosun&amp;rft.aulast=Park&amp;rft.aufirst=Yoosun&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=560&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%22A+Curious+Inconsistency%22%3A+The+Discourse+of+Social+Work+on+the+1922+Married+Women%27s+Independent+Nationality+Act+and+the+Intersecting+Dynamics+of+Race+and+Gender+in+the+Laws+of+Immigration+and+Citizenship&amp;rft.au=Park%2C+Yoosun&amp;rft.aulast=Park&amp;rft.aufirst=Yoosun&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=560&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

"Don't Be Trying to Box Folks In": Older Women's Sexuality

Author: Bradway, Katherine E; Beard, Renée L

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 504.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732569375?accountid=14667

Abstract: Youth-centeredness presents a "deficit model" of aging and stigmatizes elders. Social constructions reduce the aging process to illness and asexuality. Western conflations of beauty and youth render older adult sexuality disgusting and/or abnormal. Grounded theory methods utilized to interview older women (N = 20) about love, intimacy, and sexuality reveal more complex and heterogeneous narratives than we are socialized to believe. While important commonalities were reported across age cohorts, relationship statuses, and sexual orientations, sociohistorical as well as psychosocial factors, such as the feminist movement, attitudes about aging, experiences of ageism, and views on sexuality, demonstrate both within- and between-group differences.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%22Don%27t+Be+Trying+to+Box+Folks+In%22%3A+Older+Women%27s+Sexuality&amp;rft.au=Bradway%2C+Katherine+E%3BBeard%2C+Ren%C3%A9e+L&amp;rft.aulast=Bradway&amp;rft.aufirst=Katherine&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=504&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=%22Don%27t+Be+Trying+to+Box+Folks+In%22%3A+Older+Women%27s+Sexuality&amp;rft.au=Bradway%2C+Katherine+E%3BBeard%2C+Ren%C3%A9e+L&amp;rft.aulast=Bradway&amp;rft.aufirst=Katherine&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=504&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Work/Life Fit: The Intersection of Developmental Life Cycle and Academic Life Cycle

Author: Tower, Leslie E; Faul, Anna; Hamilton-Mason, Johnnie; Collins, Wanda Lott; Gibson, Priscilla

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 519.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732574213?accountid=14667

Abstract: A successful academic trajectory tends to be characterized by a singular Standard, that is, doctoral degree, tenure-track position, tenure, and promotion to full professor, administration, or both. Significant numbers of social work faculty struggle with the intersection of the traditional career life cycle and the developmental life cycle. This article discusses barriers that emerge from the intersection of these life cycles. Strategies to support career success and family satisfaction are also discussed, including, current law, work/life policies, self-care, and mentoring.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Work%2FLife+Fit%3A+The+Intersection+of+Developmental+Life+Cycle+and+Academic+Life+Cycle&amp;rft.au=Tower%2C+Leslie+E%3BFaul%2C+Anna%3BHamilton-Mason%2C+Johnnie%3BCollins%2C+Wanda+Lott%3BGibson%2C+Priscilla&amp;rft.aulast=Tower&amp;rft.aufirst=Leslie&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=519&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Work%2FLife+Fit%3A+The+Intersection+of+Developmental+Life+Cycle+and+Academic+Life+Cycle&amp;rft.au=Tower%2C+Leslie+E%3BFaul%2C+Anna%3BHamilton-Mason%2C+Johnnie%3BCollins%2C+Wanda+Lott%3BGibson%2C+Priscilla&amp;rft.aulast=Tower&amp;rft.aufirst=Leslie&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=519&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Notes on Same-Sex Marriage: Concerns for Feminist Social Workers

Author: DeFilippis, Joseph Nicholas; Anderson-Nathe, Ben; Panichelli, Meg

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 461.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732574468?accountid=14667

Abstract: Using a critical feminist and social work lens, this article argues that the mainstream gay rights movement and its singular focus on marriage has consistently neglected the most marginal among lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) communities and has instead focused on advancing the interests of elite and advantaged lesbian and gay people. We link professional obligations and values outlined in the National Association of Social Workers Code of Ethics to feminist and queer (both activist and scholarly) critiques of the gay marriage movement in three main ways. First, we explore the priorities of LGBT communities and draw on data that suggest there are more pressing needs than marriage equality for LGBT communities of color, who are poor, transgender, hold precarious citizenship, or are without citizenship. We then trouble that issue of marriage being upheld as the LGBT priority, as this diverts resources from these more pressing needs. Second, we look at marriage in Capitalist America and how marriage is used as a form of privatization and a tool of neoliberalism. Finally, we discuss the diversity of queer families and how they really live, while highlighting that the marriage movement stigmatizes and dismantles protections for nonhegemonic family structures. In moving forward, we argue that social workers must engage more critically with the many intersectional issues related to the gay marriage movement than it has in the past and employ feminist social work values and principles when working with LGBT communities.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Notes+on+Same-Sex+Marriage%3A+Concerns+for+Feminist+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=DeFilippis%2C+Joseph+Nicholas%3BAnderson-Nathe%2C+Ben%3BPanichelli%2C+Meg&amp;rft.aulast=DeFilippis&amp;rft.aufirst=Joseph&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=461&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Notes+on+Same-Sex+Marriage%3A+Concerns+for+Feminist+Social+Workers&amp;rft.au=DeFilippis%2C+Joseph+Nicholas%3BAnderson-Nathe%2C+Ben%3BPanichelli%2C+Meg&amp;rft.aulast=DeFilippis&amp;rft.aufirst=Joseph&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=461&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

"When Things Are Really Complicated, We Call the Social Worker": Post-Hip-Fracture Care Transitions for Older People

Author: Sims-Gould, Joanie; Byrne, Kerry; Hicks, Elisabeth; Franke, Thea; Stolee, Paul

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 257.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732574469?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social workers play a key role in the delivery of interdisciplinary health care. However, in the past decade, concerns have been raised about social work&apos;s sustainability and contributions in a changing health care sector. These changes come at a time when older patients are more complex and vulnerable than ever before. In this article, using a strengths-based approach, the authors examine the key contributions made by social workers working with older patients with hip fracture as they strive to achieve successful care transitions. Twenty-five interviews with health care professionals (HCPs) were conducted and then analyzed using an analytical coding framework. Although social workers are vital, they are often underused and overlooked in the care of hip fracture patients. The authors sketch the important contributions that social workers make to care transitions after hip fracture, specifically informational continuity; patient-HCP relational continuity; conflict resolution; mediation among family, patient, and HCP (for example, doctors and nurses); collaboration with family caregivers and community supports; and relocation counseling. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/257.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=%22When+Things+Are+Really+Complicated%2C+We+Call+the+Social+Worker%22%3A+Post-Hip-Fracture+Care+Transitions+for+Older+People&amp;rft.au=Sims-Gould%2C+Joanie%3BByrne%2C+Kerry%3BHicks%2C+Elisabeth%3BFranke%2C+Thea%3BStolee%2C+Paul&amp;rft.aulast=Sims-Gould&amp;rft.aufirst=Joanie&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=257&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=%22When+Things+Are+Really+Complicated%2C+We+Call+the+Social+Worker%22%3A+Post-Hip-Fracture+Care+Transitions+for+Older+People&amp;rft.au=Sims-Gould%2C+Joanie%3BByrne%2C+Kerry%3BHicks%2C+Elisabeth%3BFranke%2C+Thea%3BStolee%2C+Paul&amp;rft.aulast=Sims-Gould&amp;rft.aufirst=Joanie&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=257&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Indigenous knowledge: Ends or means?

Author: Bar-On, Arnon

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 6,  (Nov 2015): 780.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732574610?accountid=14667

Abstract: Scholars and practitioners in an array of disciplines, and increasingly in social work and social development, are looking to indigenous knowledge in their search for a host of ideological and pragmatic ends. Following the enumeration and analysis of these ends, this article concludes that while indigenous knowledge may perhaps provide a feel-good way of searching for answers in difficult times, its utility in achieving most of its pragmatic ends, as differentiated from its ideological ones, is questionable. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/58/6/780.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Indigenous+knowledge%3A+Ends+or+means%3F&amp;rft.au=Bar-On%2C+Arnon&amp;rft.aulast=Bar-On&amp;rft.aufirst=Arnon&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=780&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Indigenous+knowledge%3A+Ends+or+means%3F&amp;rft.au=Bar-On%2C+Arnon&amp;rft.aulast=Bar-On&amp;rft.aufirst=Arnon&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=780&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Second Coming: Faith-Based Organizations, Public Services, and Policy

Author: Watkinson, Ailsa M

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 476.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732574668?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social welfare has increasingly been downloaded to community and faith-based organizations (FBOs). Many FBOs adhere to religious fundamentalist views that challenge the rights of equality-seeking groups and conflict with international human rights laws and the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Regulations or policies governing how FBOs provide public services are lacking or nonexistent This article explores guidelines emanating from court decisions on the Charter of Rights and Freedoms&apos; interpretation of religious freedom and provides a framework through which governments may develop policy governing the delivery of faith-based public services in a manner consistent with equality rights.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Second+Coming%3A+Faith-Based+Organizations%2C+Public+Services%2C+and+Policy&amp;rft.au=Watkinson%2C+Ailsa+M&amp;rft.aulast=Watkinson&amp;rft.aufirst=Ailsa&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=476&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=The+Second+Coming%3A+Faith-Based+Organizations%2C+Public+Services%2C+and+Policy&amp;rft.au=Watkinson%2C+Ailsa+M&amp;rft.aulast=Watkinson&amp;rft.aufirst=Ailsa&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=476&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

In Search of Women of Color in the Social Work Journal Literature (1998-2007)

Author: Barretti, Marietta Anne

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 427.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732574671?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article reports secondary analysis findings that categorized the content on women of color in 17 selected social work journals over 10 years. Included are the number of articles per journal containing content on women of color, referents to their social identities, themes, curricular areas, authors&apos; analytical methods, and the amount and degree of feminist content. Data are compared to women overall. In most areas, the content on women of color was proportionate to women overall with some noted exceptions especially in social identity, and feminist and human rights content Implications for social work are discussed.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=In+Search+of+Women+of+Color+in+the+Social+Work+Journal+Literature+%281998-2007%29&amp;rft.au=Barretti%2C+Marietta+Anne&amp;rft.aulast=Barretti&amp;rft.aufirst=Marietta&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=427&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Youth Homelessness: Prevalence and Associations with Weight in Three Regions

Author: Cutuli, J J; Steinway, Caren; Perlman, Staci; Herbers, Janette E; Eyrich-Garg, Karin M; Willard, Joe

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 316.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732574699?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study investigated the utility of the Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS) to document associations between homeless status and weight while estimating the prevalence of youth homelessness in three regions. A school-based survey, the YRBS includes youths who have been difficult to involve in past research. Analysis of 2011 YRBS data produced population-weighted estimates of youth homelessness prevalence separately for Connecticut, Delaware, and Philadelphia. Public high school students anonymously reported their housing status, height, and weight on the YRBS. Height and weight were converted to body mass index (BMI) percentile-for-age scores. Homelessness was associated with higher BMI percentile scores for youths compared with nonhomeless peers. Associations between BMI percentile and different forms of homelessness (homeless with family, unaccompanied homeless without family) were explored at each site. Estimates of one-month homelessness prevalence ranged from 3.9 percent to 5.9 percent at each site. Homelessness, especially family homelessness, is associated with risk for higher BMI. The YRBS is an informative tool for estimating the prevalence of youth homelessness, expanding on what is known through other, more commonly used methods. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/316.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Youth+Homelessness%3A+Prevalence+and+Associations+with+Weight+in+Three+Regions&amp;rft.au=Cutuli%2C+J+J%3BSteinway%2C+Caren%3BPerlman%2C+Staci%3BHerbers%2C+Janette+E%3BEyrich-Garg%2C+Karin+M%3BWillard%2C+Joe&amp;rft.aulast=Cutuli&amp;rft.aufirst=J&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=316&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Youth+Homelessness%3A+Prevalence+and+Associations+with+Weight+in+Three+Regions&amp;rft.au=Cutuli%2C+J+J%3BSteinway%2C+Caren%3BPerlman%2C+Staci%3BHerbers%2C+Janette+E%3BEyrich-Garg%2C+Karin+M%3BWillard%2C+Joe&amp;rft.aulast=Cutuli&amp;rft.aufirst=J&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=316&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social work is context-bound: The need for indigenization of social work practice in Nigeria

Author: Ugiagbe, Ernest Osas

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 6,  (Nov 2015): 790.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732576910?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article evaluates how and to what extent indigenization of social work profession and practice in Nigeria can occur. There is a need to indigenize social work because of the shortcomings and inadequacies of Western social work theories and practices in addressing Nigerian social problems. For social work to succeed here, culture and tradition must be taken into consideration. Social work education and practices should incorporate some valuable local social-cultural practices. Social work should be indigenized in local contexts, that is, to accommodate the socio-cultural complexities of the over 350 ethnic groups and cultures in Nigeria. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/58/6/790.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+work+is+context-bound%3A+The+need+for+indigenization+of+social+work+practice+in+Nigeria&amp;rft.au=Ugiagbe%2C+Ernest+Osas&amp;rft.aulast=Ugiagbe&amp;rft.aufirst=Ernest&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=790&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Repositioning three models of social policy with reference to East Asian welfare systems

Author: Lin, Ka; Chan, Raymond KH

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 6,  (Nov 2015): 831.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732577515?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article compares features of the redistributive, developmental and productivist models of social policy. Using East Asian welfare systems as examples, it illustrates the application of the productivist and developmental models, and describes the contextual factors influencing these models. It argues that each model is an outgrowth of a particular social, economic and political context. When the context changes, the choice of model will also change, as shown in the recent development of redistributive policies in the East Asian region. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/58/6/831.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Repositioning+three+models+of+social+policy+with+reference+to+East+Asian+welfare+systems&amp;rft.au=Lin%2C+Ka%3BChan%2C+Raymond+KH&amp;rft.aulast=Lin&amp;rft.aufirst=Ka&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=831&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Understanding and Addressing Religious and Spiritual Struggles in Health Care

Author: Abu-Raiya, Hisham; Pargament, Kenneth I; Exline, Julie J

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): E126.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732584247?accountid=14667

Abstract: Religious and spiritual struggles are expressions of conflict, question, and doubt regarding matters of faith, God, and religious relationships. They can take three main forms: (1) supernatural struggles, (2) interpersonal struggles, and (3) intrapersonal struggles. Empirical studies have consistently linked these struggles to poorer health and well-being. The findings of these studies highlight the clinical relevance of religious and spiritual struggles, suggesting that health care providers, who strive to deliver effective and religiously and spiritually sensitive treatment, cannot avoid this potentially influential aspect in the lives of their clients. This article aimed to assist mental health professionals in understanding and addressing this phenomenon. Toward this end, the authors summarized the empirical findings in this area, proposed a conceptual framework to explicate these findings, and suggested five recommendations that can be applied to address religious and spiritual struggles in treatment. The authors hope that this article serves as a valuable guide for health care providers interested in this stimulating yet challenging area of research and practice. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/e126.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+and+Addressing+Religious+and+Spiritual+Struggles+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.au=Abu-Raiya%2C+Hisham%3BPargament%2C+Kenneth+I%3BExline%2C+Julie+J&amp;rft.aulast=Abu-Raiya&amp;rft.aufirst=Hisham&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E126&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+and+Addressing+Religious+and+Spiritual+Struggles+in+Health+Care&amp;rft.au=Abu-Raiya%2C+Hisham%3BPargament%2C+Kenneth+I%3BExline%2C+Julie+J&amp;rft.aulast=Abu-Raiya&amp;rft.aufirst=Hisham&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E126&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Conflict; Health; Supernatural; Well being; Health care services; Mental health; Health professions

Classification: 6140: illness & health care

____________________________________________________________

Application of Attachment Theory in Clinical Social Work

Author: Blakely, Thomas Joseph; Dziadosz, Gregory M

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 283.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732584359?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article proposes the use of attachment theory in clinical social work practice. This theory is very appropriate in this context because of its fit with social work concepts of person-in-situation, the significance of developmental history in the emergence of psychosocial problems, and the content of human behavior in the social environment. A literature review supports the significance of the theory. Included are ideas about how attachment styles and working models may be used in assessment and treatment to help clients achieve a secure attachment style. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/283.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Application+of+Attachment+Theory+in+Clinical+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Blakely%2C+Thomas+Joseph%3BDziadosz%2C+Gregory+M&amp;rft.aulast=Blakely&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=283&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Hakka cultural roots: Metalinguistic awareness and practice principles

Author: Leung, Carol A

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 6,  (Nov 2015): 802.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732584534?accountid=14667

Abstract: Through examining the Hakka cultural heritage, the author describes a specific Chinese ethnic group -- &apos;global Hakka&apos; -- based on its unique Hakka multifaceted languages. These &apos;guest&apos; immigrants integrate their culture and languages into the host province in China or host country outside of China. They seek cultural permanency through active participation in learning a new language or another Chinese dialect for cultural adjustment. Through learning from these clients&apos; strong adjustment abilities, social workers can practice metalinguistic awareness skills with the application of 10 principles by means of self-evaluation and reflection around their clients&apos; linguistic learning motivation. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/58/6/802.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Hakka+cultural+roots%3A+Metalinguistic+awareness+and+practice+principles&amp;rft.au=Leung%2C+Carol+A&amp;rft.aulast=Leung&amp;rft.aufirst=Carol&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=802&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Hakka+cultural+roots%3A+Metalinguistic+awareness+and+practice+principles&amp;rft.au=Leung%2C+Carol+A&amp;rft.aulast=Leung&amp;rft.aufirst=Carol&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=802&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Smoking Display-Time Trends in Iranian Movies

Author: Heydari, Gholamreza; Ahmady, Arezoo Ebn; Lando, Harry A; Chamyani, Fahimeh; Masjedi, Mohammad Reza; Shadmehr, Mohammad B; Fadaizadeh, Lida; Chaibakhsh, Samira

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): E156.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732584619?accountid=14667

Abstract: In spite of current laws against any tobacco-related advertisement, many viewers believe Iran&apos;s movie industry has yet to curb this practice. The aim of this study was to present trends in smoking display time by Iranian movie stars to encourage authorities to develop legislation aimed at reducing direct and indirect tobacco advertising. In this cross-sectional study, a list of all movies in the past three decades was prepared, and the top 10 best sellers of each year were purchased, amounting to 300 movies. Cohen&apos;s kappa was used to confirm reliability of the measurements. The average total smoking times over the decades under study (1981 to 2011) were 39.1 seconds, 67 seconds, and 99.3 seconds, respectively. Analysis of variance revealed that onscreen smoking times for male, female, and leading roles have significantly increased. Results indicate that smoking by movie actors could be a critical factor in the increased prevalence of smoking among younger Iranians. Concerned authorities should undertake more effective approaches to prevent on-screen tobacco use in movies. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/e156.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Smoking+Display-Time+Trends+in+Iranian+Movies&amp;rft.au=Heydari%2C+Gholamreza%3BAhmady%2C+Arezoo+Ebn%3BLando%2C+Harry+A%3BChamyani%2C+Fahimeh%3BMasjedi%2C+Mohammad+Reza%3BShadmehr%2C+Mohammad+B%3BFadaizadeh%2C+Lida%3BChaibakhsh%2C+Samira&amp;rft.aulast=Heydari&amp;rft.aufirst=Gholamreza&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E156&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Smoking+Display-Time+Trends+in+Iranian+Movies&amp;rft.au=Heydari%2C+Gholamreza%3BAhmady%2C+Arezoo+Ebn%3BLando%2C+Harry+A%3BChamyani%2C+Fahimeh%3BMasjedi%2C+Mohammad+Reza%3BShadmehr%2C+Mohammad+B%3BFadaizadeh%2C+Lida%3BChaibakhsh%2C+Samira&amp;rft.aulast=Heydari&amp;rft.aufirst=Gholamreza&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E156&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Understanding Community Resilience Through the Accounts of Women Living in West Bank Refugee Camps

Author: Darychuk, Anthea; Jackson, Suzanne

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 447.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732584932?accountid=14667

Abstract: Throughout the West Bank, 19 camps are home to more than 200,000 Palestinians, more than half of whom are female. The Israeli occupation and attendant poverty cause communities inside West Bank camps to live under stress and violence particularly limiting to women. Although often portrayed as "helpless victims of war," little research has been done to explore how women understand their contributions to the resilience of refugee communities. Female refugees were interviewed about their household roles and community participation. This inquiry shows how female refugees navigate the impacts of gender on community resilience.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Understanding+Community+Resilience+Through+the+Accounts+of+Women+Living+in+West+Bank+Refugee+Camps&amp;rft.au=Darychuk%2C+Anthea%3BJackson%2C+Suzanne&amp;rft.aulast=Darychuk&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthea&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=447&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The gap between theory and practice in social work

Author: Al-Ma'seb, Hend; Alkhurinej, Anwar; Alduwaihi, Mohammed

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 6,  (Nov 2015): 819.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732584982?accountid=14667

Abstract: The gap between theory and practice in social work has been the subject of considerable debate over recent years. This study aims at exploring the reasons for the gap between theory and practice in Kuwait, and the most significant reason for this gap. A convenient sample of 342 participated from different institutions. The results showed that the major reasons for the gap were job challenges and requirements, followed by curriculum, job description, and self-development. Results also showed significant differences between gender, type of university, major of the participants, and the institutions in which the participants work. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/58/6/819.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+gap+between+theory+and+practice+in+social+work&amp;rft.au=Al-Ma%27seb%2C+Hend%3BAlkhurinej%2C+Anwar%3BAlduwaihi%2C+Mohammed&amp;rft.aulast=Al-Ma%27seb&amp;rft.aufirst=Hend&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=819&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The immigration detention center as a transnational problem: Implications for international social work

Author: Furman, Rich; Sanchez, Michelle; Ackerman, Alissa; Ung, Tien

Publication info: International Social Work ; London  Vol. 58, Iss. 6,  (Nov 2015): 813.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732585544?accountid=14667

Abstract: Over the last decade in the United States, there has been a rapid intensification of the criminalization of immigration. At the nexus of this criminalization is a new institution with potentially profound consequences for transnational migrants, an especially vulnerable population now receiving increased attention from the social work profession. This article explores this phenomenon and its relevance for international social work. [web URL: http://isw.sagepub.com/content/58/6/813.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=The+immigration+detention+center+as+a+transnational+problem%3A+Implications+for+international+social+work&amp;rft.au=Furman%2C+Rich%3BSanchez%2C+Michelle%3BAckerman%2C+Alissa%3BUng%2C+Tien&amp;rft.aulast=Furman&amp;rft.aufirst=Rich&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=58&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=813&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=International+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=00208728&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Alzheimer's Patient Familial Caregivers: A Review of Burden and Interventions

Author: Wennberg, Alexandra; Dye, Cheryl; Streetman-Loy, Blaiz; Pham, Hiep

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): E162.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732585572?accountid=14667

Abstract: As the prevalence of Alzheimer&apos;s disease and related disorders (ADRD) increases, so does the staggering cost of providing care for patients with ADRD. Often, family or friends of patients adopt the role of primary caregiver (CG). Although this arrangement offsets the direct financial costs, the burden of caregiving can lead to detrimental physical, financial, and mental outcomes, including a 600 percent increased risk of spousal CGs developing dementia. The most successful interventions use multidisciplinary approaches, but results range from weak to moderate. This review presents current literature on CG burden, risk factors, and interventions, and proposes recommendations for future research. The authors advocate for a holistic, interdisciplinary team approach, including physicians, nurses, and social workers, focused on improving health and quality of life concurrently in both the CG and the care recipient. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/e162.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Alzheimer%27s+Patient+Familial+Caregivers%3A+A+Review+of+Burden+and+Interventions&amp;rft.au=Wennberg%2C+Alexandra%3BDye%2C+Cheryl%3BStreetman-Loy%2C+Blaiz%3BPham%2C+Hiep&amp;rft.aulast=Wennberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Alexandra&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E162&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Alzheimer%27s+Patient+Familial+Caregivers%3A+A+Review+of+Burden+and+Interventions&amp;rft.au=Wennberg%2C+Alexandra%3BDye%2C+Cheryl%3BStreetman-Loy%2C+Blaiz%3BPham%2C+Hiep&amp;rft.aulast=Wennberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Alexandra&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E162&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Caregivers; Physicians; Health; Patients; Nurses; Risk; Senility; Interdisciplinary approach; Quality of life; Social workers; Risk factors; Alzheimer's disease; Quality of health care

Classification: 6140: illness & health care

Title: Alzheimer's Patient Familial Caregivers: A Review of Burden and Interventions

____________________________________________________________

Qualitative Study: Exploring the Experiences of Family Caregivers within an Inpatient Neurology and Neurosurgery Hospital Setting

Author: Khabarov, Dmytro; Dimitropoulos, Gina; McGillicuddy, Patti

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 290.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732586074?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this study was to further understanding of what it means for family caregivers to be included in their relatives&apos; care and identify what type of care they are providing. This study used a qualitative research design to recruit 12 participants, who were family caregivers, from the adult neurology and neurosurgery units at a hospital located in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. The data were collected using semistructured interviews, which were conducted in person and ranged between 30 and 60 minutes in length. Analysis of the data was conducted using phenomenological guidelines and principles. Upon review, the results indicated that the participants shared common experiences that were grouped into three main themes: (1) unfamiliarity with the hospital environment and procedures, (2) identifying the hidden realities of families and caregivers, and (3) strengthening collaborative dialogues and opportunities. Overall, this study exemplified that the need to continue to recognize family caregivers&apos; experiences and their involvement is paramount in being able to understand how and in what way patient care can be better optimized collaboratively, during treatment delivery and recovery stages. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/290.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Qualitative+Study%3A+Exploring+the+Experiences+of+Family+Caregivers+within+an+Inpatient+Neurology+and+Neurosurgery+Hospital+Setting&amp;rft.au=Khabarov%2C+Dmytro%3BDimitropoulos%2C+Gina%3BMcGillicuddy%2C+Patti&amp;rft.aulast=Khabarov&amp;rft.aufirst=Dmytro&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=290&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Qualitative+Study%3A+Exploring+the+Experiences+of+Family+Caregivers+within+an+Inpatient+Neurology+and+Neurosurgery+Hospital+Setting&amp;rft.au=Khabarov%2C+Dmytro%3BDimitropoulos%2C+Gina%3BMcGillicuddy%2C+Patti&amp;rft.aulast=Khabarov&amp;rft.aufirst=Dmytro&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=290&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

What Is War? Female Veterans Experiences of Combat in Iraq and Afghanistan

Author: Strong, Jessica D; Findley, Patricia; McMahon, Sarah; Angell, Beth

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 489.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732586763?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many female service members deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan report experiencing some level of combat. However, female veterans may perceive combat and threat differently than their male counterparts. A feminist analysis of semistructured interviews was used to examine female veterans&apos; (N = 12) definitions of and experiences with combat Participants described combat in three themes--experiencing combat-related events, witnessing combat-related events, and feeling threatened. Veterans also described a flexible definition of "combat veteran," comparing their experiences to others&apos; to determine their status. This study has implications for practice, research, and policy on veterans, including broadening the assessment of combat.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=What+Is+War%3F+Female+Veterans+Experiences+of+Combat+in+Iraq+and+Afghanistan&amp;rft.au=Strong%2C+Jessica+D%3BFindley%2C+Patricia%3BMcMahon%2C+Sarah%3BAngell%2C+Beth&amp;rft.aulast=Strong&amp;rft.aufirst=Jessica&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=489&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Patient Satisfaction in Italian Childhood Cancer Survivors: Human Aspects of Treatment as a Key Factor in Patients' Quality of Life

Author: Tremolada, Marta; Schiavo, Simone; Varotto, Stefania; Basso, Giuseppe; Pillon, Marta

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): E148.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732586926?accountid=14667

Abstract: The purpose of this study was to illustrate childhood cancer survivors&apos; perceptions about their experience with the health services and their perceived quality of life. Participants were 213 Northeast Italian childhood cancer survivors with a mean age of 19.4 years (SD = 2.95). Survivors were mostly affected by hematologic disorders (n = 114); 99 had different types of solid tumors. A 30-item questionnaire assessing patient satisfaction was given to the survivors, who had finished treatment on average 9.8 years previously (SD = 4.13). Socioeconomic, medical, and health-related quality of life (HRQOL) data were also collected. The authors ran a varimax rotated factor analysis on patient satisfaction questions and identified four psychometrically robust dimensions (58.15 percent of variance): (1) medical communication and technical quality of care, (2) accessibility and physical environment satisfaction, (3) interpersonal manner, and (4) empathy. Childhood cancer survivors over 18 years old mostly declared that they had a worse HRQOL compared with controls. Patients with the greatest number of years since treatment and who declared that they had more energy at present were also more satisfied with the health care they received. The questionnaire is a promising research tool to give direct voice to childhood cancer survivors. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/e148.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Patient+Satisfaction+in+Italian+Childhood+Cancer+Survivors%3A+Human+Aspects+of+Treatment+as+a+Key+Factor+in+Patients%27+Quality+of+Life&amp;rft.au=Tremolada%2C+Marta%3BSchiavo%2C+Simone%3BVarotto%2C+Stefania%3BBasso%2C+Giuseppe%3BPillon%2C+Marta&amp;rft.aulast=Tremolada&amp;rft.aufirst=Marta&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E148&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Patient+Satisfaction+in+Italian+Childhood+Cancer+Survivors%3A+Human+Aspects+of+Treatment+as+a+Key+Factor+in+Patients%27+Quality+of+Life&amp;rft.au=Tremolada%2C+Marta%3BSchiavo%2C+Simone%3BVarotto%2C+Stefania%3BBasso%2C+Giuseppe%3BPillon%2C+Marta&amp;rft.aulast=Tremolada&amp;rft.aufirst=Marta&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E148&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Puerto Rican-Born Women in the United States: Contextual Approach to Immigration Challenges

Author: Bekteshi, Venera; van Hook, Mary; Matthew, Lenore

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 298.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732586974?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study focused on how acculturative stress and psychological distress affect Puerto Rican-born women residing in the United States. Mediation path analysis was used to estimate relationships between contextual factors, acculturative stress, and psychological distress. The fit of the data to the final model was adequate as estimated using chi-square analysis, comparative fit index, Tucker-Lewis Index, and root-mean-square error of approximation. Racial discrimination (b = 0.38, p = .01), difficulties visiting family abroad (b = 0.26, p = .03), and age at immigration (b = 0.19, p = .03) were positively associated with acculturative stress. The factor English skills (b = -0.31, p = .02) was negatively associated with acculturative stress. Racial discrimination had the strongest effect on acculturative stress, followed by English skills, difficulties visiting family abroad, and age at immigration. Racial discrimination (b = 0.39, p = .01) and financial constraints (b = 0.30, p = .01) were positively associated with psychological distress. Racial discrimination affected the women&apos;s psychological distress the most, followed by economic contexts (financial constraints). This study informs practitioners in considering the significant contextual factors relevant to the psychological distress of Puerto Rican-born women. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/298.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Puerto+Rican-Born+Women+in+the+United+States%3A+Contextual+Approach+to+Immigration+Challenges&amp;rft.au=Bekteshi%2C+Venera%3Bvan+Hook%2C+Mary%3BMatthew%2C+Lenore&amp;rft.aulast=Bekteshi&amp;rft.aufirst=Venera&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=298&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Puerto+Rican-Born+Women+in+the+United+States%3A+Contextual+Approach+to+Immigration+Challenges&amp;rft.au=Bekteshi%2C+Venera%3Bvan+Hook%2C+Mary%3BMatthew%2C+Lenore&amp;rft.aulast=Bekteshi&amp;rft.aufirst=Venera&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=298&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Mothering and Domestic Violence: Situating Maternal Protectiveness in Gender

Author: Wendt, Sarah; Buchanan, Fiona; Moulding, Nicole

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 533.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732587070?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article aimed to explore the complications and complexities of mothering in the contexts of domestic violence. Through interviews with nine women who had mothered in domestic violence, it was found that women do attempt to protect children from physical and emotional harm; however, the climate of fear, power, and control present in domestic violence limits protection, and women try pleasing their partners to prevent violence. This article argues the hostility of this environment needs to be acknowledged in constructions of protection and gender needs to be central in understandings of mothering in domestic violence.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Mothering+and+Domestic+Violence%3A+Situating+Maternal+Protectiveness+in+Gender&amp;rft.au=Wendt%2C+Sarah%3BBuchanan%2C+Fiona%3BMoulding%2C+Nicole&amp;rft.aulast=Wendt&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=533&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work Participation in Accountable Care Organizations under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act

Author: Gehlert, Sarah; Collins, Stacy; Golden, Robyn; Horn, Philip

Publication info: Health & Social Work ; Oxford  Vol. 40, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): E142.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732587077?accountid=14667

Abstract: Little is known about social workers employed in accountable care organizations (ACOs) under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Because no listing of these social workers exists, the authors distributed a survey through Listservs likely to be read by health social workers, including Listservs of the National Association of Social Workers and of three large health social work organizations. The 17-item survey asked about characteristics of social workers employed by ACOs, their roles within the organizations, and the characteristics of ACOs that employ social workers. One hundred sixty-seven of 395 of those responding were employed by an ACO. The vast majority held an MSW degree and had several years of experience in health care. Most ACOs employed 10 or fewer social workers, and most of those were supervised by non-social workers. The authors suggest the need for training in how to promote health social work to other health care professionals. [web URL: http://hsw.oxfordjournals.org/content/40/4/e142.abstract]

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+Participation+in+Accountable+Care+Organizations+under+the+Patient+Protection+and+Affordable+Care+Act&amp;rft.au=Gehlert%2C+Sarah%3BCollins%2C+Stacy%3BGolden%2C+Robyn%3BHorn%2C+Philip&amp;rft.aulast=Gehlert&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E142&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+Participation+in+Accountable+Care+Organizations+under+the+Patient+Protection+and+Affordable+Care+Act&amp;rft.au=Gehlert%2C+Sarah%3BCollins%2C+Stacy%3BGolden%2C+Robyn%3BHorn%2C+Philip&amp;rft.aulast=Gehlert&amp;rft.aufirst=Sarah&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=40&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=E142&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Health+%26+Social+Work&amp;rft.issn=03607283&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Casa Rut: A Multilevel Analysis of a "Good Practice" in the Social Assistance of Sexually Trafficked Nigerian Women

Author: Caretta, Martina Angela

Publication info: Affilia ; Thousand Oaks  Vol. 30, Iss. 4,  (Nov 2015): 546.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1732587177?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article depicts the case study of Casa Rut ("Ruth Home"), a shelter for victims of sexual trafficking, who are predominantly Nigerian women. Since 1995, through the implementation of article 18 of the consolidated act on immigration, Casa Rut has offered a program of social assistance and rehabilitation to 340 women, 120 of whom were Nigerian and 41 of whom were pregnant. Data gathered during a 2-month internship between 2008 and 2009 are examined in light of the context of the Nigerian sexual trafficking operation and its collusion with the local criminal organization Camorra in the surroundings of the southern Italian city of Caserta. Casa Rut&apos;s interventions are analyzed according to a multilevel perspective and the nature of victims&apos; case management in order to assess whether this nongovernmental organization can be considered to represent "good practice" in the fight against sexual trafficking. Hence, the work of the social cooperative NewHope--a tailoring cooperative founded in 2004 by Casa Rut that provides vocational training to formerly trafficked women--is considered in relation to the long-term employment needs of sexual trafficking victims. Human and sexual trafficking has not been extensively investigated within social work even though practitioners are best positioned to address this issue. This work therefore aims to facilitate social service providers in their everyday activities by presenting multilevel evidence of good practice in the fight against the modern day slave trade.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Casa+Rut%3A+A+Multilevel+Analysis+of+a+%22Good+Practice%22+in+the+Social+Assistance+of+Sexually+Trafficked+Nigerian+Women&amp;rft.au=Caretta%2C+Martina+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Caretta&amp;rft.aufirst=Martina&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=546&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Affilia&amp;rft.atitle=Casa+Rut%3A+A+Multilevel+Analysis+of+a+%22Good+Practice%22+in+the+Social+Assistance+of+Sexually+Trafficked+Nigerian+Women&amp;rft.au=Caretta%2C+Martina+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Caretta&amp;rft.aufirst=Martina&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=30&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.spage=546&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Affilia&amp;rft.issn=08861099&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: Slavery; Management; Pregnancy; Females; Trade; Victims; Employment; Immigration; Training; Kidnapping; Rehabilitation; Vocational education; Case management; Social workers; Working women; Social work

Recruitment and Reasons for Non-Participation in a Family-Coping-Orientated Palliative Home Care Trial (FamCope)

Author: Ammari, Anne Birgitte Hjuler, MHSc RN; Hendriksen, Carsten, DMSciMD; Rydahl-Hansen, Susan, PhD MNSc

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology ; London  Vol. 33, Iss. 6,  (2015): 655.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753391007?accountid=14667

Abstract: Cancer patients and their family caregivers need support to cope with physical, psychosocial, and existential problems early in the palliative care trajectory. Many interventions target patient symptomatology, with health care professionals acting as problem-solvers. Family coping, however, is a new research area within palliative care. The FamCope intervention was developed to test if a nurse-led family-coping-orientated palliative home care intervention would help families cope with physical and psychosocial problems at home -- together as a family and in interaction with health care professionals. However, an unexpectedly high number of families declined participation in the trial. We describe and discuss the recruitment strategy and patient reported reasons for non-participation to add to the knowledge about what impedes recruitment and to identify the factors that influence willingness to participate in research aimed at family coping early in the palliative care trajectory. Patients with advanced cancer and their closest relative were recruited from medical, surgical, and oncological departments. Reasons for non-participation were registered and characteristics of participants and non-participants were compared to evaluate differences between subgroups of non-participants based on reasons not to participate and reasons to participate in the trial. A total of 65.9% of the families declined participation. Two main categories for declining participation emerged: first, that the "burden of illness is too great" and, second, that it was "too soon" to receive this kind of support. Men were more likely to participate than women. Patients in the "too soon" group had similar characteristics to participants in the trial. Timing of interventions and readiness of patients and their relatives seems to affect willingness to receive a family-coping-orientated care approach and impeded recruitment to this trial. Our findings can be used in further research and in clinical practice in order to construct interventions and target relevant populations for early family-coping-orientated palliative care.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Recruitment+and+Reasons+for+Non-Participation+in+a+Family-Coping-Orientated+Palliative+Home+Care+Trial+%28FamCope%29&amp;rft.au=Ammari%2C+Anne+Birgitte+Hjuler%2C+MHSc+RN%3BHendriksen%2C+Carsten%2C+DMSciMD%3BRydahl-Hansen%2C+Susan%2C+PhD+MNSc&amp;rft.aulast=Ammari&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne+Birgitte&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=655&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Recruitment+and+Reasons+for+Non-Participation+in+a+Family-Coping-Orientated+Palliative+Home+Care+Trial+%28FamCope%29&amp;rft.au=Ammari%2C+Anne+Birgitte+Hjuler%2C+MHSc+RN%3BHendriksen%2C+Carsten%2C+DMSciMD%3BRydahl-Hansen%2C+Susan%2C+PhD+MNSc&amp;rft.aulast=Ammari&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne+Birgitte&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=655&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Trajectories of Anxiety Among Women with Breast Cancer: A Proxy for Adjustment from Acute to Transitional Survivorship

Author: Saboonchi, Fredrik, PhD; Petersson, Lena-Marie, PhD; Wennman-Larsen, Agneta, PhD; Alexanderson, Kristina, PhD; Vaez, Marjan, PhD

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology ; London  Vol. 33, Iss. 6,  (2015): 603.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753391086?accountid=14667

Abstract: Anxiety is one of the main components of distress among women with breast cancer (BC), particularly in the early stages of the disease. Changes in anxiety over time may reflect the process of adjustment or lack thereof. The process of adjustment in the traverse of acute to transitional stages of survivorship warrants further examination. To examine the trajectory of anxiety and the specific patterns that may indicate a lack of adjustment within 2 years following BC surgery, survey data from a 2-year prospective cohort study of 725 women with BC were analyzed by Mixture Growth Modelling and logistic regression and Analysis of Variance. A piece-wise growth curve displayed the best fit to the data, indicating a significant decrease in anxiety in the first year, followed by a slower rate of change during the second year. Four classes of trajectories were identified: High Stable, High Decrease, Mild Decrease, and Low Decrease. Of these, High Stable anxiety showed the most substantive indications of lack of adjustment. This subgroup was predominantly characterized by sociodemographic variables such as financial difficulties. Our results support an emphasis on the transitional nature of the stage that follows the end of primary active treatment and imply a need for supportive follow up care for those who display lack of adjustment at this stage.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Trajectories+of+Anxiety+Among+Women+with+Breast+Cancer%3A+A+Proxy+for+Adjustment+from+Acute+to+Transitional+Survivorship&amp;rft.au=Saboonchi%2C+Fredrik%2C+PhD%3BPetersson%2C+Lena-Marie%2C+PhD%3BWennman-Larsen%2C+Agneta%2C+PhD%3BAlexanderson%2C+Kristina%2C+PhD%3BVaez%2C+Marjan%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Saboonchi&amp;rft.aufirst=Fredrik&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=603&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Trajectories+of+Anxiety+Among+Women+with+Breast+Cancer%3A+A+Proxy+for+Adjustment+from+Acute+to+Transitional+Survivorship&amp;rft.au=Saboonchi%2C+Fredrik%2C+PhD%3BPetersson%2C+Lena-Marie%2C+PhD%3BWennman-Larsen%2C+Agneta%2C+PhD%3BAlexanderson%2C+Kristina%2C+PhD%3BVaez%2C+Marjan%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Saboonchi&amp;rft.aufirst=Fredrik&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=603&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Spiritual Well-Being in Hispanic and Non-Hispanic Survivors of Allogeneic Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation

Author: Prince, Patricia, MEd, MSW, LICSW; Mitchell, Sandra A, PhD, CRNP; Wehrlen, Leslie, RN, MSN, OCN®; Childs, Richard, MD; Savani, Bipin, MD; Yang, Li, MS; Bevans, Margaret, PhD, RN, AOCN®, FAAN

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology ; London  Vol. 33, Iss. 6,  (2015): 635.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753391161?accountid=14667

Abstract: Research suggests that spiritual well-being positively contributes to quality of life during and following cancer treatment. This relationship has not been well-described in ethnically diverse survivors of allogeneic transplantation. This study compares spiritual well-being and quality of life of Hispanic (n = 69) and non-Hispanic (n = 102) survivors. Hispanic participants were significantly younger and reported significantly greater spiritual well-being than non-Hispanic survivors. Survivors with higher spiritual well-being had significantly better quality of life. Meaning and Peace significantly predicted quality of life. Although Hispanic survivors report greater spiritual well-being, Meaning and Peace, irrespective of ethnicity, have a salutary effect on quality of life.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Spiritual+Well-Being+in+Hispanic+and+Non-Hispanic+Survivors+of+Allogeneic+Hematopoietic+Stem+Cell+Transplantation&amp;rft.au=Prince%2C+Patricia%2C+MEd%2C+MSW%2C+LICSW%3BMitchell%2C+Sandra+A%2C+PhD%2C+CRNP%3BWehrlen%2C+Leslie%2C+RN%2C+MSN%2C+OCN%C2%AE%3BChilds%2C+Richard%2C+MD%3BSavani%2C+Bipin%2C+MD%3BYang%2C+Li%2C+MS%3BBevans%2C+Margaret%2C+PhD%2C+RN%2C+AOCN%C2%AE%2C+FAAN&amp;rft.aulast=Prince&amp;rft.aufirst=Patricia&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=635&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Spiritual+Well-Being+in+Hispanic+and+Non-Hispanic+Survivors+of+Allogeneic+Hematopoietic+Stem+Cell+Transplantation&amp;rft.au=Prince%2C+Patricia%2C+MEd%2C+MSW%2C+LICSW%3BMitchell%2C+Sandra+A%2C+PhD%2C+CRNP%3BWehrlen%2C+Leslie%2C+RN%2C+MSN%2C+OCN%C2%AE%3BChilds%2C+Richard%2C+MD%3BSavani%2C+Bipin%2C+MD%3BYang%2C+Li%2C+MS%3BBevans%2C+Margaret%2C+PhD%2C+RN%2C+AOCN%C2%AE%2C+FAAN&amp;rft.aulast=Prince&amp;rft.aufirst=Patricia&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=635&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Profiling the Psychological Training and Support Needs of Oncology Staff, and Evaluating the Effectiveness of a Level 2 Psychological Support Training Program Workshop

Author: Laffan, Amanda J, BSc(Hons); Daniels, Jo, BSc(Hons); Osborn, Michael, BSc(Hons), PhD

Publication info: Journal of Psychosocial Oncology ; London  Vol. 33, Iss. 6,  (2015): 686.

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/1753391265?accountid=14667

Abstract: The importance of training non-psychology healthcare professionals to offer psychological support to people with cancer is becoming increasingly recognized. This small-scale pilot project sought to identify the training and support needs of oncology staff and to evaluate the effectiveness of a Level 2 Psychological Support Training Program workshop. Semi-structured interviews with five members of multidisciplinary oncology staff identified that training needs were primarily around communication skills, recognizing and dealing with emotions, offering support and empathy, and self-care. Pre and post-training questionnaires developed with these themes in mind revealed that the Level 2 Training Program workshops run in this network of hospitals are effective in increasing participants&apos; levels of perceived knowledge and confidence across each of these domains. Recommendations are made for further enhancing this effectiveness.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservices&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.atitle=Profiling+the+Psychological+Training+and+Support+Needs+of+Oncology+Staff%2C+and+Evaluating+the+Effectiveness+of+a+Level+2+Psychological+Support+Training+Program+Workshop&amp;rft.au=Laffan%2C+Amanda+J%2C+BSc%28Hons%29%3BDaniels%2C+Jo%2C+BSc%28Hons%29%3BOsborn%2C+Michael%2C+BSc%28Hons%29%2C+PhD&amp;rft.aulast=Laffan&amp;rft.aufirst=Amanda&amp;rft.date=2015-11-01&amp;rft.volume=33&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.spage=686&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Psychosocial+Oncology&amp;rft.issn=07347332&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
